In doing so, I am going to commence with a brief summation of Australiaâs refugee and humanitarian program. I am the minister responsible, together with Senator Vanstone, for the settlement of our refugees and I am therefore extremely familiar with the program.

speech.para: Sadly, very few members of even this House, let alone the general public, are aware of what Australia does for the most deprived and vulnerable refugees in the world. We have a program of taking each year 13,000 refugees and humanitarian arrivals, mostly from the Horn of Africa countries: Eritrea, Ethiopia, the Congo, Sudan, Burundi, Liberia and Rwandaâthe most war-torn and impoverished countries in the world. We take refugees from the camps in Tanzania, Kenya and Egypt, and they have often been in those camps for several years. We are one of only three countries in the world who do it. There are but three countries in the world with an organised refugee and humanitarian programâthe United States, Canada and Australia. So do not give me this âI am ashamed to be Australianâ stuff that you here repeated every now and then. As soon as someone says that, forget it. That is just moral proselytising; that is just self-righteous reinforcement. Australia has one of the proudest records with regard to refugees anywhere in the world bar none. Actually, after the United States, we take the most numberânot per capita but in actual terms. The United States has a program for about 28,000 refugees, ours is 13,000 and Canadaâs is slightly lower than ours. And we increased it. It was 12,000 a year ago; it is now 13,000.

Our settlement programs, where we meet migrants at the airport and give them intensive assistance with accommodation, employment, education and integration in the community, are studied throughout the world. People come here and look at how we do it. Canada and the United States will, in all humility, study our programs to see how to do their settlement better. So the Howard governmentâs refugee humanitarian policy is amongst the best in the world. We rely on the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to nominate those refugees. As I say, it is dominated by Horn of Africa countriesâpeople escaping the worst imaginable human circumstances. If they have not themselves suffered physical abuse, then they have certainly witnessed it. So there is a lot of trauma- and torture-counselling issues in the settlement also needed for them. We should be proud of that. We should be talking about it. Instead it gets swamped by media reports about unlawful arrivalsâthe asylum seekers of the past few years.

Let us understand this: our international responsibilities are to political refugees, not economic refugees. The United Nations tells us that there are 17 million refugees identifiable throughout the world. Eight and a half million are the most vulnerable and the most depressed. Australia does not accept economic refugees. We have an orderly program. By the way, can you believe that only five countries in the world have an immigration program: the United States, Canada, New Zealand, Israel and Australia. Australiaâs program is in the national interest. It is a program of 140,000 people, 95,000 of whom are business or skilled migrants. On top of that we take 13,000 refugees. We do not take economic refugees. To the best of my knowledge, no country in the world does. We take political refugees. When people arrive here unlawfully by boat then of course we have to assess their claims. And that is why you have mandatory detentionâa Labor Party policy that we have continued in government. There is nothing unreasonable or wrong about the policy at that point, at the starting point, where we determine their identities and examine their claims for political asylum. The simple fact is that a lot of unlawful arrivals are not going to assist in the establishment of their identity because that might place them as economic refugees rather than as political refugees. It takes time to work through the absence of material or the misleading material available to us.

Let us put this in context. Australia has every right, as the general public well know and understand, to determine the identity of people who arrive here unannounced and unlawfully, particularly when we are bringing in so many refugees and are so dedicated to assisting themâwith their most troubled of experiences, background and pastâto settle in Australia as quickly as possible. We want these people to realise their ambitions and their hopes for themselves and their families as quickly as humanly possible.

That is the starting point. We have to compassionately, sympathetically and speedily process people who are in detention. We agree with that and we have endeavoured to do that at all times. Now we have legislation before the House that softens some aspects of mandatory detention. I do not want the House or the public believing that this is an overnight revelation. For some time now, the government has been softening its detention policy. We have established alternative accommodation for families, for children especially, outside of detention centres.

talk.start.para: âSo you had it wrong.

âOver a period of time, as numbers have decreased, we have been able to soften it. There are interjections from the opposition. Let us turn to the opposition because I want to place on the record the framework within which the government operates and the very compassionate, humanitarian and generous program we have for refugees. Did you know that in 1994 the Labor Party had 342 children in detention? Did you know that the year we came to government, 1996, they had 191 children in detention? There was no residential project then. There was no community housing for them. The Labor Party, in the six years since they introduced mandatory detention, never softened it and never provided choice to apply for alternative arrangements for families and the like.

speech.para: The Labor Party have this chant and the Leader of the Opposition led it: children behind razor wires. They have practised it, they have worked it, maybe they have even focus-group tested itâchildren behind razor wires. If you read the Hansard from yesterday, you will see the Labor members have all been told to get that up to morally blackmail the government. There are 53 children in detention as of today compared to the Labor Partyâs hundreds of children in detention. It is remarkable, isnât it? The Labor Party have no credibility on this issue.

I will not go through each memberâs contribution; time will not allow it. The contribution I will concentrate on was that given by the Leader of the Opposition yesterday. This is the man who holds himself out to be the alternative prime minister. A more superficial and contrived presentation you would never find. Leaving aside the deficiencies of the Leader of the Oppositionâs presentation, the aspect I would like to concentrate on is his slanderous and totally unfair attack on the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. A basic rule in politics is that you never repeat a negative because that is just kicking an own goal, but I am actually going to quote the Leader of the Opposition, even though it is an attack on the department because the air needs to be cleared in regard to his allegations. He said:

quote.para: ... the bungling, disaster prone Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs presumably continues on its merry way, detaining Australian residents, deporting Australian citizens and keeping women and children behind razor wire ... A department out of control, rocked by scandal after scandal, without any scrutiny or check from a judicial review process, emerges unscathed.

speech.para: That is a cowardly attack on overwhelmingly dedicated officials of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. Firstly, there are eight million transactions or contacts by the department over the course of a year. Almost all of them are done professionally with care and attention and as quickly as circumstances will allow. Given eight million dealings with the public, you would think there would be tens of thousands of complaints. But, in actual fact, there are very few, particularly as they relate to detention. There were 88,000 persons detained last year for overstaying or for working without the correct visa or the like. Some of those detentions might have been for a few minutes; some of them might have been in the foyer of the office of the departmentâit is not that they went into detention centres. Of those, we have referred 201 cases to the Palmer inquiry for consideration. I actually believe a number of those 201 will show that the department acted reasonably. If you raid a brothel or an orchard, which is the standard practice of compliance, people for good reasons are not going to immediately offer their identity or do not have the papers with them. They do not carry their passports or their visas with them. Of the 201, I believe in a number of them it will be found that the department acted reasonably. But that represents 0.2 per cent of detentions. Forget your eight millionâlet us just look at the 88,000 detentions each year. We have raised a query about 0.2 per cent of detentions and we want the Palmer inquiry to advise on them. That is a remarkably small number.

Instead the Leader of the Opposition is using hyperbole, exaggerating and misrepresenting, because he talked in the pluralââdetaining Australian residents, deporting Australian citizensâ. We have the Rau and Alvarez cases. They are singular; they are not in the plural. The Rau and Alvarez cases are a tragedy without doubt, and reform has already taken place in identity processes, but the issue also involves a number of state government agencies and also the difficult and complex issue of mental health. I believe the Alvarez and Rau cases are more revealing about mental health treatment and identification than they are about detention. But I will wait for the Palmer inquiry.

The Leader of the Opposition then talked about the department being without any scrutiny or check from a judicial review process. My heavens! Without check or judicial review! DIMIA is the most scrutinised, accountable department in the entire Commonwealth Public Service, I would think. There is the Ombudsman and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner, all of the courts and parliamentary oversight committees. There is a steady stream of people going through detention centres, and always has been, checking the levels of service, accommodation and the like. But the point is: this is a difficult, challenging area for any government. When I talk about 0.2 per cent of detentions being referred to Palmer for consideration, as I stress, I believe that not all or even a majorityâI do not know; I am speculatingâwill be found to be of concern. I am told that was the same as when Labor was in power. This is a difficult area.

As Mr Cadman, the member for Mitchell, said earlier on, Australian citizenship is the most prized in the world. Of course people are going to come here and do their level best. The member for Mitchell said that he has no hostility towards somebody trying to use the system or whatever legal rights or avenues are available to acquire Australian residency. Why wouldnât people do that if it is the best social security, education and health system in the worldâeven as we strive to improve them? There is no inbuilt hostility towards people seeking to become an Australian citizen.

On the other hand, we are trying to run an immigration policy, and rules are rules. Listening to some members of the opposition, you would think they are saying, âLetâs tear up the rule book.â For instance, the member for Chisholm, talking about a case I am very familiar with, complained about a Lebanese man who applied for a spouse visa because he is married to an Australian citizen. Fair enough, but the rules are that you have to apply offshore unless there are special circumstances. In this case, because the child was seriously ill, I intervened using my powers under the act. I am very familiar with this case. That man deliberately and knowingly avoided the rules. The member for Chisholm complained that it took time to decide this issue. You bet it takes time. He knowingly avoided the rules. If you look at his immigration history, it will verify this.

Do we have a rule book or not? Do not confuse the visa overstayers with the unlawful arrivals or the asylum seekers. That is part of the ignorance of members of the opposition. Many of their contributions are riddled with it. There is a big difference between visa overstayers seeking a migration outcome via political asylum and people who are genuine political refugees from Afghanistan, Iraq, Iran and the like.

The member for Reid knows this. I see that the shadow minister for immigration is subject to some criticism. I have a lot of sympathy for him. All he has tried to do recently is discuss some of the realities of immigration policy. When you have millions of inquiries from people wanting to come to Australia and hundreds of thousandsâapproximately 450,000âapplications a year, you have to have some rules. You have to have some criteria and you have to do the right thing. That means applying offshore. We do have unlawful arrivals and we must deal with them. We do so as compassionately as possible, as does DIMIA.

The contribution of the Leader of the Opposition was not a contribution by an alternative Prime Minister. This was a contribution by somebody who was seizing the political moment. The Leader of the Opposition does himself no credit. His generalised slurs and slander against DIMIA are most unfair. Above all else, they are utterly incorrect. What we need from people of seniority like the Leader of the Opposition is thoughtful contributions. He will set the tone for his backbenchers and his shadow ministers. A person as politically beleaguered as he is will seize on any opportunity to turn it to his political advantage.
In regard to the Leader of the Oppositionâs second reading amendment, the first paragraph of significance is:

quote.para: ... an Inspector-General of Detention should be appointed ...

speech.para: That is just a duplication of the role of the Ombudsman. It is another bureaucracy. The Labor Party will always revert to bureaucracy and complicated internal processes when devoid of real, meaningful ideas. It is an absurd suggestion when you have the Ombudsman already in this field. The second aspect of major interest is:

quote.para: ... the Ombudsman should report monthly on the continued detention of all detainees held for 90 days.

speech.para: Ninety days! That is an administrative nightmare, as the member for Reid, with a good understanding of immigration operations, will tell you in a moment of honestyâin private. He will not say it publicly. You cannot have the Ombudsman reporting on detention after 90 days. It would be an administrative nightmare that would be utterly unworkable.

All in all, I have to say that I am disappointed in most of the contributions by members opposite, particularly in the contribution by Mr Beazley, who in his attempt to discredit DIMIA only discredits himself. Like my colleagues, I am proud of the legislation we bring to the House. We believe it is line with public expectations. It will win wide public support. It is the result of considered and, for the most part, harmonious party room deliberations. I thank all members of the government for their constructive contributions that have allowed us to reach this point, which is to soften and introduce a more flexible and orderly detention policy. (Time expired)

speech.para: In what was unfortunately a singularly ill-informed contribution, the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs denigrated this amendment by saying that it was just a matter of creating another bureaucracy. He tried to minimise the crisis affecting this department by saying repeatedly that there had been a single case of illegal detention of Australians. Once again I say it is singularly ill-informed. He seems to think that the Iranian man detained for two weeks in WA who had obvious psychiatric problems and was not an Australian should not be counted. He said that there were only 200 cases referred to the Palmer inquiry. I hope he understandsâI hope he was not trying to misleadâthat there are another 928 cases being looked at by the department to see whether they should be referred.

We have here a singular need for oversight and for transparency in this area. We are a long way from the comments of the Prime Minister in 2002 when he could credibly say in his mind that until he had evidence of bad administration or systemic failure he was not going to do anything other than support the department. That comment, of course, is very much under the hammer at the moment. We have seen over many months of exposes the urgent need for oversight. We have a situation where male guards are observing women in Baxter and the contractor can give no assurance that that will be avoided. We have a situation where the nature of Red 1, the specific detention monitoring system inside, has had to be taken out of operation because of public criticism. We have the reality that, many months before it became a national issue, people at Baxter gained the impression that Cornelia Rau might be an Australian. It did not go up the food chain. No-one was advised. She languished there.

Justice Finn has commented that âit is imperative that the Commonwealth conduct regular and systematic performance auditsâ of the contractors. That has not been the case. There is no effective review of these operations. The government has been dragged to provide better psychiatric assistance, conceding that it has been inadequate. We have the reality that Cornelia Rauâs condition was essentially only driven forward by the pleas of the detainees in the centre. They could see a psychiatric state; they could see the need for assistance. To say that all is well, that we do not need any oversight and that it is bureaucracy is an insult to that which has been exposed over recent months. It is neglect of the interests of the people in detention. We know that Justice Finn in that very important decision of the two Iranian detainees who had not been given psychiatric assistance for 12 and 17 months respectively said that there had been culpable neglect by the government, the department and the contractors.

To say that we do not need any oversight, that we do not need any transparency, that we do not need more accountability and that we do not need the reduced possibility of wrongful detention is preposterous. But that is the kind of argument that was put forward by the minister for multicultural affairsâthat all is well, that we do not need any oversight, that these things will sort themselves out, that there are no problems. Quite clearly there are. Kjell Liljegren, a former detention guard who had been there for seven years, commented:

quote.para: It was more obvious that they wanted to run the centres more like prisons than actual detention centres which are meant for administrative purposes only. Most of the time it was based on control and restraint.

speech.para: We have a federal immigration officer commenting in the Herald of 13 March 2002:

quote.para: The detention centres are now a cross between a jail and a lunatic asylum.

speech.para: So to say that there is no need for oversight is spurious. Over many months inadequacies have been found. The less the service and the cheaper you can provide it determines how it operates. There is obviously great criticism of the subcontractors in the medical and psychiatric areas. People, it seems, who do not have proper professional credentials have been working there. The actual service up until very recentlyâlong after the Prime Minister made these comments about how great the system wasâtook six to eight to nine weeks. The government has relented. It has surrendered because of public criticism by the opposition to provide a more adequate, swifter and more available service. We have a contractor, GSL, that seemingly has a culture of prison. (Time expired)

speech.para: In speaking to our amendment proposing an inspector-general of immigration detention centres, I want to make a number of comments on the negotiated settlement between the Prime Minister and the member for Kooyong in relation to mandatory detention. Whilst the compromise is welcome and certainly an improvement on the inhumane conditions so many refugees have been subjected to, we on this side of the House do not believe that the changes go far enough to address the fundamental wrong of incarcerating people in the desert without charge. Laborâs position goes so much further than what the Prime Minister was prepared to give in to. I have been promoting Laborâs policy on asylum seekers since its endorsement at the 2003 ALP National Conference in Sydney. It has an appropriate system that still retains administrative detention but removes its punitive nature.

Under the Prime Ministerâs amendments to the act, the minister will be able to specify alternative detention arrangements but will not be compelled to do so. Hopefully, the inspector-general amendment will be accepted to ensure that, in all cases where there is a threat to a detaineeâs mental or physical wellbeing, the detainee will be released into appropriate alternative accommodation. The inspector-general will ensure that 90 per cent of all claims for asylum will be processed within 90 days. The governmentâs amendments are intended to have all primary visa decisions made by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs within three months and the reviews made by the Refugee Review Tribunal in a further three months. The Howard plan does not take into account many crucial measures which have been addressed by Laborâs position. They have been out there, Minister, for the past two years. The inspector-general would allow health services in detention centres to be provided by independent medical professionals and would ensure that these aspects would be carried out. These professionals would be free to speak out on issues, the need for which has been emphasised by the recent tragic cases of Cornelia Rau and Vivian Solon.

The Prime Ministerâs measures do not create an independent inspector-general of detention centres nor, as we will hear, do they allow media access to detention centres or resolve the problems associated with lengthy waiting times for court appeals. The inspector-general would oversee the availability of appropriate community housing facilities onshore and offshore. The government proposals do not indicate where community housing will be coming from. Crucially, the Prime Ministerâs compromise position on immigration detention does not resolve flaws which lead to people remaining in the system for unacceptable periods.

Labor believes in an orderly immigration system based on the rule of law, a system of integrity in which the Australian people will have confidence and trust. We must treat individuals fairly and with dignity and civility. To treat individuals fairly requires that they are dealt with in a speedy and efficient manner, where decisions and procedures are subject to appropriate review. It is in our national interest to conduct ourselves as a good international citizen, to do our fair share for those who are subject to persecution and need protection. Labor in government will ensure that our borders are secure and that the processing and detention of asylum seekers is fair.

I am sure that all members in this place have been inundated with letters, emails and phone calls from constituents calling for changes to the inhumane system of mandatory detention. This grassroots campaign has at least brought about some softening of the arrangements. I commend all Australians who have taken the time to get in touch with their politicians urging change. If we had more grassroots activism, Australia would improve for the better. I specifically wish to record my appreciation of local Lake Macquarie and Hunter based organisations such as Amnesty International Newcastle branch and the Newcastle Action for Refugee Rights group and the campaign they have waged over many years to bring about decent changes. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThis proposal, opposition amendment (6), inserts another review process. The opposition claim that their proposed amendments streamline and make the legislation fair and compassionate. So what do they do? The first amendment they move puts another review process in train, creating a new office of inspector-general, who will be sent around the traps to look at the circumstances of detainees. The lawyers will not stay at homeâthere will be legal process involved. This amendment merely creates another review for the inspector-general who will take legal advice from representatives of the department and of the detainee. It sets out to do exactly the opposite of what the Australian Labor Party claim they are supposed to do.

speech.para: The secretary appoints the inspector-general whose functions are to receive and make determinations concerning submissions and complaintsâthere is a whole list of things the inspector-general can doâand to âpay particular attention to the needs of childrenâ. What does that mean? It will mean that psychologists, educators and medical people get in on the event and the whole process becomes another grand overview, a second hearing of all the elements already previously gone through. This is a ridiculous proposal. Instead of streamlining the process, the Australian Labor Party are proposing another complication.

The secretary is also to âensure that the Inspector-General is given unrestricted accessâ to all centres and to all people. He will cart the media along as well. So the person with the best publicist will get the most attention. What a crazy way of making decisions. The first of the proposed opposition amendments says that the media has to have access to everything. It will be trial by media. You can see it now: the inspector-general will go into a detention centre, there will be cameras everywhere, he will listen to the claims of the detainee, the lawyer, the child psychologistâall and sundry. The media then can publicise exactly what is being presented to the inspector-general. This is a strange and very unusual process.

We ought to go back to the ideas of the member for Reid, Laurie Ferguson, rather than these strange ideas. In 2002 or in 2004, his ideas were dumped and the Labor Party moved into a new era of enlightenment and fairness! This is crazy stuffâthat an inspector-general can wander around detention centres, is given open access to everything, can take complaints and submissions from all and sundry, including lawyers, and have the media there to help him along. It is no wonder the government has no intention of voting for this issue. There is no intention on our side for this proposal to get up.

If you want to check on conditions within detention centres, an elite group of people, including Gerry Hand, have been travelling to detention centres and reporting to the minister on conditions in those centres. I take it the inspector-general is not going to do that. His or her role will be to take specific submissions from people in the centres.

I do not know where the Australian Labor Partyâs brains are on some of these issues. Its former policies were bad enough, but this is moving into the arena of the strange and the terrible. It will be trial by media, by publicity. The person with the best publicist will get the most attention. Because the minister will grant access to the media, he will be influenced by public opinion rather than by the facts of the case.

I cannot believe that you would want to bypass the proposition of the government that the Ombudsman should reassess things and report to parliament. What could be better than having the OmbudsmanâI do not purport that we should start the case all over againâlook at the facts and report to parliament. That way, everything is open and transparent and everybody knows the circumstances. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWhat a pathetic performance! I wonder if the member for Mitchell recognises that there is an inspector-general of prisons in his own state of New South Wales. Does he think that is appropriate or inappropriate?
âWe have an Ombudsman.

âI guarantee there is an Ombudsman in New South Wales as well. These people are not prepared to provide external oversight of what is going on in these institutions. That committee will be asked to report to the government backbenchers on a fortnightly basis. That is how much confidence they have in this process. We need an inspector-general who will be able to receive and resolve individual complaints from detainees, be empowered to enter detention centres and immigration processing facilitiesâincluding on Christmas Island, which is part of my constituencyâmeet with detainees as necessary, question detention centre staff, view relevant records, receive complaints and inquire into and resolve such matters, pay particular attention to ensuring the needs of these children in community care are being met and be able to inquire into more systemic problems on his or her own motion.

speech.para: I ask members opposite to go to the questions without notice from Senator Kirk to Senator Vanstone on the issue of Cornelia Rau. If you want an example of why we need an inspector-general, read Hansardâbecause it makes it very clear that the role of the staff in the detention centre was the only reason that Cornelia Rauâs case was brought to the attention of the government. I have spoken to Dr Frukacz, the psychiatrist involved in that particular case, and it is very clear that the bell was rung but nobody took any notice. Had there been an inspector-general, I am sure that would not have been the case.

If we are to have an immigration detention policy, we have to make sure our procedures for detaining people are entirely above board. This is particularly important when government policy appears to beâand isâto hire private contractors to manage and staff the detention centres. I believe it is very important that the inspector-general be empowered to assess the recruitment, training and professional development standards for staff as well as the conditions for detainees. We need to be sure of the staffing arrangements in these detention centres. These problems arising from privatisation will be further exacerbated if the border protection legislation goes through, because it will add more contractorsâthis time to AMFAâto the list of persons authorised to detain. Detention centres have been described by an individual as a cross between an asylum and jail. I do not believe that anyone on the government benches honestly and sincerely believes they should not be supporting this amendmentâno-oneâbecause it is logical, fair, reasonable and says we have to have standards. In his earlier intervention the minister said, âWe were only given these amendments yesterday.â

talk.start.para: âFour minutes ago!

âFour minutes ago. Minister, you say that you are diligent, but I am not sure that you are. I believe you could be if you applied yourself, but I do not think you have. Had you known what the Labor Party policy was, you would have known that we would put this amendment, because it is part of our policy which was framed almost 2Â½ years ago. You should have known and you should have the arguments before you. (Time expired)
âMr Deputy Speakerâ
âCostello wants to know what you were doing at the Sharks game.

âThe member for Reidâs interjection would be more interesting if I could hear itâwhether it is because of the distance or because of my own capacities, I do not know. Amendment (6) seeks to impose an inspector-general of detentionâI will come back to thatâand to change the reporting times in the new part 8(c) of the bill such that reporting to the Ombudsman would be done after 90 days instead of two years and ongoing reports would be given every month instead of every six months. speech.para: I believe that everyone of goodwill agrees that the critical need is for the immigration department to administer its refugee policy with efficiency, humanity and compassion. The fundamental requirement is that the administration of the policyâthe execution, if you likeâbe done in a way that meets our expectations of compassion and efficiency. Imposing more and more third party oversight can often be very counterproductive. We already have in this bill a provision for an established office bearer with a role in oversight and review of administrative actionsâthe Commonwealth Ombudsmanâto be reported to regularly about persons in detention. This obviously is a considerable increase in accountability to the public and to the parliament. The question has to be asked: what is really added by appointing an inspector-general? talk.start.para: âHREOC.

âthrough the various NGOs and agencies, such as HREOC, as the minister interjects. There is already a considerable amount of attention paid to conditions in detention centres and, arguably, we might not be having this debate today if there were not. The answer of the Labor Party, which is simply to appoint yet another agency, is creating yet another bureaucracy to do the same piece of work being done by so many others.

speech.para: The change to the role of the Ombudsman is to bring the reporting periods down to very short time frames. It is difficult to say whether, in the light of experience, reporting after two years, with an update after six months, as is comprehended in this bill, will be timely enough. Experience will tell. The government has demonstrated that it combines both a big heart and a hard head in dealing with immigration, and that was demonstrated by the Prime Ministerâs presentation of these reforms last week. speech.para: I stated last night that, whilst I think this immigration debate is long overdue, it is pleasing that the House has the opportunity to debate the national disgrace which is our immigration system. We have heard many contributions over the course of the debate. People have addressed serious concerns regarding a number of issues in our system, such as the plight of those on temporary protection visas, independent medical access to our detention centres and, of course, the unacceptably long time that we are detaining people who are awaiting processing.

But I would like us to now focus on one single issue which I believe stands above all othersâthat is, children do not belong in detention centres. It is time that we address that in this parliament and ensure that it no longer continues. As I said in the chamber last night, Labor wants children out of detention. These amendments moved by Labor will do just that. There was much expectation when the member for Kooyong proposed his two initial bills as they had provisions for removing children from detention and placing them in community homes. The Prime Ministerâs watered down compromise does not go this far. It does not enshrine in legislation what I and many Australians believe, which is that all children should be removed from behind the razor wire. The Prime Ministerâs bill leaves it at the discretion of the minister. This is not good enough.

I think the Australian people have an expectation that we are finally going to act on this important issue and ensure that, from this day forward, no child will grow up in a detention centre in this land. That is what these amendments seek to do. Children in detention is probably the most emotive issue associated with the detention of asylum seekers. Many people find it unconscionable to keep children behind the razor wire. At this point I will talk about one of the things the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs brought up. He said that members on this side of the House keep using emotive language such as âchildren behind the razor wireâ, and he suggested that we had perhaps been told that we had to use this language. Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I point out to the minister that the reason we use emotive language on this issue is that on this side of the House we have emotions, which means that when we are talking about children growing up behind bars we get worked up about it and we use emotive language. My question is: why is that not the case on the other side of the House?

Last night I quoted a GP from my electorate who summed up the social, physical and psychological impact of detention on children. The doctor wrote and explained simply that âthe effects of long-term detention are disastrous in every way, especially upon childrenâ. We need to debate here this morning whether we really want to be responsible for these effects on children growing up on Australian soil. The governmentâs bill leaves to the discretion of the minister whether children are removed from detention. It provides for a non-compellable power for the minister to specify alternative detention arrangements. This is not good enough. It is not acceptable to me, to the GP who wrote to me or to the many other people who have contacted me, and indeed have contacted us around the country, about this issue. The specifics of Laborâs plan would see children removed from behind the wire and placed in the care of foster families after a health check. Unlike the Prime Ministerâs bill, under Labor additional ministerial powers are not required for this to take effect.

I have mentioned that I recently visited Baxter. I point out that it was May when I made the trip to Port Augusta, yet it was still 35 degrees there. I found my trip to that detention facility a truly awful experience. While I have no doubt that the staff there are working hard and trying to do their jobs, it is an awful place and is certainly absolutely no place for children to be growing up. It would perhaps be helpful at this stage to point out that these amendments do not amount to policy on the run. The Labor Party since its national conference has consistently argued in support of removing children from detention. This was announced on Australia Day 2002. To this end, Labor moved amendments to the Migration Act in 2002 and 2003 to remove children from detention. It is strange, then, that some members opposite continue to run the line that Labor has been silent on the issue. Labor has not been silent on this issue and Labor will not be silent until we get children out of detention. We have had good policy, we have been very vocal about it and we will continue to be.

Whilst I am glad to be finally having a chance to debate this issue in parliament, I am saddened that the potential to remove children from detention, as envisioned by the member for Kooyong in his initial bills, has not been realised by the government. It has fallen, once again, to the Labor Party to right the wrongs of the detention system in Australia. I urge all members of this House to support these amendments, to do something that we can all be really proud of and get children out of detention centres. (Time expired)

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: âThe first amendment the opposition moved at the consideration in detail stage of the bill proposed another bureaucracy. It dealt with the introduction of an inspector-general of detention, who would oversee the conditions of detention. And now we have a judicial assessor. As my friends and colleagues have already made perfectly clear with regard to the role of the inspector-general of detention in overseeing detention, how many more overseeing individuals, bodies and organisations do you need? Have a look at the long list. We have the Ombudsman, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, parliamentary committees, advocates who visit on a regular basis, non-government organisations, as the member for Wentworth mentioned, and legal advice. For every detainee who requests it, DIMIA is obliged under the Migration Act to provide legal advice.

âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. We had to do this earlier, but I refer the minister to the amendments that we are considering. The member for Adelaide clearly identified them as amendments (3) to (5).
(Hon. IR Causley)âI call the minister.

âI am laying the groundwork by reaffirming for the information of the chamber the unworkable and unnecessary bureaucracy that the opposition sought to establish with their earlier amendment. Now they are doing the same with their later amendments by creating a judicial assessor, which leaves more questions unanswered thanâ

speech.para: Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! I am sure the public will judge the ministerâs reply.

âThe judicial assessor will have authority to decide which children remain in detentionâyet another bureaucracy. What are the questions that immediately leap out of the recently drafted amendments? Is the assessorâs role conducted in a personal, administrative or judicial capacity? Which is it? After all, it was the member for Lingiari who boldly made an assertion earlier in impressive Latin. I was very taken aback by the scholarly skills of the member for Lingiari; I could not hope to repeat it. It is a little unusual for a Northern Territory boy to be quoting Latin in the parliament.

speech.para: Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âAll right, I did learn Latin in school; I just do not recall itâI did not take it all that seriously, I can say. Translated, what the member for Lingiari said was: âWho guards the guardians?â We have an answer to that: we guard the guardians as a parliament and as an executive, and there are numerous bodies involved in decisions about the release of people from detention, especially children. The member for Lingiari said the government should have answers to all of the issues raised in the amendments because they have been Labor Party policy for a long time. All right, if they have been slaving away on their policy they can answer these questions regarding the judicial assessor. What capacity is the judicial assessor acting in, because there are significant incentives to encourage further litigation? We are going to go back to the old days of lawyers making a meal out of the asylum seekers and establishing an industry which will delay final decisions as to their standing and status, invariably not to their advantage.

speech.para: Another question: under the Labor Partyâs amendment, what does âsignificant riskâ mean and what factors are relevant for assessing this? What is the answer to that? It has been Labor Party policy for years; can we have some answers? Why arenât these answers available? Because they are making policy on the run. The Labor Party are trying to find differences with the governmentâs exemplary legislation. How is the judicial assessor to assess whether a person ârepresents a danger to the safety and welfare of the Australian communityâ? What is the answer? What is the answer to the question of whether or not the person would be available if required? We have the Ombudsmanâs powers and we are increasing the resources. It is transparent; it is accountable. We have the interdepartmental committee headed by the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. We are serious about a more flexible and softer detention policy. The Labor Party are only serious about political advantage.

talk.start.para: âI second the amendments moved by the member for Adelaide and I am very proud to do so. The Labor Party have previously put forward two bills in this House, in 2002 and 2003, which would have seen all kids out of detention. Today we have been flexible. In this amendment we have actually used the words of the member for Kooyongâs proposal because we believe that this is a critical issue. I give credit to the member for Kooyong, the member for Pearce and others, who have put a human face on these issues and who acknowledge that we are dealing with real human beings. Today I remind the House of a very stark reality of the impact of the governmentâs attitude towards detention and its immigration regime.

speech.para: Last week I spoke about an incident where two young children were forcibly removed from their classroom at Stanmore Public School. Ji Hee Han Hwang, known as Janey, was born in Australia in 1998 and was enrolled in kindergarten in 2004. In Yong Han Hwang, known as Ian, was born in 1993, was enrolled in kindergarten in 1998 and was in year 6 at Stanmore Public School. On 8 March 2005, DIMIA officials went to their classroom, banged on the window and dragged them out of that classroom to lock them up in Villawood detention centre. The impact on those kids and on every kid in that classroom is a disgrace and should not be allowed to happen in Australia. That is the reality of the way that DIMIA is run in this country in 2005. It occurred without the presence of a legal guardian and without prior notice to the department of education. These Gestapo tactics might be defended by some opposite, but they are not the Australian way. It is completely unacceptable that two young children, one of whom was born in Australia, could be forcibly removed from their classroom. It is wrong that these children were removed in this manner and it is wrong that these children remain behind barbed wire.

The immigration department is clearly out of control. It has lost all sense of decency. It is fundamental that we treat children with kindness. All kids should be out of detention, out from behind barbed wire. Australia is the only country in the world where asylum seekersâadults and childrenâare detained for the duration of their processing. Currently 53 children are in detention centres, and on average they have been detained for over 12 months. Only half of these children have access to external schooling.

In late May 2005, three-year-old Naomi Leong was released after spending her entire life in Villawood detention centre. Her only exposure to playing with, and learning from, other children was when she was allowed to attend a child learning centre for three hours. While inside Villawood, Naomi would bang her head against the wall. Naomi was so isolated and alone and so confined that her only method of coping was to copy her motherâs emotional state. The psychiatrist who assessed Naomi and her mother has acknowledged that the family have been traumatised by their time in detention and that they are likely to be haunted by their experiences for the rest of their lives. It is blatantly clear that the detention of children is detrimental to their mental health, let alone that of their parents. A study by the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists in May 2003 of children in remote detention centres found a 10-fold increase in the number of psychological disorders in children over a two-year period.

We ask those opposite to vote for this amendment because it is about family values. This is a test of how fair dinkum they are about family values. Labor has picked up the member for Kooyongâs wording in order to maximise the possibility of that occurring. These kinds of interactions are very real. That two children at Stanmore Public School were taken from their classroom and locked up is an indication of how out of control it is. This is unacceptable in Australia in 2005. I commend the amendments to the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIf you listened to the ALP on the Migration Amendment (Detention Arrangements) Bill 2005, you would think that they had a mortgage on compassion. Let me tell members of the ALP that compassion does not start and end on that side of the House. There are people on this side of the House who have been equally concerned about children being held in detention for a long time. In fact, one of the motivating factors for the introduction of these amendments by the Prime Minister was even his concern about children in detention. So do not put yourselves on some moral pedestal about your concerns.

speech.para: If you had those concerns, why didnât you act on them in government? The member for Lingiari stands up and says, âWhen in government the ALP will do such and such.â When in government you had that chance. You had that chance to take children out of detention. What did you do? In 1994, 318 children were in detention centres. How many were born in detention? Member for Reid, 24 were born in detention after the arrival of their parents to Australia, bringing the total to 342. How many children do we have in detention today? We have 53. We have seen over a period of timeânot just since this debate has startedâthe government introducing measures to move children and their families into residential housing situations. And full credit to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs for doing that. We have now gone one step further by saying that the minister now has a non-compellable authority to move these kids into housing facilities even faster.

Laborâs amendment puts restrictions on the process by saying, âItâs got to go to a judicial assessor; itâs got to be done within 30 days.â What about just allowing the immigration minister to make the decision? After all, she has the greatest accountability. She has more accountability than any other minister on these issues. She is the most scrutinised minister in this government. She is scrutinised by HREOC. She is scrutinised by the United Nations Human Rights Commission. She is scrutinised by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. She is scrutinised by every member of parliament in this place. She is also scrutinised by the media. She will make the decision based on the needs of that family at the time. No-one has greater power than the minister in this area and, knowing her and other ministers, I believe that power will be executed with absolute consideration for the needs of the families and the children who need to be moved out of detention centres.

The minister needs greater flexibility. She needs to consider all the issues in regard to a family. Not every family that she will consider will have the same situations. They will have their own unique considerations. Of course, often with these applications, there are one or two members of a family who perhaps need greater scrutiny. So an entire family, including the children, will need to be considered more so than, perhaps, another family. We need to take into consideration the type of housing we are going to move a family into and the location. Will an NGO take them on, or will they go into a state or a federal funded facility? We need to take into consideration the age of the children, their medical conditions and the kinds of facilities and services they require. The Labor amendment simply hobbles the minister; it does not give her the flexibility that she needs.

The member for Grayndler went on with his usual rhetoric and fear campaigns, describing Gestapo-like tactics of officials taking kids out of school. What the member for Grayndler has deceitfully done is confuse visa compliance issues with those of illegal immigrants. Let us not confuse that! They are two separate issues. Yet, he has deliberately done that to give the impression to every person who has kids in school that these Gestapo immigration officials are knocking on windows and dragging kids out their classrooms. The parents are of non-compliance cases. If they have already been in this country for a number of years and they have gone through a number of bridging visas and extensions along the way, then perhaps the time has come when they need to be held accountable to the department and to the Australian people.

talk.start.para: Mr Tanner interjectingâ
âOf course we do not condone those kinds of tactics, but do not confuse the role of the immigration department and what they do with illegal immigrants versus non-complianceâ(Time expired)

âI proudly rise to support Laborâs amendment that will see children being taken out of detention centres. I just heard the previous speaker, the member for Deakin, describe what is in any school a critical incident: the removal of children by strangers. It is something that we are trained in schools to handle, yet this government practises it every day.

speech.para: In May 2004 a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report was tabled in this parliament dealing with repeated breaches of human rights suffered by children in Australian detention centres. That two-year inquiry found that the mandatory detention system breached the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. Our detention system, it said, had âfailed to make the best interests of the child a primary consideration in detaining them and it failed to treat them with humanity and respectââthe right of all innocents made vulnerable by their youth. It condemned the governmentâs failure to implement repeated recommendations by mental health professionals to remove children with their parents from detention, describing it as âcruel, inhumane and degrading treatmentââunfortunately, something Australians have been encouraged to look away from with callous disregard.

This damning HREOC report has been callously disregarded by the Howard government until now. Fortunately, a handful of Liberals with compassion and courage have stood up to the determined bullying of the Prime Minister and have forced this shameful abuse of human rights back into this parliament and into the public eye. The bill that results is a compromise, but it is the best that could be achieved within government ranks. It will fall short, unfortunately, in dealing with the crisis that exists in our migration and detention systems. Regrettably, an incompetent minister in a complacent and arrogant government, supported by complicit senior bureaucrats in DIMIA, will remain.

These amendments will not, however, remove the responsibility or the culpability of this government, but they will remove children from behind razor wire. Labor has been pressing for these amendments and for this action since 2002. But today my Labor colleagues and I are pleased to finally have the opportunity to rid our immigration system of some of the most despicable aspects of government policy that have blemished the human landscape in this great nation. I give full support to the effect of the bill and the particular Liberals involved in bringing this about.

More than 2,000 children have suffered in immigration detention over the past few years. We hear today that there are 53 childrenâI thought it was 68âwho are still at risk of abuse and are having their rights demeaned right now. Hopefully, though, this legislation will mean DIMIAâs calculated mistakes will never happen again. It has been a long battle and I acknowledge the contribution made by many of my Labor colleagues, by refugee advocates, civil libertarians and decent Australian citizens. I make particular mention of the New South Wales Teachers Federation, who have quietly assisted childrenâs education and their removal from detention centres for that education.

But too many have been absent from this debate. It has taken extraordinary pressure, in one case from the Malaysian media, before the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs agreed to grant Naomi Leong a bridging visa. Naomi, as we have heard, was born in detention and she is therefore considered statelessâa pretty damning and sad label for a young child. Until recently, Naomi had never left the confines of a detention centre. Her plight became public last month after a psychiatrist, Dr Michael Dudley, revealed that Naomi had been banging her head against a wall and was mute and unresponsive. Having spent most of my lifetime contributing to the development of children, I find this horrifying.

talk.start.para: âItâs unsubstantiated.

âIf this is true, it is horrifying. The first three years of a childâs life are formative and will shape forever their attitudes and relationships. Sadly, Naomiâs experiences, if substantiated, will have a profound and negative effect on her development.

speech.para: Michael Andrew Tran was born prematurely on 23 May 2005 under guard at Perthâs King Edward Memorial Hospital. Michaelâs parents were among 53 asylum seekers who came within sight of Australian shores in July 2003 and have lived in detention on Christmas Island since. Michaelâs parents endured seven days of heartache while they waited to see if a compassionate DIMIA would allow them to keep their one-week-old baby, Michael. Thanks to intervention and media attention, this family was not forced to return to Christmas Island, but they continue to live under guard in a Perth suburb with the fatherâs 74-year-old mother, who was at the centre of controversy earlier this year when she was kept in the Perth airport detention centre while seriously ill. What must they think of Australians?

When mothers are forced to abandon their children, when kids are locked up in detention from birth, when mentally ill Australians are incarcerated or deported because they are unable to explain or defend themselves, it is clear that Minister Vanstone and her department of immigration are in unacceptable crisis. Naturally, the department resists a judicial assessor. It resists any scrutiny of its performance and any onus of proof being placed on it. We know that some 200 cases of potential wrongful detention have been referred to the Palmer inquiry. Decent Australians demand a more compassionate approach and this amendment will deliver that. When people of the world arrive at our doorstep seeking respite from trauma and injustice, seeking shelter and safe haven, we have choices and we certainlyâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThere are several ways in which the parliament can deal with this problem of children in detention. Let me say that I and, I believe, all of my colleagues share the communityâs concern about children being in detention centres. It is highly undesirable. Extended detention is clearly calculated to inflict psychological damage on children. It is a most unsatisfactory state of affairs. The recognition of that unsatisfactory state of affairs can be found in the legislation proposed by the government. What does it say? Children should not be detained in detention centres other than as a last resortâI emphasise: a last resort.

speech.para: So there are two approaches that we can take. The approach the government are taking is for parliament to state a very clear principleâchildren should not be in detention. That is what we believe; that is what we want to achieve. Having stated that principle, we then give the minister the ability to implement that principle by arranging for children and their families to live in the community under regimes of supervision or reporting that in some cases may be very light indeed.

Then the third part of that approach is to make the exercise of that discretion accountable so that parliament knows and the community knows whether the minister is exercising her discretion in a manner that is consistent with the principle laid out by the parliament, a principle which we all share.

The oppositionâs approach is a different one. It seeks, just as it did in the previous set of amendments that we discussed, to impose another legalistic layerâin this case, a judicial assessorâto impose yet another level of legal review in a system that is crippled and rendered inefficient, unjust and lacking in humanity by excessive legalisms, excessive legal processes. In some respects, as I said earlier today, the tortuous path of litigation associated with immigration matters is of Dickensian proportions. The government is endeavouring to cut that back with the migration reform bill, but more will need to be done. I would have hoped that the opposition would have recognised the problems associated with excessive litigation, excessive legalism, and would have recognised that an abundance of lawyers is no answer to a shortage of compassion. The answer to a shortage of compassion is more compassion, and that is what the governmentâs bill seeks to enable the minister to effect.

In short, the opposition is simply providing here just another excuse for something to say. The judicial assessor will make no substantive improvement to the situation. The law, as proposed, gives states a very clear principle. It gives the minister great discretionâthat discretion of the ministerâs is made accountableâand if she fails to exercise that discretion in a manner consistent with the principle then she certainly will be brought to account. A judicial assessor is simply yet another legal framework, another opportunity for the legal profession, of which I have to confess I am a member or a former member, but it is not a move that is calculated to make our system more efficient, it will make it less efficient, and it will certainly not make it more compassionate. There is no substitute for efficient and compassionate administration. (Time expired)

âI move opposition amendment (1):

amendment.para: (1)Â Â Â Schedule 1, after item 9, page 5 (after line 19) insert:
