debateinfo.title: ENVIRONMENT AND HERITAGE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The purpose of the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 is to make amendments to the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 and to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act 2001.

Australiaâs Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 has made a significant contribution to the global effort to phase out ozone depleting substances, and is now also contributing to minimising Australiaâs avoidable emissions of synthetic greenhouse gases. Through cooperation between government and industry, the legislation has reduced Australiaâs consumption of ozone depleting substances by 80 per cent since 1989, resulting in estimated savings to the Australian economy of some $6.4 billion by the year 2060.

This bill proposes to amend the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 to rectify a small number of operational anomalies and unintended consequences of drafting. The proposed amendments will ensure the consistent and effective operation of Australiaâs legislation for the management of ozone depleting substances and their synthetic greenhouse gas alternatives. These substances have very significant impacts on the global climate system and the ozone layer, and appropriate restrictions are essential to ensure that these substances are managed consistently and used sustainably within Australia.

Specifically, this bill will make two changes to the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989. Firstly, it will confirm that importers or exporters of recycled or used methyl bromide or hydrochlorofluorocarbons are only required to hold a used substances licence. This approach is consistent with that taken for other ozone depleting substancesâsuch as chlorofluorocarbons and halonsâcurrently controlled under the act.

Secondly, the bill will ensure that reporting obligations for synthetic greenhouse gases manufactured in Australia are the same as those for synthetic greenhouse gases imported into, or exported, from Australia.

The proposed amendments to the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 contained in this bill demonstrate the governmentâs determination to further advance its practical and effective approach to managing ozone depletion and climate change.

In relation to the amendments to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act 2001, the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust is responsible for preparing and implementing a plan for the future uses of former defence and other Commonwealth lands on or near the foreshores of Sydney Harbour. These are historic lands. They tell the story of European settlement in Sydney and trace the patterns of defence, industry and population growth in the fledgling colony of New South Wales.

The lands are Macquarie Lightstation on South Head; the former Artillery School at North Head; Woolwich Dock and Parklands; Cockatoo Island; Snapper Island; Defence lands at Middle Head-Georges Heights-Chowder Bay; and the former marine biological station at Watsons Bay.

The Sydney Harbour Federation Trustâs comprehensive plan for these sites was approved by the Minister for the Environment and Heritageâs predecessor, the Hon. Dr David Kemp, in September 2003. The plan was some years in preparation and involved wide community consultation. It is fair to say that consultation by the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust in the preparation of the plan was a hallmark of the planning process. A community advisory committee, established under the Sydney Harbour Federation Trustâs legislation, was instrumental in reflecting community interest in the sites and providing advice and recommendations on site outcomes. I particularly commend the work of the member for Warringah and the member for North Sydney in assisting with the community consultation.
The Sydney Harbour Federation Trust has begun the challenging task of implementing the comprehensive plan.

Former Defence lands at Middle Head-Georges Heights-Chowder Bay are being transformed into a headland park. The park will link all the elements of these disparate defence bases and bring them into accord with the great natural and cultural assets of the Middle Head plateau. A network of walking tracks, lookouts, revegetation and interpretive signage will underpin compatible uses of buildings and facilities and highlight the Indigenous and military history of this beautiful headland.

The Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act 2001 provides for the sale, subject to environmental and heritage considerations, of 19 residential lots listed in schedule 2 to the act. The residential lots are at Markham Close, Mosman. Other trust lands are listed in schedule 1 to the act and are to remain in public ownership.
To date 12 residential lots at Markham Close have been sold by auction.

The effect of the proposed amendments contained within this bill will be to enable the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust to more effectively bring to the fore the natural ridgeline of Middle Head peninsula and add to the character of the headland park. This entails transferring three residential lots in Markham Close from schedule 2 to schedule 1, thus allowing them to be incorporated into the park and in exchange transferring the land on which a disused scout hall is located, currently included in schedule 1, to schedule 2 permitting its eventual sale.

This land swap, which has strong community endorsement, is consistent with the trustâs comprehensive plan and the fundamental objective of making its lands accessible to the public. The scout hall land does not have any significant environmental and heritage value and the scouting association has relinquished its lease on the land. The scout hall land, comprising around two-tenths of a hectare of trust lands, will be sold to private funds to enhance trust sites.

The trustâs preparation of the management plan for Markham Close included the proposal to swap land in the interests of highlighting the ridgeline of Middle Head peninsula and contributing to the creation of a spectacular headland park. The proposed land swap was overwhelmingly supported by the community during the exhibition of the draft management plan.

The proposed amendments contained in this bill will enable the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust to fulfil the objectives of the comprehensive plan and to open Middle Head peninsula for the benefit of the community.
I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 2.00 pm, the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 97. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

âMy question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that the petrol bill of a typical family increases by $8 a week with every 20c a litre petrol price rise? Will the Prime Minister strengthen the Trade Practices Act and the powers of the ACCC to prevent and punish profiteering? Will the Prime Minister establish a full and independent inquiry into petrol pricing and profiteering? Or does the Prime Minister agree with the Treasurer that there is nothing the government can or will do?

âI would have thought that the Leader of the Opposition was aware that the reason petrol prices are so painfully high at the momentâand they are painfully high; the government understands thatâis that the world price of crude oil has risen. It is as simple as that.
âA record high.

âIt is a record high, as the Treasurer reminds me. Let me say that since 1979, when I think the former leader of the Labor Party and former Labor Prime Minister and my immediate predecessor embraced the policy of import parity pricing for crude oil, I have not heard the Labor Party repudiate that policy. All I can say is that the call by the Leader of the Opposition for another inquiry is the sort of empty populism about which Senator Robert Ray has complained. To Senator Robert Ray, the member for Lalor and all the other people who are running around telling the Leader of the Opposition to lift his game can I say that a decent policy alternative and not cheap populism is what is needed from the Leader of the Opposition.
âMy question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister inform the House of the outcomes of yesterdayâs meeting of the International Whaling Commission.

âI thank the honourable member for his question. The International Whaling Commission held its second day of meetings in Ulsan, Korea, yesterday. At that meeting Japan proposed an amendment to the convention that would have allowed the resumption of commercial whaling. I am pleased to inform the House, and of course it has been in the media in any case, that working closely with quite a number of like-minded countries we were successful in voting down this measure by 29 votes to 23. The fact that a majorityâa good majority in the circumstancesâwere opposed to the resumption of commercial whaling is something that we particularly welcome. This was a vote that built on our earlier success in blocking Japanâs attempts to alter the procedures and the agenda of the International Whaling Commission to suit pro-whaling nations.

answer.para: I make the point that this excellent result was the product of patient diplomacy, and I congratulate Senator Ian Campbell, the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, on the excellent job he has done. I think we are all very grateful to him for his hard and effective work and to the officials of his department and my department. This is an example of patient diplomacy that has spanned many years. This is not an issue that has cropped up in the last three months; this issue is ages old. We have had very effective but quiet cooperation with our partners.

There will be further votes in coming days, including on an Australian motion that the International Whaling Commission not consider Japanâs expanded scientific whaling program until a review of the original program has been completed. The outcome is hard to predict and, again, it will be very difficult to get a majority. It is possible that we could, but it is possible that we will not. But in the end we will do our best to try to achieve that outcome.

In conclusion, some members and commentators have argued that we should abandon this process, that it does not amount to much, and, instead, we should just go to the International Court of Justice. The government have always said that we do not rule in or rule out any options. We obviously keep our options open, but we would need to consider any measure like that very carefully. That is the sort of measure that needs to be thought through. Bringing legal action in the International Court of Justice is a process that could take a decade or more, so we would not get very quick results there. Also, the doctrine of abuse of rights, which is the basis on which we would take action in the International Court of Justice, has not succeeded so far and so that is a case that would have to be argued. A third consideration is that, even if we were successful after a decade or so in the International Court of Justice, it would be open to Japan to circumvent the impact of the courtâs decision by simply withdrawing from the International Whaling Commission. It is better that Japan remain in the International Whaling Commission, where its whaling activities can be supervised and regulated. We would not want to overreact by dealing with this issue in such a way that it might be to the benefit of a decent headline one day but in fact be entirely counterproductive the next. That is the sort of issue that not just the government but the parliament needs to think through very carefully.

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of the comments by the Parliamentary Secretary for Industry, Tourism and Resources, who, according to yesterdayâs Cairns Post, said that the slaughter of whales for food is âokayâ? Is the Prime Minister aware that the member for Leichhardt stated that he has an âissue with the government taking a position of total prohibition against countries killing whalesâ? Given that whale watching contributes some $300 million annually to Australian tourism, will the Prime Minister send a clear and unequivocal message by harpooning the member for Leichhardt from his position as parliamentary secretary for tourism?
âThat question is bordering on being ruled out of order, but, if the Prime Minister chooses to answer it, I invite him to do so.

âI would be happy to answer it. I am glad they have the heavyweights in action now! I simply say that our policy on this is very well known. What is more, it has been powerfully articulated by Senator Ian Campbell, who has done a wonderful job. I endorse without reservation everything that he has said on the subject.

âMy question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer outline to the House recent partial data on the state of the economy? What does this data indicate about Australiaâs economic outlook?

âI thank the honourable member for Paterson for his question. The Australian Bureau of Statistics today released information on sales of new motor vehicles for May. That showed that sales were down by 1.2 per cent on the previous month. One would not want to overstate this, because 2003 was a record year, 2004 was a record year and 2005 is in excess of 2004, but the fact that sales are increasing at a slower rate compared to 2004 does show that consumer demand may well be slowing a little, as I have indicated through other data.

answer.para: Also, the skilled vacancies index was released today, which showed that skilled vacancies fell by 0.5 per cent in the June quarter and are 3.2 per cent lower over the year. That is consistent with the budget forecast showing a moderating domestic demand and employment growth slowing to 1Â¾ per cent in 2005-06. That is slower than in previous years but it would be sufficient to maintain the unemployment rate at around 5 per cent, which is at a 29-year low.

The partial data released today, I believe, is consistent with other data such as we have had from the housing sector, which indicates a slowing in consumption in the domestic economy. We have had very large price rises in relation to exports, and a rebalancing of growth from domestic to external sources would certainly be welcome. This moderation of consumption may well be consistent with households rebuilding their balance sheets. Again, that would be a welcome development for the economy.

talk.start.para: âMy question is also directed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House on what date the government first became aware of the credit card security breach which has exposed 130,000 Australian cardholders to fraud?
âNo, I cannot advise what date the government became aware of that. I understand that Senator Ellison has been answering questions in relation to this in the Senate.
Mr Crean interjectingâ
âOrder!

âI am interrupted by the sound effects man down there! I can inform the House that data was stolen in America from CardSystems Solutions through computer hacking in the United States. I am informed that any person involved in using credit data stolen from CardSystems within Australia to access funds, credit or other financial benefits will be subject to offences under the Criminal Code. I am also informed that the code of practice between the Australian banks provides that, where somebody has suffered a loss because of fraud by a third party, the banks will make good and individuals will not be responsible for any loss. I am also told that the banking industry is forming an information security customer response task force, led by the Australian Bankers Association, which will be in place by 1 July.

answer.para: As far as I am aware, those banks that became aware of this credit card fraud in the United States took immediate steps to replace the cards. I am not aware that there has been any loss by any Australian user of those cards, because the banks have made that good. I believe that Australian law enforcement authorities are cooperating with their American counterparts.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I invite the Treasurer to get back to the House at a later hour with advice on exactly when the government became aware of the fraud.
âIt is the prerogative of the Treasurer if he wishes to add to his answer.

âMy question is also addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer inform the House of new tax schedules that are due to take effect in July 2005? Are there any impediments to these schedules taking effect?

âI thank the honourable member for Wakefield for his question. I can inform the House that the good news is that all Australian income tax payers will receive a tax cut in nine days time on 1 July. The legislation to enact those tax cuts, unfortunately, has been blocked in the Senate by the Australian Labor Party, but schedules, which take effect and can be relied upon, have not been disallowed by motion in either house. They have now been in this House for 11 days and in the Senate for six days. There is only one more day of sitting for anyone to move a disallowance motion. Provided that no-one moves a disallowance motion tomorrow, those schedules will go ahead and every Australian will receive a tax cut on 1 July 2005.

answer.para: Laborâs campaign to stop taxes being cut on 1 July 2005 has failed. The good news is that the public recognises that Laborâs campaign against income tax cuts was a misguided campaign. A large proportion of the Australian Labor Party also now recognise that the decision by their so-called brains trust to oppose the income tax cuts in the budget was misguidedâand the poor Leader of the Opposition is living with that. But, as I constantly say to the House, do not hold him solely responsible; he was advised by the member for Lilley, the member for Swan and Senator Conroyâthe three wise roosters.

This morning the member for Lilley was asked about the tax schedules. I will read the question and the answer, because I think the question is a bit of a corker. The journalist that approached the member for Lilley asked this questionâand I ask the House to listen to it: âWayne, are the roosters worried that Kim Beazley isnât coming through?â Answer: âNo, weâre not worried at all.â The good news is that the roosters are not worried. The line from rooster central is that there is no need to panic. Everything is going according to plan. There is a cunning strategy and all will shortly be revealed. Let the backbench of the Labor Party know that this particular strategy is under controlâunder rooster control. Situation normal at rooster command.

We on this side of the House believe that taxes should be cut because, if you can fund your services, if you can balance your budget and if you can reduce your debt, income taxes should be as low as possible for the Australian public. We have a plan to cut income tax rates at the lowest marginal rate and to increase thresholds at the top rate. After these schedules go through and after the legislation goes through in August, only three per cent of Australians will be bothered by the top marginal tax rate. That will put incentive back in the Australian taxation system and encourage growth and the continuation of a strong economy in this country.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Minister, is it a fact that, in negotiating a new agreement with Commonwealth car drivers, the government, discharging its employment responsibilities through Comcar, has proposed to cut 10 current conditions of employment with no pay increase? talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: âI am not aware of the negotiations with the drivers and Comcar. Now that the member for Perth has alerted me to them, I will make some inquiries. âMy question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr ANDERSON

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for his question. I am delighted to be able to report to the House that there is very clear evidence that the governmentâs aviation policies are working. There is strong growth in both the domestic aviation sector and the international aviation market. The combined domestic and regional aviation industry is operating now at record high levels, with almost 38 million passengers carried during the year ended December 2004. That was an increase of 14 per cent on the previous year. At the same time, passenger traffic on Australian international flights has also grown very strongly.

answer.para: Over the 12 months to December 2004, we saw a record high of 1.93 million passengers internationallyâan increase of nearly 10 per cent on December 2003. International activity reached a record high of 10,000 flights in December 2004, which was 16 per cent higher than December 2003 and 48.4 per cent higher than the low recorded in June 2003 when activity was negatively impacted by SARS.

The figures are very buoyant and very encouraging. They come off the back of the sharp downturn of two or three years ago, which no-one could have foreseen; but, nonetheless, they are remarkable figures. It is worth bearing in mindâand we must never forget itâthat the aviation industry operates in a very volatile climate. It is particularly susceptible to sudden shocks. Unfortunately, the international aviation industry is highly corrupted with many airlines enjoying not only natural geographic advantages over usâthat is all strength to their right armâbut also the protection of government ownership and support, which we no longer supply and should no longer supply in Australia.

I make the point that, while the airlines themselves have to do everything they can to be internationally competitiveâand we encourage them in thatâthere is also a vital need for international reform. There are too many airlines internationally because there are too many governments that prevent sensible rationalisationâa point well made by Rod Eddington recently. He is a well-known and respected Australian who headed up BA for a long time. Unfortunately, our carriers still face unreasonable restrictions on access to other countries. For example, in my view there are still unrealistic and unfair limitations on our access to the important UK market.

On the domestic front, it is worth making the point that there are those opposite who would still want to saddle the aviation industry in Australia with the cost of a white elephantânamely, a second airport in Sydney.

talk.start.para: âNonsense!

âNonsense. He wants a second airport but cannot justify it. I think it would, by demonstrable indicators, be a white elephant that would cost the aviation industry a lot of money. The fact is that total passenger numbers at Sydney airport have more than recovered, but the number of actual aircraft movements is significantly lower than it was back in 2000.

answer.para: Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âA lot of policy thought has gone into this by those opposite. You can tell that. They are all over the place. There is a certain sense of aircraft drift here, aviation drift. What has happened is that there has been a rapid move to having fewer aircraft carrying more peopleâmore rapid than anyone might reasonably have foreseen. Indeed, it is worth making the point that the Sydney airport master plan, approved last year, indicated that the airport would be able to cope with Sydneyâs air traffic needs for at least 20 years. I think that is a very good outcome indeed. Accordingly, I say to the House that the government has formed the view that a second Sydney airport will not be needed in the foreseeable future and, consequently, the government has no plans to impose a white elephant on the aviation industry in Australia.

âMy question is to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Does the Deputy Prime Minister share the belief of many National Party members that the education ministerâs voluntary student unionism bill will destroy student services at regional university campuses? Will the Deputy Prime Minister support the National Party members and senators by allowing them a free vote on this issue, or will the Deputy Prime Minister bow to the Liberal Partyâs plan to destroy student services at regional universities?
âThe Deputy Prime Minister will ignore the last part of that question.

âI thank the honourable member for what could be described as a fairly predictable question. The Nationals are completely opposed to compulsory unionism, particularly where those funds are used to support political campaigns and activities. I was at the University of Sydney in 1975 and I remember very well those front lawn activities. You do not forget them, Mr Speaker, so we are pursuing a policy that has long been supported by the party that I have the privilege of leading. If people want to voluntarily join a union, that is entirely their choice. But the changes contained in this legislation will finally offer university students across the country the choice that I think they want and they need. But I would make this point: there has been no greater friend to regional universities than the Howard-Anderson government.
âThe best friend they ever had.

âThe best friend regional education ever had, thatâs right. Indeed, my colleague the Minister for Education, Science and Training has prevailed over the provision of an extra $140 million in regional loadings for our regional universities.
Ms Macklin interjectingâ
âOrder! The member has asked her question.
âIn relation to services, if there are issues there that need to be discussed, the minister will take those forward in a very constructive and cooperative way.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Would the minister inform the House how the government is protecting and upholding the rights of employees? Are there any alternative views?

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Fisher for his question. I can indicate to him and the House that the governmentâs workplace reforms will protect minimum wages, they will protect collective bargaining and, indeed, they will protect the right of individuals to join unions. It is against this background that we see this continuing misleading campaign from the unions and the ACTU. Just recently they have been joined by some ALP MPsânamely, the member for Canberra; Senator Lundy, the Labor senator for the ACT; and the member for Fraserâwho have sent out a letter to residents in the ACT, including a copy of an ACTU brochure which contains a number of misleading and deceptive statements. It appears now that the ACTUâs campaign has been extended to using the postal allowance of ALP members to send out this misleading union campaign material.

answer.para: Like other misleading statements that have been made by the unions, this brochure contains further deceptive material. For example, this brochure asserts that minimum wages will be reduced. That is just wrong. It asserts that unions will not be able to access the workplace. Again, this is just wrong. It says the changes that the government proposes will reduce the capacity for collective bargaining. Again, that is simply wrong. So what we now have is ALP members being the mail-out boys and girls for the ACTU scare campaign. It would seem that, in return for the $47 million which the unions have donated to the Australian Labor Party, what they have bought for themselves is a junk mail delivery service, as this letter from the member for Canberra and the member for Fraser indicates.

We have had an increasingly desperate campaign from the ACTU as the days have gone on. Yesterday, the Secretary of the ACTU, Greg Combet, said that this government proposed to abolish federal awards. That is what he saidâwe would get rid of federal awards. That is absolutely wrong. It was made clear in the statement which the Prime Minister made to this parliament, it has been made clear in numerous other statements and it has been made clear in all the material which has been sent out that this government proposes to retain federal awards, yet we have this increasingly desperate campaign from the ACTU and Greg Combet, just saying things which are simply misleading and deceptiveâa desperate campaign from a desperate union movement.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Can the minister inform the House what, to use his words, the âclinically suitable alternativeâ drug for Alimta, an end-of-the-line treatment for lung cancer, would be? Isnât it true, Minister, that there is no drug on the PBS which hasâand once again I use the ministerâs wordsâa âchemically identical active ingredientâ to Alimta, which can only be prescribed when all other treatments have failed? Can the minister explain why people suffering from lung cancer should pay around $500 per treatment for the only drug that can help them?

âI say to the member for Lalor that, if it is the only drug that can help them, their treating doctor can apply to the HIC for an authorisation and they will get that drug at the standard copayment.
âMy question is also addressed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister inform the House how the government is providing country people with better access to medical services?

âI thank the member for Hinkler for his question. As he knows, as members of this House know, and as the Prime Minister and the state Labor premiers all recently agreed, Australia has a good health system. One of the reasons we have a good health system is that the Howard government does not just talk about Medicare; we invest the real money needed to make a good system better.

answer.para: I can say to the member for Hinkler that we have heeded his message about medical services in the bush. We have listened to people like the member for Hinkler and we are delivering. Under the policies of the Howard government, some 2,000 long-serving country doctors are receiving bonus payments of up to $25,000 a year to keep practising in country areas. We have put nurses into 1,100 rural practices and we have got 600 allied health professionals working with country GPs. There are now 11 rural clinical schools, including an excellent rural clinical school run by the University of Queensland in the town of Bundaberg in the electorate of Hinkler. There are 10 university departments of rural health. Twenty five per cent of medical students are required to do at least 50 per cent of their clinical training in country areas, because the more you train them in the bush the more likely they are to stay and practise in the country. Since 2001 there have been 346 additional medical student places at our universities, every single one of them bonded to country practice or practice in areas of work force shortage. Since 2000 there have been three new medical schools in the great state of Queensland, with 150-plus publicly funded places.

Can I make it very clear to the member for Hinkler and everyone else in this House: Medicare matters. Medicare matters to the Howard government, and since the election I have answered 37 questions about Medicare from coalition members. I just had my fifth from the member for Lalor. I ask this question: what has the member for Lalor done to upset the Leader of the Opposition so much? What has she done? Let us face it: she is not the only one who leaks out of shadow cabinet. That is what you get from a bunch of dills: leaks out of shadow cabinet. Or it may be that the Leader of the Opposition has got the message that the member for Lalor has not gotâthat the Howard government is the best friend that Medicare has ever had.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the Minister explain to the House and to people with epilepsy whatâonce again to use his wordsâthe âchemically identicalâ generic substitute is for Keppra, a medicine used to treat epilepsy? Minister, isnât it true that there is no clinically suitable alternative to Keppra? Isnât it also true that experts advise that epilepsy patients should not switch medications and that no doctor would substitute Keppra with a chemically different drug?

âI welcome that question from the member for Isaacs. I respect her interest in the welfare of patients, and I say to her what I said to the member for Lalor: if it is the only drug that is clinically appropriate and if the doctor approaches the Health Insurance Commission for an authorisation then that patient will get the relevant drug at the standard copayment.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As we approach the six-month anniversary of the tsunami tragedy, would the minister update the House on how the government has helped populations in affected countries through its emergency assistance?

âI thank the honourable member for Makin for her question. I appreciate all the work she does and her interest in the way that our support for Indonesia and other countries in response to the tsunami is unfolding. This Sunday marks exactly six months since the tsunami tragedy, and it does provide an opportunity to outline both the timeliness and the effectiveness of the governmentâs response. The government has now spent over $75 million on relief and rehabilitation assistance to help people rebuild their lives as a result of the tsunami. In Indonesia, over $40 million has been spent on projects in Aceh and North Sumatra. Over 1,000 tonnes of humanitarian aid to Aceh has been delivered, medical services are being assisted in their re-establishment, essential pharmaceutical supplies have been given, schools have been re-equipped and essential infrastructure, including water and sanitation, has been repaired. And we provided over 100 Australian medical staff to assist.

answer.para: As the emergency assistance phase draws to an end, as it obviously isâand we provided initially $60 million for that, all of which has been spentâand people return to their homes, we are beginning the task of assisting them to meet their longer term needs. In addition to what I have already described, the House well knows that the government has committed a billion dollars to the five-year Australia-Indonesia Partnership for Reconstruction and Development program, and progress on this is already pretty strong. Over $175 million worth of activities has already been agreed, including the $50 million Aceh rehabilitation program. We are helping, for example, with the rehabilitation of the Banda Aceh hospital; we are training doctors and nurses to take the places of some who were killed as a result of the tsunami.

In conclusion, there has been some suggestion in one of the newspapers today, the Australian Financial Review, that this program was not unfolding. It is and it is unfolding at a good and effective pace. It would be folly indeed if we tried to spend all of the money at once. That does not just apply to the government but also to the non-government organisations which have raised over $300 million. They have spent about 20 per cent of that, but it needs to be spent over a period of time, not spent all at once. This program by both the government and the non-government organisations is progressing very successfully. I think all Australians will be pleased to hear that, because all Australians have supported the response by both the government and the non-government organisations to the tsunami.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Health and Ageing. I refer the minister to his last two answers and I ask: given the medical evidence about the lack of chemically identical substitute drugs for Alimta for lung cancer and Keppra for epilepsy, is the minister guaranteeing no patient will ever pay more than the standard PBS copayment for these medications?
âNo, I am not. I am guaranteeing that my previous answer is correct.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Would the minister inform the House of further progress on the governmentâs efforts to introduce national literacy and numeracy tests and plain English report cards?

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Dobell for his question. He is working hard to get those toilets fixed at the Tuggerawong Public School in his electorate. As I informed the House last week, the government, before handing over $33 billion of taxpayersâ hard earned money for schooling over the next four years, has for the very first time put conditions on the funding. The states, before they receive that money, will be required to agree to a number of things, which include that by 2010 there will finally be a common starting age for schooling in Australia. We will from next year have not only testing of our children in years 3, 5, 7 and 9 in literacy and numeracy but reporting to parents. Principals will have a say over who actually teaches in the school. The performance of the school must be published at the school level. In other words, parents have a right to know how many students are passing literacy and numeracy in years 3, 5 and 7. They have a right to know the qualifications of the teachers, the participation of teachers in their ongoing professional learning and how much money governments spend on the support of teachers at the school level.

answer.para: One of the other requirements is career leaver destinations: how many kids got apprenticeships, how many went to TAFE, how many got a job and how many went to uni. That information needs to be published. Another requirement, which is long past due, is that of plain language reports to parents. As parents, we are sick and tired of getting politically correct language neutered reports at home about our kids. If you are told that your child is almost achieving, what does that mean? If you are told that your child is consolidating or performing sometimes or not yet performing, what does that mean? We have only one state government left to sign this agreement, and that is the Victorian government. The Victorian government has eight days to sign up before it will lose more than $1 billion in funding for schools.

The plain English report cards will describe student performance as A, B, C, D or E. As parents, we know what A, B, C, D and E mean. They will also be required to tell parents which quartile, which 25 per cent, of the class their child falls in. So, taking the typical Australian primary school report which has gone to the states, for example looking at mathematics, the student will be graded A to E. So, for example, with a D in mathematics, Mr Speaker, you would know exactly what that meant if your child came home with that or was in the bottom 25 per cent. Then the teacher is required to explain in plain language what it means. So the grades are from A to E and then the parents must be told in which quartile of the class their child falls. If your child is in the bottom 25 per centâsomebody has to be thereâyou would want to know about it. For example, the report might say: âWayne is trying hard in maths and attempting his homework. However, he is not doing as well as last year and I would like to discuss further work he could do at home. Please contact me.â This is what parents are going to get over the next 12 months. Plain language reporting is a condition of funding, and I table an example of a plain language report.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Isnât it a fact that, when interviewed on radio on 25 January this year, in answer to a question about whether the prices of branded medicines would go up for patients as a result of the Howard governmentâs 12.5 per cent price cut policy, the minister said:

quote.para: The idea that the price of drugs is going to go up because of a 12.5 per cent price cut for generics is just wrong.

talk.start.para: âI make two points. First of all, I say to the member for Holt that any patient whose doctor believes that a particular drug is clinically necessary can, by way of an approach to the HIC and an authorisation from the HIC, ensure that that patient gets the drug at the standard copayment. That is the first point I make. The second point I make is that we the government stand by our policy of a 12Â½ per cent mandatory price cut for new generic drugs coming onto the PBS. This is a good policy.
Ms Gillard interjectingâ
âOrder!
âIt is a good policy.
âYou put the price up.
âOrder! The member for Lalor!

âIt is a good policy because we need to make more use of generic drugs and we need to deliver a better deal for the taxpayers of Australia. This is a government which is quite prepared to consider two objectives at once and which is quite capable of it. We are quite capable of both delivering the necessary drugs to the patients of Australia and protecting the interests of taxpayersâunlike members opposite, who are capable of nothing but irresponsible scaremongering.
âGive us a guarantee.
âOrder! The member for Lalor is warned!

âI will just take a moment to focus, Mr Speaker, so that I do not mess up like yesterday. My question is addressed to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Would the minister update the House on recent developments with the governmentâs increased assistance to Australiaâs drought ravaged farmers.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr TRUSS

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for Hume for his question. He represents some of the worst drought affected farmers in New South Wales and he has been a strong advocate, providing timely and effective assistance to the farmers in his region. The member for Hume will welcome the good news that yesterday the Farm Household Support Amendment (Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment) Bill 2005 passed through the Senate. That means that all of the elements of the governmentâs enhanced drought assistance package can now be implemented on time and in full. The legislation means that there will now be a $10,000 concession on off-farm income in assessing the eligibility of farmers in drought stricken areas for the exceptional circumstances relief payment. That will mean that a lot more farmers will be eligible to receive this essential help for them and their families.

answer.para: Other parts of the package include the more generous EC interest rate subsidiesâup to 80 per cent in second and subsequent years of a droughtâand the easier off-farm assets test associated with those benefits. Additional counselling and support services are being put in place. The new drought Envirofund round will be called very soon. And yesterday the Prime Minister and I were happy to ceremonially hand over a cheque for $3 million to the CWA so that they are able to commence their role in providing additional assistance to farmers and their families who are especially in need. Last week I provided to the state rural adjustment authorities revised guidelines for the implementation of the interest rate subsidies, which again will mean that more assistance will be available and that it will be provided under more generous terms than has been the case in the past.

These benefits will certainly be encouraging to farmers facing the difficulties of drought. There is no doubt at all that the Howard-Anderson government has been the best friend that drought affected farmers have ever had. I guess there is only one thing better that we could deliver, and that is rain right across the nation. We have made a reasonable start on that, although I know we had a bit of assistance from above. There is one thing better than drought assistance that farmers can get, and that of course is rain across the country. I am encouraged by recent falls but, as the honourable member for Hume knows, there is going to have to be a continuation of this improved weather for some time before the drought is broken. In the interim, this government will stand beside farmers so that they are able to take advantage of better circumstances when they come.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Minister, isnât it a fact that the expensive new drugs used to treat osteoporosisâdrugs which cost the PBS $130 million a yearâare effective only if taken together with calcium tablets, which have now been removed from the PBS to save about $9 million a year? Isnât it also a fact that some patients with kidney problems may need to take as many as 10 calcium tablets a day, at a cost of over $30 a month? Given these facts, why did the government take calcium tablets off the PBS, particularly without getting any advice from the experts, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee?
âLet me make two points in response to the member for Lalor. The first point I make is that once upon a time there were responsible members of the Labor Party. Let me quote:

quote.para: ... the community as a whole can ill-afford the situation where large quantities of these medicines are dispensed on medical prescriptions when they are readily available over the counter ...

answer.para: That is a very true statementânot from me, not from the Treasurer or the Prime Minister; it was from Dr Neal Blewett, the Labor minister for health, when the former Labor government took a large number of over-the-counter medicines off the PBS. That is the first point I make. The second point I make is that the government has recently received advice from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee on this matter, and we are taking it seriously.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer. Would the minister advise the House on progress in giving choice in superannuation to Australian workers. Are there any barriers to greater choice?

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr BROUGH

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Blair for his question and his interest in superannuation and the workers of Australia. On 1 July this year, in just nine days time, some five million Australian workers, for the very first time, will get the choice of determining where their investment, their superannuation, is to be invested. This is something that the coalition has been fighting for since 25 May 1995, when it was first announced as coalition policy. In November that year, the then shadow Treasurer, now the Treasurer, told the ASFA conference exactly what the coalition intended to do with choice and how we were going to empower Australian workers. We took it to the Australian public in 1996 and won an overwhelming mandate. Here we are, nine years later, with nine days to go before finally Australian workers will be able to choose where their money is invested. It certainly has been a marathon.

answer.para: To people listening, to the Australian workers out there, it must seem incredible to believe that the Labor Party is still seeking to obstruct the introduction of super choice. There is just one sitting day left in the Senate and the Labor Party is yet to support the government in passing the final superannuation choice legislation. That is creating confusion for small business and unnecessary uncertainty just because the Labor Party refuses to make a decision.

People need to understand what it is that we are trying to achieve. For nine years the coalition have been fighting to give workers the right to be able to choose where their money is investedânot so some union through a union backed award agreement decides where your money goes, not so an employer decides where you should put your money, but so you as the worker who has earned that money decides where it goes. If an employee moves jobs they are required to set up another fund in many cases and have another set of fees. The Labor Party seems to think that is all right in 2005. That is the status quo that the Labor Party wants to maintain.

talk.start.para: Ms Macklin interjectingâ

âI hear the member for Jagajaga interject. In the same way, the member for Watson yesterday tried to tell the House that employers would face jail terms. I would like to tell the member for Brand, who is a Western Australian memberâit may come as some surprise to himâthat Western Australian employees have had the right to choose where they put their superannuation investments since 1998. I did not see at the last state election the Labor Party in Western Australia trying to remove that right. In fact, the very charge that was levelled in this place yesterday was that employers would go to jail. How many people have gone to jail? How many people have ASIC thrown the book at in Western Australia, where they have had the right of choice since 1998? One hundred? Ten? Zero. It is another lousy scare campaign and last-ditch attempt by the Labor Party to try to roll back choice. It is not going to happen.

answer.para: I read in the Financial Review today that the Labor Party will release its own super plan closer to the next federal election in 2007. I implore the Labor Party to make a decision todayânot in 2007, not 12 years after we put choice into this place, but todayâand once and for all support super choice in the Senate. Let Australian workers have the choice to determine where their biggest investment for their retirementâtheir superannuationâshould be.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
âMr Speaker, I seek the indulgence of the chair to add to an answer.
âThe minister may proceed.

âIt has been reported that there was a security breach in an Arizona based credit card transaction processing company. The vast majority of cards vulnerable to the breach are held by US customers. Of the MasterCards affected it is thought that less than two per cent were issued by banks in the Australia-Pacific region. The following information comes from Visa. Visa has informed the Treasury that it was the National Australia Bank that uncovered this fraud out of all the domestic and international banks of the world and reported it to MasterCard and Visa in September 2004. The FBI was notified and commenced an extensive investigation and on 1 June 2005 declared it a crime scene. During this investigation organisations were told by the FBI not to say anything publicly and the FBI only allowed public comment on Thursday or Friday of last week. I am told by Senator Ellison that he was aware of the matter when it was reported in newspapers in Australia, as was I, which was some time this week.
âWhat about the department?

âYou want answers; I am giving them. You ask when the government was aware. I am telling you that I was aware when it was in newspapers and I am toldâI would not know myselfâthat Senator Ellison became aware of it when it was published in newspapers this week. The electronic funds transfer code of conduct administered by ASIC protects account holders from liability in respect of unauthorised transactions where they have not contributed to the loss. Visa and MasterCard have similar internal rules.

speech.para: The government encourages all credit card users to review their statements on a regular basis and report any suspicious transaction to their financial institution. Australian banksâand they have done this publiclyâare urging credit card customers who have travelled to the United States or used their cards to buy goods from a US based online merchant to check their statements and report any unauthorised transactions to their financial institution. I again state that this was believed to be a breach of security in Arizona in the United States.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, with regard to recent press reports concerning the very large number of House of Representatives committee reports and joint committee reports that government ministers have failed to respond to, will you agree to write on behalf of this House to the responsible minister in each case to seek advice as to when a response will be forthcoming and the reasons for any further delay? I understand a report to the House on the status of all outstanding government responses to committee reports is due to be presented tomorrow by you. I think it is important that steps are taken by you to:

quote.para: ... reassert and re-establish a degree of respect and regard for the institution.

question.para: They are words used by this Prime Minister on the election of the Speaker on 30 April 1996 and, sadly, not acted upon by his ministers.

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Banks. As he has rightly pointed out, tomorrow I will be providing a status report to the House on responses to committee reports. I intend to make a few further comments at that point.

talker.name: Mr ANDREWS,MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I seek the indulgence of the chair to add to an answer.
âThe minister may proceed.

âI was asked a question by the member for Perth about some negotiations between the department of finance, as it is, and Comcar over their collective arrangements. I am advised that the department of finance met with the two relevant unions, the TWU and the CPSU, on 2 June to discuss negotiations of a section LJ collective agreementâthat is, one with the unionsâand that in the course of those discussions the department of finance gave the unions a list of 10 possible productivity measures that could offset any pay increases that the unions may seek in the negotiations. It is therefore wrong to assert that we were stripping entitlements. The 10 proposals, I am advised, are purely options for the unions to consider and are completely dependent on the size of any wage increase sought by the employees. It is open to the unions, as is usual, to accept or reject some or none or all of the optionsâthey are not final. Indeed, the department of finance has sought for three weeks to arrange a meeting with the unions to get a response to the proposals made at the earlier meeting, on 2 June, and the unions only agreed yesterday to meet on 28 June. This is a beat-up by the Labor Party to portray negotiations as though they were outcomes and to scaremonger about productivity improvements in the absence of referring to any offsetting pay increases.
âMr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
âDoes the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
âYes.
âPlease proceed.

âThe Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations implied in an answer today that I had misused my postage allowance with regard to industrial relations issues. What I have done, Mr Speaker, is write to all my constituents and invite them to come to meet with me and sign a petition of opposition to the governmentâs industrial relations measures, and I am very proud to have done so.
âMr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
âDoes the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
âYes.
âPlease proceed.

âI also refer to question time today in which I believe that the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations misled and misrepresented me in relation to correspondence. He can wave it in my face for all he cares. He referred to the correspondence sent out in my name to my constituency and implied that I had used that process inappropriately. That is not true. I have also written to my constituency inviting them to meet with me on Friday evening at the Tuggeranong Hyperdome in my electorate to discuss the IR issues.

talk.start.para: âI have received letters from the honourable member for Lalor and the honourable member for Wentworth proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by standing order 46(d), I have selected the matter which, in my opinion, is the most urgent and important; that is, that proposed by the honourable member for Lalor, namely:

quote.para: The Governmentâs failure to be accountable for its ongoing mismanagement of Australiaâs health system

subdebate.1.para: I therefore call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their placesâ

talk.start.para: âThat was a very wise selection indeed, Mr Speaker; thank you very much. There is a brand of politics that causes more disgust towards politicians and governments than any other. Many people in this parliament were fans of the American television show The West Wing in which the press secretaries would gather on a Friday afternoon and talk about âputting out the trashâ. What they meant by âputting out the trashâ was that they would put out the bad stories on Friday nightâput them out deliberately too late for Saturdayâs newspapers but by Sundayâs newspapers they were too old. That was how they would clear out the stories they did not want anybody to know about. It is clever, it is tricky and it is that brand of politics that causes the community to reel back in horror. Unfortunately, it is a brand of politics in which the Minister for Health and Ageing fundamentally believes, because it is that kind of trickiness that has actually characterised his interaction with the public across the sweep of his public life.

speech.para: This is the minister who in 1998 denied any involvement in the Australians for Honest Politics slush fund, only to be caught out spectacularly on TV on 27 August 2003 on the 7.30 Report. This is the minister who got caught out so amazingly on Lateline denying and then confessing in the one interview that he had met with Cardinal George Pell. This is the minister who went out and gave the community a rock solid, ironclad guarantee before the election, with every ounce of his credibility and every fibre of his being in that guaranteeâwith his word, his honour and his integrity on the line in that rock solid, ironclad guaranteeâonly to smash it immediately after the election. This is the minister who practises that sort of mean, tricky politics by doing things like putting out the private health insurance premium increase notifications on the same day that interest rates go up, hoping against hope that one storyâthe big interest rates storyâwould come over the top and exclude from the public glare the story about the mismanagement by the Howard government of private health insurance premium increases.

Last Wednesday we saw the minister back at it again when at 6.30 that nightâwhen, as Leader of the House, he would have known that Douglas Wood had been released and that all of the nation was going to be rejoicing that Douglas Wood had been released and was going to be returned home safeâthere was the minister sneaking out under the radar, hoping no-one would notice the fact that he is turning our Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme into a two-tiered system. There is a reason I started with an allusion to The West Wing. I did so because this is the Americanisation of our health systemâthe creation of a two-tiered system for pharmaceuticals. Perhaps the Australian community would forgive Minister Abbott his meanness, his trickiness, his bit of manipulation here and slipping out of a press release there and his not-quite-frank statement on TVâmaybe they would forgive him those thingsâif they thought he was competently running our health system.

In fact, Minister Abbott is either nowhere near our health system or near those bits that are a complete shambles. Let us look across the sweep of the Howard government. Who is looking after the biggest issue when it comes to the health sectorâs medical work force? The Treasurer isâthat is who is looking after that. Who is looking after reviewing the PBS? The Treasurer is, and, when the minister for health was asked, he did not even know about the review. Take a huge issue like mental health. Who is looking after that? The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing, who is leaving the chamber now. Take something as important to the future of medical science as the stem cell review. Who is looking after that? The Minister for Ageing is. Then of course there is the question of the sale of Australiaâs biggest private health insurer, Medibank Privateâgovernment owned at the momentâthat most Australians rely on for their private health insurance products. Who is looking after the sale of that? Senator Nick Minchin, as Minister for Finance and Administration, is. And when asked about the scoping study for the sale of Medibank Private, the minister for health did not even know anything about it. So all of these enormous health issues are being dealt with elsewhere in the Howard government.

One might imagine that his closest colleagues know something about his competence that they do not let the rest of the Australian community into. When you look at the things that the minister for health is actually managing, you see they are a shambles all round. I am going to go out and buy a Tattslotto ticket on the strength of the fact that I put in this MPI before the most recent shambles in health even emerged in the public domain. But it has emerged today with the Pharmacy Guild basically putting up their hands and saying: âWe want to deliver medicines at a reasonable price to Australian consumers. We would like the Prime Minister to honour his word, the word he gave us when he wrote to us on his letterheadââa prime ministerial letter on prime ministerial letterhead, and John Howardâs signature down the bottom, which is something you would think would actually count a little bit. âWe would like the Prime Minister to honour his word to pharmacists. We are trying to negotiate a new five-year agreement with the minister for health and we just canât do it because the minister for health cannot competently conclude these negotiations.â That is the most recent shambles in health, which emerged today in between me putting in this topic for the matters of public importance debate and the debate actually coming on before the parliament. The pharmacy agreementâa five-year agreement about the delivery of pharmaceutical products and medicines across Australia at reasonable pricesâis expiring on 30 June. And this minister, who knew that it was expiring on 30 Juneâbecause everybody knew that was the end dateâand who has had every day since he first became minister for health on 29 September 2003 to competently conclude a new agreement with the pharmacists, has been unable to do so, jeopardising Australiansâ access to pharmaceutical products after 30 June this year. Everything he has ever touched in health has become a shambles.

But the very particular matters I questioned the minister about today show that the very thing he slipped out last Wednesday, hoping no-one would noticeâthis new two-tiered structure for the PBSâis, as of today, in a shambles too. Let us talk about this in some level of detail. What has happened here is that in the federal election campaign, after the Prime Minister had gone out on the Sunday, done his campaign launch speech and spent billions and billions of dollars with not one dollar specifically directed at older Australians, by the Monday and Tuesday in the second to last week of the campaign the headlines and the newscasts were all saying that there was an adverse community reaction to Prime Minister Howardâs free-spending policy announcement speech. On the Wednesday we had the Labor launch and it contained a very big policy for older AustraliansâMedicare Gold. By the Friday the Howard government, which had obviously wanted to coast through the election campaign not saying a word about older Australians because they were taking their votes for granted, thought they had better respond. But they knew they had spent too much money. What were they going to do faced with this conundrum: they needed a policy for older Australians but had spent too much money? âOh,â they go, âwe need a savings measure. Where are we going to get a savings measure from across the whole sweep of government? Where are we going to make a cut when we are desperate? I knowâthe Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.â

They had a small problem: they had spent two years corresponding with Labor denying savings could be made on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Schemeâdenying such savings were possible. But let me tell you: while they bleat about the Charter of Budget Honesty process as it applies to the opposition, they never apply anything that sounds like the same discipline to themselvesânever once, not ever. So, with complete disregard of anything like transparency in fiscal policy, in a quick 48-hour cycle, they cobbled together a cut on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. It is very important to remember that the money generated from this cut was not going to go to PBS sustainability; it was not even going to go to the Health portfolio. It was going out of Health to other portfolios to fund an older Australians policy that they cobbled together at the last minute. The Department of Health and Ageing has admitted at Senate estimates that it had nothing to do with the costing of this savings measure. Why should that surprise us?

talk.start.para: âIt was in the caretaker period.

âIf it was a responsible measure, you would have been working on it before the caretaker period, my friend. Putting that to one side, why should it surprise us that the Minister for Health and Ageing did not know anything about this savings measure? It would not surprise us at all because, on his own admission, at a press conference he said he is ânot very good with figuresâ. For a minister with a multibillion dollar spending portfolio, his depth of knowledge about expenditure in health is limited to the statement, âPeter will provide; he always doesââa reference to the Treasurer. The ministerâs intellectual hold on the financing of the single biggest expenditure area of the Commonwealth governmentâhis complete encapsulation of this challenge for modern Western democracies where inflation and balancing the health account keep public policy specialists and academics fully engagedâis âPeter will provide; he always does.â The problem is that Peter has a tendency to provide six months before an election and a very startling tendency to cut back six months afterwards. When Peter could have salvagedâ
(Hon. IR Causley)âThe member Lalor will use the memberâs correct name.
âShe is quoting him.
âMember for Hotham, the chair does not need any help.
Mr Crean interjectingâ
âThe chair can also remember the standing ordersâespecially 94(a).
Mr Crean interjectingâ
âI will be speaking to you.

âIt is a direct quote as to how the Minister for Health and Ageing refers to the Treasurer. The Treasurer is known to refer to me by unusual titles, but I will respect your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker. The problem for the Minister for Health and Ageing is that the Treasurer provides in the run-up to elections, but he does not provide afterwards. The Treasurer could have salvaged this ministerâs future and credibility and allowed him to keep his rock solid, ironclad guarantee to the Australian public for an expenditure of $200 millionâthe difference between the Charter of Budget Honesty figure of $1.3 billion and the $1.5 billion the Treasurer said he had to cut back. He decided not to do that. Peter does not always provide, does he?

speech.para: Let us come to the details of the savings measure this government cobbled together during the election campaign and the consequence it has had. The government want to cut the price of generics by 12Â½ per cent. That is not a bad thing, but because it is badly designed policy it has a lot of knock-on consequences for newly listed, innovative drugs. The minister has no hold on the interconnection between these two things. He wanders around saying, âIt all doesnât matter because I know my policy has caused four drug companiesâand four drugsâto say that they will not accept the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme listed price. I know that means that patients will have to pay a special contribution, but it does not matter because there are chemically equivalent drugs available on the PBS.â Wrong, Minister: there is no chemically equivalent drug to eclipta, which is taken for lung cancer; there is no chemically equivalent drug to keppra, which is taken for epilepsy. Doctors say you cannot substitute.

The Minister for Health and Ageing comes into this place and says, âIf you canât substitute, then you can have it at the PBS price.â My question to you, Minister, is: what is this special patient contribution which you announced ever going to do for these two drugs? If there is no chemical substitute, if every patient who is taking that drug needs only that drug and you say they do not have to pay the special patient contribution, that means that no-one will ever pay the special patient contribution, but you cannot have it both ways. You should get up to the dispatch box and say that you announced a mythical policy last Wednesday and that no-one will ever pay the special patient contribution, or you should say that in truth you know some people who need that drug and will pay the special patient contribution despite all of your words of comfort and guarantees.

There are only two possibilities, there is no third choice: patients are going to end up paying that special patient contribution, even though it is the only drug they can take, or your special patient contribution is a myth and you can guarantee that no-one will ever have to pay it. But I know what is going to happen: people with lung cancer who cannot take any other medication will have to pay $500 out of their pocket. That is a disgrace equal to where we started this session with you breaking your rock solid ironclad guarantee. It is an absolute disgrace. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âSo much bitterness and bile in one person!
âWhat about yourself?
(Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Hotham is on thin ice.
Ms Gillard interjectingâ

âI wish the Australian people could see that. That would be interesting. Today, the member for Lalor has made a rare prime time appearance. The incredible, disappearing shadow minister for health has, advisedly, been kept under wraps for the last six months by the Leader of the Opposition.
