talk.start.para: âUntil today, all she has been allowed has been four questions. In the face of what she keeps saying is a collapsing health system, chronic incompetence and maladministration, the Leader of the Opposition has allowed her just four questions until today. She got three questions today. Good on her! Obviously, the little touch-up that she got yesterday has worked.
âThe minister will refer to the member by her seat or title.

âI am delighted to think that I still have the capacity to get under her skin. This bile, this anger transference from the Leader of the Oppositionâwho has advisedly kept her under wraps for the last six monthsâis quite unbecoming and demeans her. It certainly does not enhance the standards of this House.

speech.para: If our health system is the disaster that the member for Lalor keeps telling us it is then why, when the Leader of the Opposition went out yesterday to reverse his collapsing poll standings and revive the spirit of his demoralised troops, did he nominate three areas he was going to focus on for the rest of this term? He was not going to be distracted by the concerns of voters, he was not going to have anything to do with suggestions that his frontbench are a bunch of dillsâoh no, they are all brilliant, as has been demonstrated time after time in question time over the last 10 daysâand the three areas they are going to focus on are Telstra, IR and debt. Where is health?

talk.start.para: Ms Gillard interjectingâ
âThe member for Lalor is in a difficult position. She has been warned.

âThe Leader of the Opposition either does not think that health is very important or, more likely, he does not like his shadow health minister and does not trust her competence to deliver a substantial message. I was quite interested to hear on Sky News on Monday, 13 June the opposition signalling that it wants to shift the focus to health and land some blows on Minister Tony Abbott. I was quivering with fear and apprehension! I was so nervous I could hardly eat my cornflakes on Tuesday morning! I had to wait all this time to have three or four questions, which are all essentially the same, to which there is a clear answer.

speech.para: Since the member for Lalor made her announcement on Sky News, we have had four press releases and four doorstops but, until today, not a single question on health. We constantly get from the member for Lalor a string of hysterical press releases and a succession of shrill doorstops saying that the sky is falling in and we will all be destroyed because of the evil of the Howard government. Obviously I do not believe her, because I am presiding over the health system. The Australian public do not believe her. According to Newspoll, more and more Australians believe that the Howard government is best placed to handle the issues of health and Medicare.
The Leader of the Opposition does not believe the member for Lalor. If he did, he would give her more questions in question time. When the Leader of the Opposition took office, he was asked:

quote.para: Have you given thought to how Labor will change its approach, will need to change its approach to meet that challenge in the Reps?

speech.para: The Leader of the Opposition replied:

quote.para: Yes, I have and totally new significance will come around our tactics committee in the House of Representatives and the role that Julia Gillard plays â¦

speech.para: A lot of new significance has come in: she now has almost no role! Under the former Leader of the Opposition, the member for Lalor would do a doorstop every day and then ask a question in the House of Representatives. Under the current Leader of the Opposition, she does the doorstop every dayâthe same shrill, hysterical attacks on the Howard governmentâbut almost never asks a question. It is not just that I do not believe her, it is not just that the Australian public does not believe her and it is not just that her own leader does not believe her; it is that the premiers do not believe her. If the health system were as chronically mismanaged as the member for Lalor keeps telling us, why is it that the premiers and the Prime Minister said in the communique that came out of COAG last week that Australia has one of the worldâs best health systems? How can it be one of the worldâs best health systems if, in the words of the member for Lalor, it is suffering from âongoing mismanagementâ? The member for Lalor is on her own. She is isolated among her colleagues, unpopular with the Leader of the Opposition and scorned by the premierâthose successful and responsible Labor politicians. She is on her own.

Let me take a few moments of the Houseâs time to talk about some of the precise issues that the member for Lalor has raised. She says that I denied involvement in the Australians for Honest Politics Trust. I ask: what has that got to do with health? I have never denied involvement in the Australians for Honest Politics Trust. For the record, let me say that I have never denied that. If the member for Lalor is going to come into this House and make statements, as a former partner in a law firm she should at least get it right, tell the truth. I think she is suffering from TDDâtruth deficit disorder! The next statement she made was that I denied a meeting with Cardinal Pell.

talk.start.para: âThat is true. I have got the videotape!

âI did not deny a meeting with Cardinal Pell. I said, when asked, that I had no recollection of a meeting. The member for Lalor then said that we had denied that savings were possible in the PBS. Again, that is not true. What we saidâ
âWell, get your letter out!
âThis caterwauling is unbecoming of the House. This shadow minister will treat other members of this House with the same courtesy she received when she made her contribution earlier.
âThe chair will ensure that, Minister.

âI am sure you will, Mr Deputy Speaker. The member for Lalor said we had denied that savings were possible in the PBS. That is not true. We said that savings could not be included in the forward estimates if they were merely speculative or hypothetical; in order to be included in the forward estimates they had to be the result of a change in government policy. When she finally dropped the personal abuse and the litany of untruths and tried to talk about health, she came up with two criticisms. The first criticism was that the 12Â½ per cent mandatory price cut policy means that patients will allegedly have to pay hundreds of dollars more for necessary drugs. I have already said this several times in the House today, but let me say it again for âMadam Slow Learnerâ: if it is clinically necessary in the opinion of the treating doctor that a patient should get a particular drug, all the doctor needs to do is seek an authorisation from the Health Insurance Commission and that drug will be available to that person at the standard copayment. Please, let us not hear any more of this furphy, this scare tactic. Let us have the member for Lalor tell the truth for once and properly describe the policy of the government as I have repeatedly explained it today.

speech.para: Her next statement about health was that negotiations with the Pharmacy Guild were not going particularly well. Has the member for Lalor ever had negotiations with the Pharmacy Guild? What is the proposal of the member for Lalor? How does the member for Lalor imagine that we are going to get savings out of the PBS through the use of generics? How does the member for Lalor imagine that we are going to get savings out of the PBS through more effective management of the supply and distribution chain? It behoves responsible politicians not just to come in here like Chicken Little and cry day in, day out that the sky is falling in but to come up with some policies of their own.

The current Australian Labor Party has two policies. The first policy is Medicare Gold. That policy was described by Michael Costello, the former Chief of Staff to the Leader of the Opposition, as a strategic disaster. It was described by Peter Botsman, a genuine Labor intellectualâ

talk.start.para: Mr Laurie Ferguson interjectingâ

âI note the laughter and the scorn coming from the member oppositeâas a policy that had the body of a wombat and the head of a donkey. It was described by former President of the Australian Labor Party, former respected member of this House and former minister in the Hawke government, Barry Jones, as a turkey. This is policy No. 1: Medicare Goldâa strategic disaster, a turkey with the body of a wombat and the head of a donkey. What a monster! But it is the conception of the member for Lalor.

speech.para: The other policy of the member for Lalor is to totally abolish the Howard governmentâs Medicare safety net. The member for Lalor comes into this House regularlyâwhen she is allowed. It is not normally in prime time, but it is in the adjournment and grievance debates and in debates on second reading speeches. She comes in and talks about how terrible it is that the thresholds of the Medicare safety net have been adjusted by the Howard government to what we originally proposed. This terrible crime is that we now have the same safety net thresholds that we originally proposed in November 2003.

With all these buckets of crocodile tears, the gallons of indignation and the self-righteousness dripping out of every pore, what would she do to the threshold? She would abolish it altogether. There would be no safety net. There would be 1.6 million Australians who would totally miss out on the additional help from Medicare that they need and deserve, and $1.1 billion would be ripped out of the Medicare budget because these people are Medicare vandals. I really do invite interested members of the general public who do take health seriously, who might be following the discussion here this afternoon and who want to figure out who is serious about health, to look at the work of the Howard government: look at the $11 billion more that we have invested since October 2003 in the forward estimates for the Health and Ageing Portfolio; look at the fact that we have got bulk-billing rates up from 66 per cent to 73 per cent; look at the fact that bulk-billing rates for kids are now at an all-time high; and look at the fact that we have settled down the crisis that was enveloping our public hospital system. Compare that with the web site of the Australian Labor Party. These people, who think that health is so important, have devoted just 323 words to health. It is pathetic. It is a disgrace. It is a comment on the fact that the member for Lalor has no standing with her own leader, no standing with her own party and increasingly less standing with the general public that she is forced to come into this House and make the kind of shrill, hysterical and false attacks that we have seen today.

talk.start.para: âOn reflecting on that very passionate contribution by my friend the Minister for Health and Ageing, Tony Abbott, I was very concerned that he was talking about messages of hate, messages not benefiting his career. You always worry in politics when an announcement that tastes like a specific sort of sandwich and is a specific sort of sandwich gets delivered when you are least likely to see it, particularly at a time of national rejoicing. âsneaky, mean and tricky press releases put out in the timing of them. Few would match this press release put out just after 6.30 pm, when the nation was rejoicing, under the cover of darkness. speech.para: This press release should be of great concern to the least advantaged in our community, who have borne the brunt of a lot of the Howard government reforms. I am trying to help the minister for health, so I will read some of his press release into the record:

quote.para: The Government is now in the process of implementing 12.5 per cent price cuts for 10 brands of PBS medicines where generic equivalents have applied for listing on August 1.

Unfortunately, four companies have not agreed to accept lower prices. As a result four brands of medicines listed on the PBS will be subject to a Special Patient Contribution in addition to the normal PBS co-payment.

talk.start.para: Dr Emerson interjectingâ

âI know that this government has taken âuser paysâ to a new level, but this is a very OrwellianâI thank the member for Rankin for saying it as it isâuse of language. This is the government that basically said that the Medicare safety net was going to be set at a level and it has increased. This is the government that tells people who have paid their taxes that they should be paying more to see their doctor. Now we have the government basically saying to people, âWe screwed the negotiations with the pharmaceutical companies and now we are going to screw you by passing this on.â It would be bad enough if these were well-off people or people who did not necessarily need these drugs, but try telling someone with mesothelioma that they need to pay $460 to get their medication. It is interestingâas I said, in my view this is a hole in the wall.

speech.para: Let us look at some of the antipsychotic drugs, because one of the pharmaceutical companies that refused to accept that 12.5 per cent cut was a company that dealt in antipsychotic and antidepressant medication. The problem is that there are a number of new generation drugs coming on stream which are quite expensive. This leads to my broader concern with respect to the health ministerâa concern that has been constructively raised by the shadow minister for health: there are very scant details about this policy and the mechanisms and process under which it will operate. In fact, according to the Sydney Morning Herald, the new President of the AMA, Mukesh Haikerwal, said that the new measure was âa chink in the armour of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Schemeâ. The report stated that, according to Dr Haikerwal:

quote.para: Although doctors would have to play a pivotal role in declaring where patients should be exempt from the additional cost, the medical profession had not been consulted about the move.

speech.para: What sort of change is this? We in the electorate of Holt are used to some funny things happening, I tell you.

talk.start.para: âI bet they are with you as their member!

âAs the member for Casey would know, when we were lobbying for a Medicare officeâand my good friend the health minister did in fact come and open itâit took 10 years and a petition with 22,000 signatures to get it. speech.para: What do these changes mean to the least well-off, to those with psychotic disorders, to those many Australians who rely on antidepressants and to those dying of lung cancer? The health minister has not made a statement in this placeâunless the shadow minister for health has not told me; I certainly have not heard anything. He has done this by stealth. He has slipped a substantial change into the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme under the door while the Prime Minister was addressing this House on a matter of national importance.

It is not just us who believe this. I have quoted the President of the AMA, Mukesh Haikerwal. There is a very appropriate headline to an article written about this by Annabel Stafford in the Australian Financial Review. It sort of summarises the minister for healthâs approach to life. The headline is âThis is going to hurtâ. I think that is very appropriate. It is not just the opposition being critical. For the member for Caseyâs edification, I quote from the article:

quote.para: Health experts ... have slammed the governmentâs plans to make patients pay for drugs on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, saying itâs a dismantling of the cheap medicines scheme by stealth.

speech.para: Someone who I think would be of great importance to the minister for health is the Chief Executive Officer of Catholic Health Australia, Francis Sullivan. quote.para: We should make no mistake that these measures, along with the recent cuts to the PBS [safety net], indicate that the government is looking at every opportunity to shift costs to patients and this in turn erodes any benefit low-paid people receive from the tax relief.

speech.para: So a good friend of the minister for health, the Chief Executive Officer of Catholic Health Australia, Francis Sullivan, has belled the catâthe health minister is not present in the chamberâso it is not just us who are belling the cat on this issue. This is a serious breach in relation to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. When we tried to have a debate on this, it was gagged. I was here. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAfter listening to the contributions of those oppositeâthe member for Lalor and most recently the member for Holtâit is quite obvious that the motive behind, and the reason for, this matter of public importance is not a concern for health policy. This is not about health policy at all. Both of those members sketched out an elaborate conspiracy theory that reflects either their particular political outlook at the moment or a vivid imagination, or a combination of both.

speech.para: At the outset, I would like to address in some detail why the conspiracy theory, outlined so vividly by the member for Lalor, and to a lesser extent by the member for Holt, simply does not stack up. The motive for proposing this MPI is something entirely different. It is not about the concern of those opposite for health policy, as they would pretend. I will concede that the member for Lalor is far better at pretending that she believes in something passionately than is the member for Holt.

What this MPI is aboutâand the reason it has been proposed todayâhas nothing to do with health policy; rather, it is a desperate and irresponsible act by those on the other side to cover up policy and political calamity on issues far away from health. It is to cover up other issues that are quite obvious and which are not at all the subject of a conspiracy. But they do appear in the Australian, where members opposite are being quoted on their views regarding the Labor Partyâs approach to so many other issues.
Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âAmong those opposite who are interjecting is my good friend the member for Melbourne Ports, for whom I have high regard. Having a high regard for the member for Melbourne Ports means that I know him well. I know that he will always interject when he is sensitive about a subjectâalways. The member for Lalor outlined with vivid imagination her conspiracy theory based on an episode of The West Wing. The problem is that her conspiracy theory runs like this: last Thursday a press release went out at a terribly nasty time and, therefore, this was something of great concern to those opposite.

speech.para: The member for Lalor and the member for Holt said they were so concerned about this issue that they wanted to propose an MPI. The only problem is that, if they were so concerned, they would have proposed an MPI at the first available opportunity. If they were so concerned, they would have proposed this MPI yesterday. Instead of putting forward an MPI on this matter yesterday, we had an MPI on small business, which was proposed by a shadow minister who is, I think, about 32nd in line. The shadow minister, who is 32nd in the Labor team, got precedence over the member for Lalor. Say she missed out on the MPI in the tactics group yesterday; you would have thought that she would have got a question, that she would have come in here on Tuesday morningâ

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Casey will refer to members by their title.

âBecause the member for Lalor cares so deeply about this issue and has proposed an MPI, she would have come in here and asked the first question. But, no, we had 10 questions without the member for Lalor getting a guernsey, without her asking a question. Today, there were five questions on subjects that had nothing to do with this MPI. The first question from the Leader of the Opposition was on petrol. The second question from the member for Grayndler was on whales. The third question from the member for Hunter was on credit cards. The member for Perth asked the startling question about Comcar drivers. Then we had a question on voluntary student unionism. Finally, after last Thursday, the member for Lalor got a guernsey and asked her first question on health.

speech.para: As I said, if those opposite were really concerned about this issue, if they were deeply of the belief that this was such a critical policy issue, we would have had an MPI yesterday. We would have had questions on Monday and Tuesday. We would have had questions today. The member for Lalor had 25 opportunities to ask a question and she took the 26th question today. She asked the sixth question in question time today. So we know that deep concern is not the reason she has proposed this MPIâand we know that because she could have done so yesterday. We know that the member for Lalor could have asked the first question, not the 26th. So there must be another reason why this MPI has been proposed. The motive for proposing the MPI is obvious. Those opposite know it. It is another episode of The West Wing that the member for Lalor is acting out, and that is the great diversion from their own policy and political catastrophe.

Since the member for Lalor raised American politics, it reminded me of another great political figure who had a vivid imaginationâthat is, former President Lyndon Johnson. To paraphrase, he said that if you have a relative who has one eye and it is in the middle of their forehead, you do not keep them in the front living room. I am grateful that the member for Reid is in the chamber, because he is that person in the Labor Party. The great problem for the Labor Party is that he is not just in the front living room; he is at the doorstops every morning describing a policy that is completely at odds with his backbench and that has led the leadership of the Labor Party into total policy catastrophe throughout this week. He has announced, I think, three separate positions. Two were identical. The first one was followed by a total reversalâ

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I appreciate that an MPI discussion should be wide ranging, but this is getting well and truly off the subject matter of the MPI.
âThe member for Casey should come back to the point of the MPI.
âI am more than happy to. In following the member for Lalor, I thought I should be equally wide ranging. I do appreciate the role of the Whip to cover the uncoverable. I appreciate what theâ
âThe member for Casey will come back to the MPI.
âThat is why this MPI has been proposed, as the Minister for Health and Ageing outlined quite clearly. The MPI is in the following terms:

quote.para: The Governmentâs failure to be accountable for its ongoing mismanagement of Australiaâs health system.

speech.para: After the Premiers Conference, I would not have thought that any other Labor figure in Australia believed that. As the minister for health points out, Australia has a good health system, and the Labor Premiers agree with that. Whilst those opposite will criticise the health systemâand the minister for health outlined just what an irresponsible furphy it was that they ran today in question timeâwe must ask: what is their alternative? When you look back over the last nine years, you see a doubling of the spending on health policy. You see the introduction of a private health insurance rebate, which never existed before, of 30 per cent for the general public, 35 per cent for those aged over 65 and 40 per cent for those over 70. You see the introduction of a Medicare safety net that is now paying benefits for out-of-hospital expenses that Medicare never paid in that form.

You would think that if those opposite were criticising the health system they would be offering to increase spending in those areas. But, far from that, the past for those opposite will actually be the future health policy if Labor ever gets its way. If Labor had its way, what health system would we see? Let us go to the substance of this MPI. You would see a health system with no private health insurance rebate. The member for Holt spoke after the member for Lalor about the deep concern for health in his electorate. He obviously has no concern for the more than 40 per cent of people in his electorate who have private health insurance. That is obviously something they have picked up which would explain his result at the last election. Not only would we have no private health insurance rebate; as the minister for health pointed out, we would have no Medicare safety net because, whilst the member for Lalor will criticise the safety net, what she does not publicly outline is that her policy desire is not to alter it or tweak it but to totally abolish it.

What is her alternativeâMedicare Gold? It has been called foolâs gold. I would call it for what it was: âMedicare gold toothâ. That policy, amazingly, is the one policy the member for Lalor still sticks to today, in spite of opposition from those on her own backbench and inside the shadow cabinet. As the minister for health rightly pointed out, Labor figures have called it everything from a strategic disaster, âsomething with the head of a donkey and the body of a wombatâ, a hoax, to something that proved to be a turkey. Lindsay Tanner, the member for Melbourne, said it would be a very substantial burden on future budgets. This MPI is a furphy. It has been put up to cover up a policy catastrophe on the other side and it should be dismissed for the irrelevancy that it is. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOrder! The discussion is concluded. Before we go on with government business, could I just make a comment that there has been a liberal use today of personal pronouns: âyouâ, âheâ, âsheâ and âyourâ. âOn behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the sixth, seventh, eighth, ninth and 10th reports for 2005 of the committee relating to the Australia House defence and light wells refurbishment, Australian High Commission, London; the midlife upgrade of the existing chancery at the Australian High Commission in Singapore; new Consulate-General building in Bali, Indonesia; construction of a chancery in Vientiane, Laos; and the Reserve Bank of Australia business resumption site.

speech.para: Ordered that the reports be made parliamentary papers.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâThe committeeâs sixth report of 2005 addresses the refurbishment of light wells and defence office accommodation at Australia House in London. The works, referred by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, are intended to ensure compliance with current occupational health and safety standards, provide an acceptable level of amenity for tenants, ensure ongoing viability of the property in respect of income generation and redress degradation of the light well areas. Having investigated the proposal, the committee is satisfied that the works will improve the amenity of the 90-year-old building in a cost-effective manner and therefore recommends that the works proceed at an estimated cost of $11.98 million.

speech.para: The committeeâs seventh report of 2005 examines the midlife upgrade of Australiaâs existing chancery building at its High Commission in Singapore. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade reported that the chancery in its current form has significant deficiencies in meeting current occupational health and safety and Building Code of Australia standards. It is dysfunctional and non-cost-effective in layout and does not present an appropriate image of Australia in its representational and reception areas. To redress these deficiencies, the department proposes to upgrade building services, access, security and communications systems and reconfigure and refurbish tenant office accommodation. The committee was satisfied with the departmentâs responses to its questions and recommends that the work proceed at an estimated cost of $12.7 million.

The committeeâs eighth report of 2005 deals with a proposal, also by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, to construct a new Consulate-General building in Bali, Indonesia, at an estimated cost of $7.15 million. The department reported that the former Consulate-General building in Bali is no longer suitable to fulfil its consular and representative role, with significant deficiencies in respect of occupational health and safety, floor space and functionality, building structure and services and particularly security. Since the terrorist bombing in 2002, the Australian Consulate-General in Bali has been accommodated in leased premisesâa situation that is not sustainable in the long term. The committee is in no doubt as to the requirement for the proposed work and recommends that it proceed. Further, the committee is pleased to note that the proposed work will provide a permanent site for, and improve access to, the memorial garden and anniversary pond erected to victims of the Bali bombing.

A further proposal by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Tradeânamely, the construction of a new chancery in Vientiane, Laosâforms the subject of the committeeâs ninth report of 2005. The proposed new building, estimated to cost $11 million, is intended to replace the existing chancery, which was acquired and refurbished in 1961 and no longer maintains modern standards in respect of services, layout, building codes or occupational health and safety requirements. The committee has given detailed consideration to this proposal and it recommends that the works proceed at an estimated cost of $11 million.

The 10th report of 2005 presents the committeeâs findings in relation to the proposed construction of a dedicated business resumption site for the Reserve Bank of Australia. The purpose of the proposed work is to provide a facility that, in the event of an emergency, will ensure the continuation of functions critical to the operation of Australiaâs financial systems. During the course of its inquiry, the committee investigated the revenue to be generated and/or saved by this project, issues relating to relocation and accommodation of staff, the use of the facility, electricity supply, energy consumption and green building initiatives. The committee was particularly impressed by the range of energy and water conservation measures proposed for the new facility and was pleased with the high quality of the evidence submitted by the Reserve Bank, which assisted greatly in the speedy completion of the inquiry. The committee has no hesitation in recommending that the proposed work proceed, at the estimated cost of $38 million. I would like to take this opportunity to thank my committee colleagues and all those involved in the five inquiries, and I commend the reports to the House.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, I present the following report: Report No. 403âAccess of Indigenous Australians to law and justice services.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâOn behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, I have just presented the committeeâs Report No. 403, Access of Indigenous Australians to law and justice services. The terms of reference were adopted and the inquiry commenced in the previous parliament, when the committee was capably chaired by Bob Charles and his deputy, the member for Sydney, Tanya Plibersek. Two ongoing members of the sectional committee, the current deputy chair, Sharon Grierson, and Senator John Hogg, provided important continuity to the inquiry over the two parliaments.

speech.para: The committeeâs inquiry examined the delivery of legal services to Indigenous Australians from the perspective of providers and their clients. Of particular concern to the committee was the access that Indigenous Australians have to family and civil law services in cases where the safety of individuals is threatened by criminal activity, such as family violence.

This report makes 17 recommendations for the government to consider that build upon programs already in place. The committee has recognised the governmentâs doubling of resources to the Family Violence Protection Legal Services program over the last financial year as an important response to family violence in Indigenous communities and has recommended a further expansion of these services to people living in urban areas. While the committee is in no way opposed to the holistic response to victims of family violence, incorporating services such as counselling, it has recommended that family violence protection legal services be recognised primarily as providers of legal representation and advice to persons at risk of violence, who must be assured of their full rights to protection and compensation under the law.

The importance of expert staff in providing legal services to Indigenous Australians should not be underestimated. To this end, the committee has recommended an investigation into and review of comparative rates of remuneration for staff of Indigenous-specific providers of legal services and of publicly funded mainstream providers. There is also room for increased cooperation and coordination between Indigenous-specific and mainstream service providers to promote mutual benefits to staff in both types of organisations.

In conclusion, I would like to express the committeeâs appreciation to those people who contributed to the inquiry by preparing submissions and giving evidence at public hearings. I particularly want to thank the people of the community of Yuendumu in the Northern Territory for their hospitality and their frankness. It was an example of how cultural law and common law can work together for outcomes in the community. I wish to thank all members of the sectional committee involved for their time and dedication in conducting this inquiry. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâAs Deputy Chair of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, I am also pleased to draw the attention of the House to our recent report No. 403, Access of Indigenous Australians to law and justice services. This reportâs recommendations give government clear direction for the future provision of Indigenous law and justice services. The report strongly recommends the acceptance of separate and specific requirements for the three main areas of legal servicesâfamily, civil and criminal lawâmatched of course by adequate funding. It draws attention to the tendency for legal representation services to be directed primarily at those facing criminal charges and possible incarceration.

speech.para: In the interests of women and children, the family violence prevention legal services so needed in both urban and rural Indigenous communities must be consistently accessible and available. The committee received evidence that from 1991 to 2001 the number of Australian women in custody increased by 147 per cent. Indigenous women were included in that figure. The corresponding increase for Indigenous women alone was 225.8 per cent. To us, it was very evident that services are needed. In my own region, the Many Rivers Aboriginal Legal Service explained that the increase in the incarceration of Indigenous women was a response to high incidences of family violence and child sexual assault. They said:

quote.para: ... we are starting to see the flow-through into older ages of a lot of child victims of sexual assault, physical assault and systems abuse from having been made state wards and left high and dry.

speech.para: We have much to achieve in providing for women and children and in healing the harm that past policies have done to the Indigenous people in this country. No stronger evidence of that was presented than that at Dubbo, where sadly we were part of the grief and despair around a death in custody at that time. For the committee members, it was a very poignant and certainly pointed reminder that we have much to do in representing Indigenous people.

Ways for government to adequately respond to the problems of staff recruitment and retention were identified in the report. Comparable pay rates, exchange programs, scholarships bonded to regional service, and assisted training and development plans for paralegal community support workers were all recommended, as were the better coordination of legal services and the sharing of resources. I draw particular attention, as the chair did, to some wonderful initiatives towards multiagency policies and policing in Western Australia, and I thank those involved for their initiative, their innovation and their commitment. Many service providers strongly expressed their concerns that the governmentâs new tendering system may compromise Indigenous ownership of legal services and Indigenous participation. But, pleasingly, it seems that the government has heeded those concerns, with successful tenderers thus far in Queensland, Victoria and Western Australia all being Aboriginal legal services.

It was truly a privilege to be invited by the people of Yuendumu to visit their community. Life experiences reinforce that local solutions work best, and the self-determined initiatives to overcome petrol sniffing, domestic violence and antisocial behaviour by youth that the people of Yuendumu have devised are exemplary. There is no place in government for programs of paternal benevolence such as the recently endorsed petrol for parenting measures, but there is a real place for taking notice of Indigenous communities when they pose local solutions to problems that eat away at their communityâs prosperity. I thank the people of Yuendumu. I was touched by their wisdom and by their commitment to their kin and community.

Recent media articles have raised concerns amongst the community that committees do not achieve real effectiveness in shaping government policy. I am proud to say that this report and this inquiry have already been effective. This report is a tribute to the committeeâs secretariat, particularly Dr Glen Worthington, and to all those who submitted to and supported the committee in its deliberations. I would also endorse the chairâs acknowledgements and appreciation. I can say that this was perhaps one of the too few experiences that we have in this House that motivate us to achieve more through our work here as parliamentarians. I commend the report to the House.

subdebateinfo.title: Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Crime Commission

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Crime Commission, I present the committeeâs report on the examination of the Australian Crime Commissionâs annual report 2003-04 together with the evidence received by the committee. I move that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: âI seek leave of the House to make a short statement.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Crime Commission, I present the committeeâs report on the examination of the Australian Crime Commissionâs annual report 2003-04. The Australian Crime Commissionâs annual report was presented out of session on 21 December 2004 and was tabled in both houses on 8 February 2005, in accordance with section 61 of the Australian Crime Commission Act 2002. The duties of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Crime Commission are prescribed under section 55 of the Australian Crime Commission Act 2002. These duties include examining each annual report of the Australian Crime Commission and reporting to the parliament on any matter appearing in or arising out of any such annual report.

speech.para: In the course of its scrutiny of the Australian Crime Commission report, the committee held a number of hearings in Canberra on 17 March and wrote to a number of individuals and organisations, inviting them to comment on the annual report. We received seven submissions as well as a number of letters that expressed satisfaction with the operation of the Australian Crime Commission. This yearâs Australian Crime Commission report is significant in that its reporting period covers the first full year of the commissionâs operation. It gives the committee, the parliament and the electorate the opportunity to evaluate the progress of the Australian Crime Commission towards its stated objective of âreducing incidence and impact of serious and organised criminal activityâ.

The committee draws the Houseâs attention to a number of recommendations made in the report that are designed to provide more public information about the Australian Crime Commissionâs operation. They include a recommendation that the Australian Crime Commission consider the release of public versions of key research, including a declassified version of the informative picture of criminality. The committee has also recommended that the Australian Crime Commission review the legal and administrative arrangements governing information on its intelligence networks and that it brief the committee on the results. To make some of the performance indicators more informative for the committee, the parliament and the community, the committee has included recommendation 4:

quote.para: ... continued refinement of the performance measures, including an explanation of the significance of quantitative and qualitative indicators.

speech.para: Recommendation 5 also concerns performance indicators. The committee has recommended that those performance indicators relating to criminal intelligence operations include, subject to reasonable security considerations, how priority is given to matters submitted to the Australian Crime Commission board for consideration.

In making these recommendations, our committee is acutely aware of the necessarily confidential nature of the work of the Australian Crime Commission; there is a fine line to be drawn between information which must be kept confidential for operational reasons and that which can be released for general use. However, the committee considers that the recommendations made in this report will not compromise the Australian Crime Commission in any way and will provide a greater understanding of the work and achievements of the commission.

In conducting its evaluation of the annual report, the committee acknowledges the assistance of the chairman of the ACC board, Commissioner Mick Keelty, the CEO, Mr Alistair Milroy, and officers of the Australian Crime Commission. Throughout the reporting period, the ACC has provided considerable assistance to the committee through written reports and briefings as well as through verbal presentations. The commissionâs willingness to assist the committee has been of great assistance and has contributed to a transparent and cooperative relationship. The committee would like to acknowledge also the considerable assistance of Professor John McMillan, the Commonwealth Ombudsman, and his staff. I also take this opportunity to thank the secretariat staff for the consistent support they have given to the committee.

Finally, I take this opportunity to inform the House that, following discussions with the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Ellison, the committee has agreed to conduct a statutory evaluation of the operation of the Australian Crime Commission Act, pursuant to section 61 of that act. This inquiry will call for submissions in the near future. It will be an excellent opportunity to examine the adequacy of the act to provide a practical working framework for the Australian Crime Commission in a criminal environment, which is not only national but also transnational in character.

debateinfo.title: ENVIRONMENT AND HERITAGE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2005

talk.start.para: âWhen I began my speech prior to question time, I did not get through to the completion of my amendment, so I might start at the beginning again. I move:

motion.para: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

item.para: âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House:
(1)Â Â notes that:

item.label: (a)
item.para: the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Amendment Act 2003 received bi-partisan support as it built constructively on the Ozone Protection legislation of the Hawke and Keating Governments;

item.label: (b)
item.para: the licensing process for the air conditioning and refrigerant industry being undertaken by an industry board (appointed by the Minister) is the keystone of the proposed ozone and synthetic greenhouse gas emission minimisation program;

item.label: (c)
item.para: the licensing regime for 50,000 tradespeople commences on 1 July 2005; and
(2)Â Â is concerned that, as a result of unnecessary delays caused by the Minister for the Environment;

item.label: (a)
item.para: the national industry board for the air-conditioning and refrigerant industry was belatedly appointed on 31 May 2005, six months after it was expected to be announced and only one month before the new licensing regime begins;

item.label: (b)
item.para: there was widespread frustration and confusion in the industry because the reforms proposed by the Act were delayed; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: the environmental improvements which are the rationale for the 2003 Act have not been achievedâ.

speech.para: I note that a very similar second reading amendment was passed by the Senate without any dissent being recorded. Clearly, there must be some concern amongst the ministerâs own Senate colleagues over his handling of this issue; otherwise, the government would have argued against the minister being criticised for causing unnecessary delays in the appointment of the industry board. Also, you would have thought the government would have supported the minister against criticisms that he had not achieved the environmental improvements which are the rationale for the 2003 act. Clearly, the criticisms are well founded, and that is why the Senate voted as it did.

The Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 proposes amendments to two acts: the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 and the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act 2001. The proposed amendments to the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act are relatively uncontroversial and are of a housekeeping nature. They ensure that a person importing or exporting used HCFC or methyl bromide has either a used substances licence or a controlled substances licenceânot both, as could be the case under the existing act. It also applies the same controls and reporting requirements to anyone who sets up a synthetic greenhouse gasâSGGâmanufactur-ing operation in Australia as those applying to SGG importers.

The amendments to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act 2001 permit the sale of a disused scout hall in Mosman and a land swap to replace the lost public space. These are uncontroversial and have the support of the New South Wales government. The Sydney Harbour Federation Trust legislation is legislation that I spoke on when it was introduced. The harbour is the jewel in Sydneyâs crown, and I, as someone who was born there and loves Sydney Harbour, certainly believe that Sydney is the jewel in Australiaâs crown. Anything we can do to protect and enhance the Sydney Harbour National Park and the public space around the harbour is to the benefit of all Australians. On this side of the House, we support these minor changes to the act.

I want to confine my comments today primarily to the changes that are effected by the amendments to the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act. The main industries affected by the amendments to this act are the refrigeration and airconditioning industries and the fumigation industry. In Australia, the regulation of the fluorocarbon gases used in the refrigerant industry started when the Hawke Labor government introduced the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 to phase out CFCs and implement the Montreal protocol. CFCs, as everyone came to know, were causing global ozone depletion or, to put it another way, a hole in the ozone layer. International action on this important issue was urgent, and the Hawke Labor government acted quickly and decisively to phase out the import and manufacture of CFCs by 1 January 1996.

Recently I had the pleasure, at an Australian-Israel Chamber of Commerce function in Sydney, to hear Dr David Suzuki talk about climate change and the challenge that it presented to us. He drew parallels with the issue of CFCs and their impact on the ozone layer and how, originally, it was thought that these revolutionary consumer items were going to bring great benefit to us. It took time for the danger that CFCs were causing to the ozone layer and the threat that they posed to the global environment to be recognised. There is a parallel with the current debate on climate change and the danger that greenhouse gases are causing to the climate and, therefore, not just to our environment but also to our potential economic future.

I am very pleased and proud to say that the Hawke Labor governmentâs decision to phase out CFCs by 1 January 1996 was achieved with strong community support and without significant disruption to industry. It is a great practical example of taking action that is necessary, rather than finding reasons not to take action as a global community. The Hawke Labor governmentâs actions are in stark contrast to the complacency of the Howard government when it comes to climate change. In 1995, the Keating Labor government continued this good work and introduced the Ozone Protection Amendment Act 1995, which included controls on HCFCs, reflecting their inclusion in the Montreal protocol. HCFCs are also an ozone-depleting gas, albeit considerably less so than CFCs. They will be phased out by 2020 at a rate considerably in advance of Australiaâs international obligations. This great result was achieved because the Keating government worked with industry to do the best that it could, not merely just the minimum. Again, the Keating Labor governmentâs actions are in stark contrast to the abject complacency and incompetence of the Howard government when it comes to taking action on climate change.

The Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Amendment Act 2003 included controls on HFCs and was seen as a useful step by the industry. It received bipartisan support. The legislation will minimise emission of HFC gases which are controlled by the Kyoto protocol but previously uncontrolled in Australia. HFC gases are mainly used as refrigerants. These gases do not deplete the ozone layer but do have a significant greenhouse warming potential. End use controlsâthat is, minimising the emissions of these gases to atmosphere through sound industrial practicesâare contained in the regulations dated 16 December 2004. The controls are put in place by improving training and other standards in the industry, certifying tradespersons and inspecting associated work. Without an appropriate licence a tradesperson will not be permitted to purchase refrigerants. Companies buying and selling refrigerants or using refrigerants in a manufacturing process will also have to be appropriately licensed, abide by agreed standards and be subject to inspection. This licensing process is a keystone of the actâs emission minimisation program and is to be undertaken by an industry board to be appointed by the minister. The board was to be directed by the Department of the Environment and Heritage. This approach received strong industry support and emerged from a consultation and review process held over a number of years. Somewhat scandalously, the minister did not appoint the industry board until three weeks agoâon 31 May 2005. With nobody to put the program in place until three weeks ago, the legislation passed way back in late 2003 has not, up to this point, produced a tangible environmental benefit.

According to ABC news reports in February, the appointment of a national industry board was derailed after lobbying from a small section of the industry in Western Australia. After achieving bipartisan support for such important legislation and also getting industry support for national regulation, the minister backflipped and wanted to rewrite the whole thing. This step was taken without consultation with industry, and the minister refused to meet with industry representatives. The minister stated that he wanted to take in âregional and sectoralâ considerations. I think everyone here knows what that is code for when this minister and other ministers in the Howard government speak about âsectoralâ considerations. The minister delayed the whole licensing regime for six months while he tried to find a way to accommodate these parochial interests. Not surprisingly, the ministerâs approach was severely criticised by the industry.
Senior people in the refrigeration industry could not hold back their anger and frustration with the minister. The editorial in the April 2005 edition of Climate Control News stated:

quote.para: The Ministerâs decisionâ

speech.para: not to proceed with a single national boardâ

quote.para: has left a broad cross section of the Aussie refrigeration industry in varying degrees of anger, frustration and confusion.

speech.para: What an editorialâanger, frustration and confusion caused by government inaction. But the editorial had a bit more to say than that. It went on:

quote.para: But the real loser in all this is the very thing the whole process was set up to saveâthe environment. ... Despite being millions of dollars and four years down the track, not a single gram of carbon dioxide equivalent has been saved from entering the ether.
Like Nero all those centuries ago, the earth is burning while Campbell fiddles.

talk.start.para: Ms Julie Bishop interjectingâ
âThe Minister for Ageing laughs at the predicament that the minister finds himself in.
âI laughed at the Shakespearean overtones.

âMinister, that was an editorial from the April 2005 edition of Climate Control News. It is not from the Labor Party and it is not from the trade union movement; it is from the main industry newsletterâpeople on the ground who know what the impact of this governmentâs inaction has been. Also quoted in the April edition of Climate Control News was Rod King, president of the Air Conditioning and Refrigeration Equipment Manufacturers Associationânote: the association, not the union; this is the industry. He said:

quote.para: There have been press reports that the Minister is considering establishing multiple boardsâbut we can find no justification or rationale for this approach. We have just spent years getting to the point where we have comprehensive national regulation of refrigerants and now there seems to be a move to implement accreditation on a state basis.

speech.para: But Mr King went on to say a bit more as well. He said:

quote.para: This approach is completely inconsistent with other Federal Government reforms, such as the move towards a unitary industrial relations system.

speech.para: But who could expect consistency from this government? They have been up at the International Whaling Commission arguing that secret ballots are a bad thing, and yet in industrial relations, when it comes to workers having control over their own environment, they are pro secret ballots.

So it is consistency that is needed when it comes to the environment, just as on the issue of the Kyoto protocol we have a different position from that which we had on the Montreal protocol. By our not being a part of the most significant global effort on the most important environmental challenge facing the global community, that of avoiding dangerous climate change, we are undermined when we talk to the international community about issues that everyone here would agree withâeveryone except the parliamentary secretary for tourismâwhich is that whaling is a practice that should be consigned to the dustbin of history.
We need consistency when it comes to the environment if we are going to be able to achieve real gains. Alan Woodhouse, the CEO of the Australian Refrigeration Council, another industry body, stated:

quote.para: We are all very disappointed. The Government called for tenders to fulfil a single national industry board. We responded with a very thorough tender that complied with all the specifications. Now, nearly 12 months later the Department of Environment and Heritage is abandoning the original tender and the structure and outcome from work put in over the last three years. Why?

speech.para: Alan Woodhouse then noted he was âunderstandably bewildered and upsetâ by the ministerâs actions.

In attempting to overturn the national approach and protect parochial interests at the expense of a consistent national approach, the minister has threatened the underlying philosophy behind this important legislation, which enjoyed bipartisan support in this House. The delays in appointing the industry board exposed the airconditioning and refrigeration industry to severe consequences as the industry board issues the licences which will be required by law for 50,000 tradespeople after 1 July 2005.

So you have got a system that is going to apply to 50,000 people in 10 days time being debated in this House now, when the board was appointed at the end of last month, on 31 May. This is an extraordinary performance even by the ministerâs own standards when it comes to taking decisive action on issues of environment and heritage. And that is why Labor is moving the second reading amendment today. It is also possibly why the Senate carried the second reading amendment yesterday without the government members even calling for a vote or expressing opposition to our amendment.

talk.start.para: âAmazing. Embarrassed, were they?

âAs the member for Throsby, the parliamentary secretary for environment and heritage for the Labor Party, says, I think they were embarrassed by this performance, because the whole purpose of the licensing regime is to minimise ozone-damaging gases and other greenhouse gas emissions. There has been widespread frustration and confusion in the airconditioning and refrigeration industry because the reforms proposed by the act have been delayed by the minister. More than 50,000 tradespeople in the airconditioning and refrigeration industry have been frustrated and confused as to what the industryâs licensing regime is. It is a scandal that the environmental improvements which are the rationale for the bipartisan 2003 act have not been achieved. Once again this shows the minister and the Howard government are just not serious about taking practical steps to avoid dangerous climate change. The Howard government is slow, it is reluctant and it is complacent when it comes to tackling the issue of climate change. National leadership is needed to avoid dangerous climate change, but instead Australia has a lethargic, tired approach.

speech.para: Climate change caused by the burning of fossil fuels and greenhouse gases is changing Australiaâs climate right now. Australia is at one of the most important crossroads in its history. What we do in the next 10 years about these issues will determine the fate of our economy and our environment for the rest of this century and beyond. The extended four-year drought gripping Australia is the most dramatic example of climate change to hit our continent. Experts predict Australia is going to get progressively drier over the coming century because of changes to our climate caused by greenhouse pollution. According to the CSIRO, climate change will only worsen drought conditions.

The Prime Ministerâs decision not to ratify the Kyoto protocolâhaving had the former Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill, sign the Kyoto protocol in 1997 and declare it a win for the environment and a win for jobsâis an outrage.

talk.start.para: Mr Lloyd interjectingâ

âThe member for Robertson, sitting opposite, proclaims confusion about jobs and the Kyoto protocol. But I was quoting the Prime Minister from 1997âthat is what he said. He was right then but he is wrong now when it comes to taking decisive action, because the decision not to ratify the Kyoto protocol is stopping new investment in technology which would reduce greenhouse gases, create jobs and move Australia to a cleaner, more secure energy future.

speech.para: The Kyoto protocol is not perfect, but it is an essential first step and shows what can be done when the international community works together. It is a global solution to a global problem. Not ratifying Kyoto means Australia cannot contribute to how the world is dealing with the climate crisis. One hundred and forty other nations are having a say, but we are not. We have no credibility in the discussions over emission reductions in future international agreements, which will take effect after 2012. Quite clearly much deeper cuts will be necessary. In a passionate speech in Britain recently, the international Chairman of Shell, Lord Oxburgh, stated:

quote.para: We have roughly 45 years. And if we start NOW, not in 10 or 15 yearsâ time, we have a chance of hitting those greenhouse gas reduction targets. But weâve got to start now. We have no time to lose ... The boat is sinking, and we have to use everything that we possibly can.

speech.para: It is extraordinary that companies such as Shell and BP are so far ahead of the position taken by someone like the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, who thinks that climate change is not really happening. People in industry, including those industries which have contributed greatly to climate change, understand very well that the world has to change. Certainly the frustration of the refrigeration industry is another example of the overwhelming frustration felt by those who recognise the dangers of climate change and want to do something about it. That is what the second reading amendment that we have moved today is about. My colleague the member for Throsby will second it. It is a fair and balanced amendment, and I ask members to join with the Senate in supporting it.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âIs the amendment seconded?
âI second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

âThis afternoon is a timely moment to reflect on Australiaâs achievements with greenhouse gases. Obviously, the Montreal protocol pertains to the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 that we are debating today and the amendments to the legislation which, as we can see, have support from both sides of the House and are relatively minor. The Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 needs to be amended in three or four ways. It will bring licensing of domestic producers into line with importers and exporters. I think that is appropriate. There will not be the complexity of requiring both used and controlled substance licences. I think that is also appropriate. Finally, the process of reporting to the minister on when these products are imported and exported will now be brought into line for domestic producers and manufacturers. I think that is all relatively non-controversial.

speech.para: Right now is an excellent time to remember exactly what has been achieved by Australia in reducing the use of these gases. The gases have important roles in industry. The most obvious one is their quarantine application. I experienced that myself when we brought material back from a recent visit from Papua New Guinea which was fumigated. There are quarantine uses for these heavy gases. There are the non-quarantine applications which pertain to the Montreal protocol. That protocol only pertains to non-quarantine uses. In the areas of refrigeration, use in the manufacture of foams, use as solvents and airconditioning, we have seen significant reductions.

The point I make today is that had we simply stuck to the bare bones of the protocol we would be importing today 240 tonnes of methyl bromide. But, no, we have done significantly better at 160 tonnes and I think that should be acknowledged. If we hung purely and simply on the symbolism of signing to a protocol and doing not an ounce better, then we would be performing significantly more poorly than we actually are today. I would point out that it is not always government, whether we are in power or opposition, that should be congratulated for those achievements but industry themselves that go out there and go one step better than the protocol. I think that is a fine allegory for the debate we are having around Kyoto where our reductions and emissions are in line with achieving the 2008-2012 objective of being aâ

talk.start.para: âSo why donât you ratify it?

âBecause we are doing it and industry is doing it without that ratification down to 108 per cent of emissions in 1995. These gases also have applications in medicine and science. Heavy gases are used in eye surgery where a millilitre of heavy gas is used to reattach retinas. I do not see that one as threatening the ozone layer, but it is important to remember that there is still, as we reduce the use of these substances, a notable but very small tail where they will still be used. The HCFCs I hope will be phased out within a year or two, but methyl bromide which has some more essential applications one would suspect will be used perhaps early into the next decade.

speech.para: I have made my point already about the use of HCFCs being 160 tonnes of importation. Methyl bromide is at 145 tonnes and that is predicted to fall next year to 66 tonnes and the following year to 42 tonnes. That is a substantial reduction and a credit again to industry and also to two bodies that have been running now for some time. I refer to the National Halon Bank, which has been responsible for collecting about 1,985 tonnes of halon. While a small amount of that will be required to be saved for aviation use, the rest is being cleaned up and either preserved or destroyed. The Halon Bank has been a very effective way of avoiding around 160 million tonnes of ozone being destroyed in the atmosphere.

The other body is Refrigerant Reclaim Australia, which has been responsible for collecting refrigeration gasesâaround 1,000 tonnes. Some of these are extremely ozone damaging. We are talking about one kilogram of these gases being able to destroy up to 50 tonnes of ozone. When you think that this molecule is only present in perhaps three or four molecules per million and has such an important role in blocking ultraviolet C and effectively in important health applications, there are very good reasons for keeping ozone intact. What you have effectively done with that reclamation is to avoid around six million tonnes of COÂ² going into the atmosphere. They are two very good success stories for the work that has been done over recent years.

I turn my attention to the member for Grayndler, who spent most of the time allotted to him focusing on effectively cobbling together some opinions of individuals who are unhappy with the speed of the process. And there was a great fixation on board appointments. But what is far more important than anything is the fact that we have had significant reductionsâamong the best in the worldâand have got the use, the importation and the collection of some of these heavy gases to be world standard. That is really where the action is. The action is not what has been signed and what has not been signed, but what is happening on the ground. For that reason, I believe that industry itself deserves an enormous amount of credit.

Industry itself is now finding alternative heavy gases to use. In some cases that is very difficult, and the federal government has set out some critical use exemptions which are very important. This again speaks to the fact that, if you have a government prepared to work with industry rather than using a protocol in a punitive way, you do not need to have that luxury of sitting back and saying, âWe have signed and that was enough. We have achieved what was signed off on a protocol, and that is all we intend to do.â That a constructive approach goes much further than what one would sign up to in a protocol is evidenced here with Australiaâs achievements in relation to these heavy gases. That is analogous to the situation with the Kyoto protocol.

We now have significant reductions. There is still HCFC reliant equipment and machinery that will be using heavy gasesâin small amountsâuntil the end of its lifespan. That is an important concession made so that industry is able to comply, to go about finding alternatives. But it is not done in a punitive way; it is done with a discrete allocation of time for industry to be able to respond. That is really important.

About 5,100 ozone-depleting potential tonnes of material are being prevented from being released into the atmosphere. Again, that is a significant improvement on what is happening in a number of situations around the world in a number of economies. The achievements of the Halon Bank, as I have pointed out, are impressive, as is the reclamation of refrigerant gases. Industry is supportive of all of these three amendments.

There is no doubt that, of these ozone-depleting substances, some also have greenhouse impacts, but we have seen a movement from some of the highly ozone-damaging substances, with an ozone-depleting effect of about 0.4, down to some HCFCs that are in the realm of about 0.05. That is a significant improvement, and we are seeing that in the outcomes for Australia in being well in front of its obligations due to the Montreal protocol.

I believe it is industry that should be congratulated for those achievements; it is the government that has continued to tighten up legislation as required. For each of those reasons, I speak in support of the amendments today. We have excellent end use regulations, so there is provision there for industry, and industry appreciates the flexibility, but in the end I would say that it is not the small arguments that are contained in these amendments that are important. What is truly important is the eventual emission reductions from Australia, for they are world class.

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Bowman for his contribution to the debate on the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. It was quite an erudite scientific and technical explanation, some of which went over my head as I do not have that level of detailed knowledge about the science of the issue and its impacts. But what I did find rather surprising in his contribution was that he failed to respond to the essence of the argument of the member for Grayndler, which was to compare and contrast the international action, with Australiaâs support, to deal with the impacts of the depletion of the ozone layerâhow Australia really led the way in that debate and the actions that have subsequently flowedâwith the total inactivity over the newest global threat that is confronting all of mankind, and that is global warming.

speech.para: The shadow minister was making the point that Australia supported the ratification of the Montreal protocol. But, unfortunately, and much to the regret of people on this side of the House, the Australian government continues to fail to ratify the Kyoto protocol. The Kyoto protocol, as members know, has now been ratified by about 140 developed nations. Only Australia and the United States stand outside the ratification process on an issue that many Australian citizens believe is the greatest threat facing not just our own country but the global community. That was a profound point made by the member for Grayndler.

People on this side of the chamber take great pride in the fact that it was under the Hawke Labor government that this nation took steps to fall into line with the calls that were being made to ensure that we phased out the use of substances that depleted the ozone layer. At that time, the data that was being collected revealed a general thinning of the ozone layer over most of the globe. This included a five to nine per cent depletion over Australia since the 1960s, and it was having very severe impacts over Antarctica. The ozone hole in 2000 was the largest on record. At that time, it measured 32.9 million square kilometresâmore than three times the size of Australia. It is not surprising that the Australian community at large was very concerned about the impacts of that depletion and the far-reaching consequences for human health.

As the member for Bowman rightly said, governments around the world began the phasing out of CFCs, halons and other ozone-depleting chemicals. Those chemicals had been widely used as refrigerants, aerosol propellants and foam-blowing agents. The success of the action under the Montreal protocol is now evidenced by the fact that eminent scientists now believe that the prospects for the long-term recovery of the ozone layer are improving. Non-essential consumption of major ozone depleting substances did in fact slow down during the early 1990s, and if we continue to give this issue our best efforts some estimate that the hole in the ozone layer could be fully recoverable by around 2050.

Interestingly enough, had we not taken action as a nation in concert with the rest of the international community, studies seem to suggest that by 2050 ozone depletion would be 10 times worse than current levels and UVB radiation would have resulted in an estimated 19 million additional cases of non-melanoma skin cancer, 1.5 million more cases of melanoma and 129 million more cases of eye cataracts. The seriousness of the situation compelled an international response at that time. I am very pleased that our country was part of that international effort. It is much to the shame of the Howard government and the Australian nation that the same commitment to solving another international and global crisis is not being made by this government.

The member for Bowman rightly acknowledgesâand I want to say a little more about thisâthat the substitute gases, the more ozone benign gases, are in fact themselves contributing to the greenhouse impact. I recently read a UN report which was headed âSafeguarding the ozone layer and the global climate systemâ. You would assume that the substitution of ozone friendly gases would not cause any irreparable harm and any consequent flow-on effects. But in fact what this and other reports are suggesting is that in phasing out CFCs, halons and other ozone depleting chemicals we have replaced them with alternatives that are having a marked impact on global warming.

Like CFCs, some of the alternatives, such as the group referred to as HCFCs, HFCs and PFCs, are themselves powerful greenhouse gases. In the words of the Secretary-General of the World Meteorological Organisation:

quote.para: Although climate change and ozone destruction are essentially different issues, our use of certain chemicals links them together.

speech.para: He goes on to argue:

quote.para: We must continuously monitor, undertake research and improve how we manage this group of extremely useful substances, which is implicated in not one, but two of the major environmental problems we have ever known.â

speech.para: To limit their damaging effects governments have included two of the CFC alternatives in the 1992 UN climate change convention and in the Kyoto protocol, under which signatory countries must reduce their emissions from a basket of six greenhouse gases by the period 2008 to 2012. This basket contains the alternative HFCs and PFCs. The contribution that CFCs and their replacements and other ozone-depleting substances currently make to global warming is estimated to be about five per cent of humanityâs total greenhouse gas emissions.

I raise this issue because the major concern in the public debate is with the contribution of carbon to greenhouse warming. In fact, the substitutes that we are now using to continue to protect the ozone layer are themselves partly contributing to greenhouse gas emissions and global warming. This report went on to recommend some simple and commonsense practices that should be put in place to minimise the impact of the ozone friendly chemicals on global warming. The report says that containment can be improved to prevent leaks, evaporation and emissions of unintended by-products.

About 65 per cent of todayâs total emissions from this group of chemicals still comes from CFCs, mainly from existing refrigeration and airconditioning equipment. Reducing leaks from these sources could cut greenhouse gas emissions, benefiting both the ozone layer and climate change. Amounts of the chemicals needed in equipment can be reduced and there should be more end-of-life recovery, recycling and destruction of HFCs and PFCs. Since virtually all ozone depleting substances and their replacements are now used in closed systems, they are not emitted until years or even decades after being produced. Large amounts of CFCs still exist in current refrigeration and airconditioning equipment and in insulating foams from which they can leak or evaporate. Later, as the report indicates, when the equipment is finally decommissioned, these gases can be released into the atmosphere.

While I commend the bipartisan approach that we have seen in the past in phasing out ozone depleting substances, many of the alternative gases that are now being used, whilst ozone benign, are potent greenhouse gases contributing to the greenhouse effect. I point out, as the member for Grayndler did, that there was a concerted international effort led by our national government on the ozone layer, but on the issue of global warming this national government is missing in action by its failure to ratify the Kyoto protocol. So, in that context, we have to be even more vigilant that there are systems in place to monitor the impact on global warming of these ozone benign gases.

On the specifics of the legislation, the member for Grayndler went through the lead-up and the details contained in the amendments so I do not want to dwell on the detail for too long, other than to say that the implementation of the proposed licensing regime and the creation of the new council has been another example of a botched effort on behalf of the minister who has overall responsibility for protection of Australiaâs environmental conditions. The new refrigeration licensing system is to replace existing state systems and, as the member for Grayndler rightly pointed out in moving his amendments to the bill, the industry has experienced a litany of delays and frustrations in getting the system into place.

There is no doubt this has caused concern and frustration in the industry, and the comments the member for Grayndler made, drawing on a number of industry sources and industry bodies, I think make that very clear. Here we are today in parliament debating a piece of legislation that is supposed to come into effect on 1 July.
