I do note, though, that there are now transitional arrangements under the licensing regime because there is no way that people are going to have their licences properly in place by the operative date of 1 July when something like 50,000 tradespeople are going to be incorporated as part of this new regime. There are also many in the industry who are querying the cost of the licencesâ$320, I think it is, for a two-year licence. And some who may not have the requisite trade qualifications are going to go through transitional arrangements that will recognise prior learning, however ill-defined that is at the moment.

So it has been quite a botch-up in terms of administrative arrangements. That botch-up is most clearly revealed in the delays that the member for Grayndler outlined in relation to the creation of the Australian Refrigeration Council, the body that was supposed to operate as a service provider under contract to the government. Its main role is to issue the licences and authorisations and to undertake compliance audits. Quite clearly, there was a lot of parochial and sectional pressure on the minister, most notably by the Motor Trade Association over in the west which attempted to derail the national system that was originally outlined in the bill. One has to ask about the special privileges this industry body had in applying the kind of pressure that has seen the new council announced only very recentlyâon 31 May. So here we have a totally new body announced at the end of May that is supposed to oversee a process to license around 50,000 tradespeople between now and 1 July, and yet this legislation has still not being carried by this parliament. It would be hard to find a clearer example of maladministration and botch-up than in the arrangements for the new licensing regime that is to apply.

We do support the essence of the bill, while our amendments clearly note the failures of the government and refer to the problems that these delays and pressures are causing in the industry. There is a clear parallel between the action Australia took when the worldâs community understood the impacts of the thinning of the ozone layer around the world, when we were at the forefront of the international action that has seen the damage to the ozone layer being held at bay with the possibility of the damage being reversed, and the lack of action by this government over a similar global crisis, the crisis of global warming, where we do not have the courage to go along with the rest of the developed nations and ratify the Kyoto protocol. When this bill is passed I look forward to being reassured by the government that we will have proper monitoring in place to look at the impacts that the more ozone friendly chemicals are actually having on global warming and climate change. There should be no trade-offs in my opinion between saving the ozone layer and minimising the very negative impacts of climate change. They are two global issues of equal importance and you cannot have any trade-offs between saving the ozone layer and minimising climate change.

Lastly, I ask the members of the government to think seriously about the benefits that would flow to the Australian economy, to the Australian environment and to the health and wellbeing of our communities if the government were to do the right thing and accept the challenge put forward in the member for Grayndlerâs private memberâs bill, which had a second reading in the House the other day. It is a bill that would see this government belatedly recognising the impact and the negative consequences of climate change and actually doing the right thing and ratifying the Kyoto protocol. I think the Montreal protocol showed that the international community working together can have a major influence on serious global environmental issues and I think ratification of the Kyoto protocol would show this government belatedly accepting the need for Australia to join again with the rest of the international community in dealing with a major environmental issue confronting mankind today.

talk.start.para: âIt is widely recognised by the Australian community that the coalition government is the greenest government in Australiaâs history.
âYou have got to be joking!

âI am not joking, my friend. Since 1996 we have spent an unprecedented amount of money repairing the impact of 200 years of European settlement in this country. We have had the Natural Heritage Trust and an enormous range of other objectives, and the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 is yet another way that the Howard government is doing what it can to make sure we appreciate collectively as a country that we do hold our nation in trust for future generations.

speech.para: Australia is performing strongly in moves to phase out the use of hydrochlorofluorocarbonsâHCFCsâas set out in the internationally accepted standards of the Montreal protocol. It follows our commendable results in phasing out other more harmful ozone-depleting gases. Chlorofluorocarbons, the propellants that were so talked about in the 1980s, have not been in use in Australia since 1996, the year that the Labor government was swept from the Treasury benches and a year ahead of the time frames of the Montreal schedule. The almost as equally damaging gas, halon, once used as a coolant in refrigerators and fire-extinguishing systems, has not been used in this country since 1993, also a year ahead of the Montreal timetable. I am not, however, suggesting that this side of politics has a monopoly on interest in our environment. I believe that one of the important steps forward in recent years has been that everyone, both in the political arena and more generally, has appreciated that as a nation we simply could not go on as we were and that we had to look very closely at our environment and appreciate that obviously we must make sure that the environment is appropriate for succeeding generations of Australians. Methyl chloroformâused as a solvent for adhesives and for metal degreasingâwas phased out completely by 1996.

These three examples give some indication as to how serious Australia is to end the use of ozone-depleting gases for the good of the environment. The Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 will further help Australiaâs efforts by improving the licensing and administration of the guidelines for importers and exporters of hydrochlorofluorocarbons or used methyl bromide. The bill proposes to amend the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 by modifying the requirement of importers and exporters of these two gases so that they only require a used substances licence. This mirrors similar actions taken for chlorofluorocarbonsâCFCsâand halons, which I mentioned earlier and which are both now out of circulationâquite appropriatelyâin this country. The bill will effectively halve the licensing requirements for importers of HCFCs and methyl bromide gas.

Those who may be wondering about the impact of the amendments can rest easy knowing that the environmental protection afforded by the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 will not be compromised in any way by the amendments currently before the House. The bill will help fix what is largely a number of anomalies that were overlooked during the drafting of the legislation in 1989. I honestly do not know why so many mistakes have been made in the drafting of legislation over the years. I know that our parliamentary draftsmen do have a very high degree of skill, but it is frustrating to see that it is necessary on so many occasions to dot the iâs and cross the tâs and finetune the provisions of legislation which has been enacted in earlier times.

The bill will also ensure reporting conditions for synthetic greenhouse gases that are manufactured in Australia come into line with reporting conditions currently required for imported and exported synthetic greenhouse gases. Hydrochlorofluorocarbons have between one per cent and 10 per cent the ozone-depleting effect of the CFCs that they replaced one decade ago. Usage in Australia of methyl bromide, which is mainly used as a soil fumigant, has been cut back dramatically, by about 70 per cent of 1991 levels. Australia is continuing to investigate alternative gases that have no detrimental environmental impact; however, for some purposes there are regrettably still no viable alternatives. The use of these two gases in limited amounts and in controlled situations is, sadly, presently unavoidable. While the government recognises the environmental impacts of these substances, there is also an economic advantage in their usage. HCFCs are still the most commonly used refrigerants, as well as being widely used in foam-blowing, fire protection and aerosols, while methyl bromide is used as a solvent and, as I have mentioned, in the fumigation industry. However, the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 encourages the usage of recycled or used HCFCs and methyl bromide to further reduce the detrimental effect that these gases are acknowledged to have on the environment. Importing of these used or recycled gases is an important factor in the ongoing phasing out of the use of these substances altogether.

The second part of the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 ensures that part of Sydneyâs valuable historic past is conserved and enhanced. Several landmarks on the harbour reflect the colonial history of the area. They map out the growth of the region in terms of our defence and industry, and the population growth of the young fledgling colony of New South Wales. The areas targeted in this bill include Macquarie Lightstation on South Head, the North Head former artillery school, Woolwich Dock and the adjacent parklands, Snapper Island, Cockatoo Island, the once-bustling marine biological station at Watsons Bay and the defence lands at Middle Head, Georges Heights and Chowder Bay.

The amendments put forward in the bill will help enable the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust to continue to develop its plans for a beautiful parkland. I understand that local residents have already overwhelmingly voiced their support for a proposal that will see a 2,000 square metre block of land owned by the trustâthe site of an unwanted scout hutâallowed to be subdivided and sold off to private purchasers. In some communities, a grand plan such as this might ordinarily attract widespread condemnation, but the Sydney community is an understanding one and it will receive other benefits that balance the sell-off that might appear to outsiders looking in to be of somewhat limited value. In return for the scout hut land sale, three houses will be purchased in Markham Close, with the houses to be removed and the land then incorporated into a spectacular headland park. The cooperation of the community and its support for the insightful plans of the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust will enable the development of an attractive parkland that is both practical in terms of sensible land use and a great place for families to enjoy.

I listened to the political rhetoric of the honourable member for Throsby when she claimed that the government should ratify the Kyoto protocol. It is not in Australiaâs interests to ratify that particular protocol. We are meeting the targets which would have been set out in that protocol, so Australia is actually playing its part. We are simply not going to react to some knee-jerk requirement by members of the opposition that we should ratify a protocol that is clearly not in Australiaâs interests. At the outset I said that the coalition government are the greenest government in Australiaâs history. We do have a proud record. The environmental situation of this nation is infinitely better now than it was when we were elected to office in 1996 and the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 adds to that excellent environmental record. I am pleased to be able to commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âIt is a pleasure to speak to the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. As has been outlined, the purpose of this bill is to amend the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1999 and the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act 2001. Amendments to the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act are of a housekeeping nature. They ensure that a person importing or exporting used hydrochlorofluorocarbons or methyl bromide has either a used substance licence or a controlled substances licenceânot both, as could be the case under the existing actâand apply the same controls and reporting requirements to anyone who sets up a synthetic greenhouse gas manufacturing operation in Australia as those applying to synthetic greenhouse gas importers. Amend-ments to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust Act will permit the sale of some land in Mosman and a land swap to replace lost public space.

speech.para: This is an opportune time to review some of the matters that surround the phenomenon of ozone protection. During my time in this place, I have had a number of opportunities to speak on various bills. Sometimes it is worrying to go back over previous speeches âyou may be a little concerned that you did not keep a consistent line. Having had the opportunity to speak on ozone protection legislation in 1988, 1992, 1995 and 1998, there was a great risk that perhaps I had not been consistent. One thing that has happened when reviewing pieces of legislation is that at each step we, as legislators, have had to react to the developing body of scientific knowledge to do with this phenomenon. Sometimes I think that is not understood. Scientific investigation is very dynamic.

Tonight I wish to go through some of the things that continue to develop our understanding of ozone depletion in the stratosphere which have led to this body of legislation, culminating in the Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 that is to be amended by the bill tonight. Governments of both political persuasions have come to grips with this over the last 17 years. When these environmental phenomena are tackled by global cooperation and in an international way we can have great success.

This phenomenon came to light in the 1980s. Fortunately, we have seen the global community come together and, through the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer, followed by the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer, set down a timetable of achievement, cutting out the production of gases identified as being ozone depleting. I am not going to go over the successes because they have been indicated by a number of people already in this debate. Even if we take the position that the honourable member for Bowman put quite stronglyâthat industry had cooperated and should get a pat on the backâit should be realised that industry is important and has done its part. If we were to look only at Australiaâs success in isolation, like any global phenomenon, we would do an injustice to the way in which we are attempting to protect the planet.

On this side of the chamber we say that through Kyoto we could achieve for climate change and the greenhouse phenomenon what has arisen through the Montreal protocol. It is incongruous that we have this dichotomy where there has been bipartisan support right throughout the 17 years of the Montreal protocol and the 20 years of the Vienna convention. It was never questioned that we should be doing this in an international way through the cooperation we have seen.

Regrettably, when we have seen bipartisan support, we do not really want to go into this territory. But on some of the reviews of the Montreal protocol, this government has tended to side with the United States over, for instance, the Europeans in the way in which implementation timetables have been placed. Traditionally these have been seen to extend the timetables. When Australia decides, it is usually not to go with the earlier target placed on removals by Europeans but to fall into line with the Americans. This is a little disappointing. The Chinese have made considerable strides in meeting their targets and are likely to meet them many years ahead of requirements in the Montreal protocol.

The points I want to make today have been touched upon in other contributions. Back in 1988 we were endeavouring to set in place a timetable which countries could sign up to and which industry was comfortable with. Industry had started on the development of replacement gases. At that stage there was not much discussion about which gases might replace the ozone-depleting gases. As things have developed and as alternatives have come on board, we have studied those alternatives and realised some of the phenomena that occur with the release of those gases into the atmosphere and then their percolating up to the stratosphere. We saw industry developing the alternatives: hydrochlorofluorocarbons, or HCFCs; hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs; and perfluorocarbons, or PFCs. We now know these are powerful greenhouse gases.

We are now tackling ozone depletion by taking measures leading to ozone protection where it intersects with the phenomenon of climate change. It is very important that we realise there is an interconnection. It makes it even more important for the government to understand that, even though this is only one grouping of greenhouse gases, these are important environmental phenomena that are the result of mankindâs use of the planet and they have to be tackled in an international and global way. We have to make sure we understand the phenomena created by synthetic greenhouse gases and that we look at the replacement of those gases with more benign substances which can have the same effect. Ammonia has been suggested as an alternative for refrigerants and mineral wool has been suggested as an alternative to plastic insulating foam.

There is a further intersect about which I was a little surprised. As reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 28 April this year, it has been suggested, in the monitoring of the Arctic ozone layer, that ozone depletion was at its worst recorded levels as a result not just of the percolation of ozone depleting gases but also of climate change itself. It is known that the stratospheric clouds that are over both poles in winter have some involvement in the phenomenon of ozone depletion. It is now being suggested that, because of climate change, the concentrations of stratospheric cloud are greater, and therefore ozone depletion is greater. It is now being suggested that ozone depletion is the result of not only greenhouse gases but also climate change. Increasing ozone depletion is not only caused by the greenhouse gases that are used to replace ozone depleting gases but is also a direct result of climate change. In fact, the European Union is investing $27 million in a five-year project to try to understand this phenomenon.

Returning to where I commenced tonight, I repeat that understanding of this phenomenon requires continuing scientific study. As we go forward, the overlap is getting greater. Given the stage we find ourselves at, in terms of our cooperation with the international community over matters to do with climate change, Australia must understand that it is better for us to be in the international cart that is represented by the Kyoto protocol than outside it, because these are cooperative efforts going forward. There is no reason to suggest that a phenomenon that happens in the Northern Hemisphere, which is increasing ozone depletion and creating ozone âholesââwhich, of course, are not holes but areas with a reduced level of ozoneâwould not be happening in the Southern Hemisphere.

Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, as a Tasmanian you would be aware that the so-called ozone hole in the Antarctic is stretching across not only Tasmania but also mainland Australia. The cost to Australia of not doing anything over the last 17 years would have been astronomical. The direct cost to human health is high, and the cost of the change in habitats and biospheres throughout Australia is also high. We only have to think of the effect of UV rays on plankton in the oceans, and the fine balance in the food chain for aquatic animals, which starts with plankton, to realise that this is a very important area of public policy.

It is not often understood and it has not been repeated in this debate that what we are talking about in the reduction of the production of the gases is one step. The next step is to realise that there are still a lot of CFCsâfor instance, in old refrigeratorsâwhich continue to be refrigerants. All the acts and regulations developed recognise that and have put in place proper procedures for the appropriate removal and storage of these gases from obsolete equipment. But it is often not recognised that some of these gases have very long lives when they reach the stratosphere. It may take anything from months to years for the gases to percolate, but once they get there their lives are over tens of years to hundreds of years. So we are taking action now to attempt to get back to levels measured 40 years ago, which may not happen until the middle of this century. This is an investment to make sure that we are doing things today that will have that longer term advantage. Again, if we contrast this to greenhouse, this is exactly what is being said. These are actions we have to take in our proper stewardship of the environment to ensure that later generations are afforded the protection required. To the extent that these matters require bipartisan agreement I think that, in the main, that has been achieved.

The opposition places before the House its concerns, which are set out in the second reading amendment passed by the Senate when it dealt with this legislation before sending it to us for our deliberations. The amendment expresses our absolute disquiet about the length time it has taken to put in place requirements for the appointment of a national industry board, leading to industry regulation and the way in which people working in the industry could be registered to carry out actions under the legislation. If we look at the timeline, we see that it was not until 31 May that the minister indicated that the Australian Refrigeration Council had been selected to administer the national authorisation and licensing system for the sale, use and handling of refrigerants that are ozone-depleting substances and synthetic greenhouse gases, and it was not until a week later that the details of the licensing scheme were announced.

The opposition acknowledge that transition arrangements have been put in place, but we are reliant on the skills and techniques of those who will be licensed under this act to ensure that we do not have the release of ozone-depleting gases into the atmosphere and then into the stratosphere and that we do not have the release of replacement gases that are now acknowledged as greenhouse gases. That was the point of the 2003 legislation. I think it has been acknowledged throughout the debate that all parties have worked together in this important area of public policy. We understand that we need to solve and ameliorate these problems and acknowledge that the partnership between government and industry will set out these achievements. Many of the uses made of ozone-depleting gases are illustrative of the way our society has developed. Artificial refrigeration and many other uses of these gases have been important to our economy. But it is also an example of the way we have gone about ozone protection that various studies of these pieces of legislation have, importantly, highlighted that this has been of benefit to our economy. So we see yet again an example of where we have the collision of measures being taken that are of benefit to the environment, of benefit to the economy and, because people have an understanding of collective action, of benefit to society. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to address the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. I particularly want to focus the attention of the House on some of the gross mismanagement of vegetation in Queensland through the Queensland vegetation management legislation and on how the Queensland Labor Party through the leadership of Peter Beattie is failing to deliver what he thought he was going to deliver by his punitive measures. He is failing to deliver the positive outcomes to the ozone that could be delivered with good vegetation management laws. The Premier failed to work cooperatively with the key stakeholdersâthat is, the land-holders and the regional communitiesâbefore he brought that legislation forward. Yes, he went out to see them, and I was involved in some of the visits to parts of my electorate. But he failed in that process and, in the end, he just brought his legislation forward with little concern for the impact it would have on local landholders.

speech.para: Our environment is part of our heritage, and it is important that we protect it for future generations. That is undisputed. Australia houses several unique environmental wonders of the world, including the Great Barrier Reef, the Daintree rainforests and, at the back of my electorate, the Simpson Desertâanother one of those great unique features of our landscape. Let us not forget the Lake Eyre basin and Lake Eyre itselfâwhat a unique feature that isâthe Queensland Mitchell grass plains and the brigalow lands. The Darling Downs is unique as an agricultural land in the Southern Hemisphere because of its features, its soil type and the richness of it. In the west of my electorate is the great Channel Country, where the inland rivers flow, and, of course, there is the Murray-Darling Basin.

All have unique vegetation, unique features and unique animal life. Last week we saw the launch of National Bilby Day in this parliament. The bilby is a wonderful little mammal that has for many years survived non-native predators like wild cats and foxes that have been introduced into Australia. Thank goodness for those people from my electorate, who were down in Canberra last week, who have done a tremendous job in protecting the bilby and establishing an ecosystem where they can breed in a natural environment. It is a fact that land-holders across Australia have been working since very early settlement to manage our native vegetation.

Australiaâs natural environment and landscape is one of the biggest drawcards in attracting both domestic and international tourists to our wonderful environmental features. The latest figures, for instanceâand this demonstrates just how important our environment isâshow that tourism contributes substantially to Australiaâs economy. Tourism is a $73 billion industry, which employs more than half a million Australians, with over 200,000 of those in regional areas.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order: whilst these matters might be of interest, I do not think they relate to the bill. The long title is âA Bill for an Act to amend the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act 1989 and to make changes relating to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust, and for related purposesâ.

(Mr Baldwin)âThe parts I heard of the debate referred to greenhouse gas and emissions, but I will listen to the memberâs contribution. I ask the member to make sure that he refers to the contents of the bill.

âI just say to the honourable member that I am demonstrating the uniqueness of some of our environment and how we should protect it, because it does contribute to the ozone layer, and how through protecting our vegetation in our rural areas it will contribute to the protection of the ozone layer. I am just highlighting an issue relating to tourism. The health of the ozone layer is important to tourism as well as to good vegetation management.

speech.para: To complete what I was saying about the tourism industry, tourism earns something like $17.3 billion. Australia earns more export dollarsâand this is interestingâfrom tourism than from the export of coal and wool combined. The honourable member might just reflect on that for a moment, because we know that coal is one of those energy sources that is not a positive on our environment or the ozone. We know we cannot live without it at the moment; it is important. So, when you consider that tourism can replace some of these exports over time, tourism will be a great economic driver for the nation. I just point that out to the House and for the honourable member in the face of his intervention.

The government in Queensland introduced into the parliament the Vegetation Management Amendment Bill, which was legislating to ban broad-scale tree clearing of remnant native vegetation by December 2006. There were several purposes for that legislation, one of which was to contribute to greenhouse abatement. That was one of the Premierâs intentions. It is a known fact that trees contribute to reducing the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and, hence, the potential to minimise the ozone being further damaged by industry emission sources such as motor vehicles, which we all obviously drive, factories and coal fired power stations. So trees play an important part in the environment and an important part in contributing to greenhouse abatement.

The Queensland governmentâs vegetation management legislationâI will be kind and say âinadvertentlyââis having a detrimental impact on the environmental ecosystems of parts of Queensland. The only reason I can see for the Premier acting in the way he did is that he was after Greens preferences. He was not really considering ozone; he was after preferences. He should have had that foremost in his mind in addition to his being able to work in a positive and cooperative manner with the land-holders of Queensland. Had he been prepared to work with the land-holders of Queensland and get suitable vegetation management laws in place, it would have been a win-win for both the ozone layer and the livelihoods of land-holders. If the Queensland government had worked with land-holders, there would have been a positive outcome for the regional towns as well, because they are just so dependent on the jobs created by the enterprises on the farm lands, the pastoral lands, around those towns.

On a recent visit to Quilpie in the west of my electorateâI was there with my parliamentary colleague Senator Ron Boswell, the Leader of The Nationals in the SenateâI inspected a property in the mulga lands where the legislation in Queensland is having a detrimental effect. I have linked trees to the ozone, so I think I have the right to continue pointing out where bad laws will have a detrimental impact on the ozone. Stephen Tully is a well-respected and knowledgeable land-holder. He is a descendent of some of the first settlers in the Quilpie region. The families of some of the first settlers are still there. They have been there since 1874. We toured parts of his property and, of course, as we all know, that part of Queensland is in exceptional drought. It has been in exceptional drought for the last two years. It will have to be rolled into a third year. We would all love to see rain so that is not necessaryâbut it looks as though it will be. There has been some rain in the region, but not exceptional drought-breaking rain.

On Mr Tullyâs property the grasses have been eaten out and have not been able to regenerate because of the exceptional drought. Mr Tully, his family and a large number of the pastoralists in that region have harvested mulga trees, which are a source of fodder and nutriment for animals in times of drought. A lot of the land in western Queensland has been mapped by satellites. These satellites are a wonderful tool for all of us, but they are inaccurately describing some of the vegetation on Mr Tullyâs property. Some mulga trees are described as âbastard mulgaâ when in fact they are not in that region; they are elsewhere on the property.

In order for Mr Tully and other land-holders in the mulga ecosystems of western Queensland to sustain their stock, as they have done for more than a hundred yearsâthe mulga regenerates in the good seasons and is conserved for the bad seasonsâthey have to harvest that timber. They would have harvested it in the early days with an axe. Later on it would have been with a chainsaw, and then with a tractor. While in some cases that practice is still allowed under a permit, it is becoming more difficult day by day and year by year as a result of the legislation introduced by the Queensland Labor government, under the premiership of Peter Beattie.

One of the aspects of harvesting mulga is that when the trees or the low branches are laid on the ground they protect the soil. We have only got to look at a mulch system in our own garden to see that when we put mulch on top of the ground we protect the soil and conserve moisture underneath it. Mr Tully was able to show us that, with the last few years of limited rains, trees have been harvested for their fodder but underneath the branches that remainâwhich have been acting like a mulchânew green plants were emerging. They had germinated. They were also protected from the livestock. So what you have here is some grass and some weeds coming through. It will grow through the mulch if the tree or its branches are allowed to remain on the ground. The mulch also creates a ground cover, which prevents erosion when the rains come. Mr Tully was able to show us how he and his forebearsâhis familyâhave successfully used mulga since the late 1890s. They only harvest it when they want to use it as drought fodder.

Another point I want to make in relation to the harvesting of mulga is that, if you do not harvest the mulga, the tree will of course grow to its full height and, as it matures, the leaves become very dry. It cannot produce the same sorts of benefits that a young tree, green grass or crops produce for carbon abatement; it cannot create a carbon sink. So by harvesting the mulga and allowing it to regenerate when the seasons come and by using the fodder harvested to feed drought affected stock, you end up with a win-win situation.

To my mind, there is no-one better to determine whether or not mulga should be harvested than the land-holders who have been doing it sustainably for 150-odd years. Why a satellite map should be the only determinant for this outcome, I am not quite sure. It should be used as a useful tool, but it should be used in conjunction with the knowledge of the land-holders and of course the regional bodies who are very involved in the agricultural or the pastoral scene, as in this case.

An example of what happens when you do not manage your vegetation was clearly demonstrated right here in Canberra with the bushfires. The national parks were not being managed and we saw the tragic consequences of that with the bushfires. When the wind conditions changed the fires raced towards Canberra and, sadly, people lost their lives and over 500 homes were destroyed. Had the vegetation in the national parks been managed to prevent bushfires, those sorts of consequences would not have occurred. The other element of those fires is that the smoke from them is a net negative for our ozone.

If we manage our vegetationâour timber resources and our grassesâwe can have a win-win for the environment. I believe that, importantly, the issue is about management rather than about the punitive measures that we have seen introduced into Queensland. The land-holders in Queensland who want to work with government to produce sustainable ecosystems are not in the business of destroying the ecosystem. They are not in the business of wanting to destroy their own livelihoods. It is their livelihood; it is what sustains their families.

I know time is short, but I want to move very quickly to the recommendations of the Productivity Commission report which was commissioned by this government in the last term of government. That report, which was brought down in June last year, is titled Impacts of native vegetation and biodiversity regulations. I commend that report to the opposition, because the conclusions are the basis on which I believe we should be looking at vegetation management at a national level. I refer to recommendation 10.3, which reflects what I have been saying about fodder harvesting. It states:

quote.para: Ongoing efforts are required to improve the quality of data and science on which native vegetation and biodiversity policy decisions are based, particularly âon-the groundâ assessments to test the accuracy of vegetation mapping based on satellite imagery.

speech.para: That is the very point that I was raising in relation to the problems Stephen Tully has been having. That is a recommendation from the Productivity Commission report. All this leads to having a positive outcome on the environment and also on the ozone layer, if we manage our vegetation properly and sustainably.

It was found that there needed to be an improvement in the regulatory regimes to enhance the transparency, the consistency and the accountability of decision making. In particular, recommendation 10.4 highlights several possible approaches, and I would commend those to others, because of the limited time I have here. One of the other recommendations that I believe is particularly important is 10.5. It states:

item.para: greater use should be made of the extensive knowledge of landholders and local communities â¦
some across-the-board rules â¦ could be relaxed and replaced with requirements that meet environmental objectives but which reflect regional environmental characteristics and agricultural practices.

speech.para: That fits in exactly with what I have been talking about in relation to the mulga lands of western Queenslandââthat reflect environmental characteristics and agricultural practicesâ. Finally, the report also saysâand this is important in the vegetation laws of Queenslandâthat regulations assert authority of ownership over the private propertyâs remnant vegetation. Land-holders are held accountable for the management of the vegetation while being left uncompensated for this ongoing day-to-day management. Incentives for land-holders to voluntarily manage and conserve native vegetation are therefore undermined. Subsequently, when regulation reduces the private value of land-holders or native vegetation, incentives to manage it are diminished.

In light of the Productivity Commission report and the comments and the experience of the land-holders of Queenslandâand I visited the mulga lands of western Queensland only two weeks agoâI commend to this government and all governments across Australia the work of the Productivity Commission in bringing forward sustainable vegetation management rules. (Time expired)

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: âin replyâIn summarising the debate on theEnvironment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005, I wish to do three things. Firstly, I want to address the points raised by both government and opposition members. Secondly, I wish to address some of the issues more generally in relation to the ozone and synthetic gas amendments. Thirdly, I want to outline some key points in the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust amendments. In looking at this billâand I wish to thank all of the speakersâwe have had a series of points from both government and opposition members.

speech.para: I want to address the points raised by the three opposition members: the member for Grayndler, the member for Throsby and the member for Scullin. Their points really fall into two categories, other than a general agreement with the governmentâs policy and approach on ozone protection and endorsement of the actions in relation to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust. The two criticisms that the members of the opposition have raised fall into these categories: firstly, there has been an attack on the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Ian Campbell, who is currently in Korea having enormous success in leading the international campaign against whaling and getting ready to see his reforms in relation to ozone and synthetic gas come into being.

The criticism was that the minister had in some way delayed the appointment of the refrigeration and airconditioning industry board to issue licences for refrigeration and airconditioning. I want to set down that there were two absolutely clear principles which the minister adopted. The first was to make sure that any appointment of a group which would regulate would be contested, that there would not just be a desire but a responsibility to ensure that a critical position such as that was fully and properly contested. The minister was not happy that there was sufficient contestation. He made a very clear, very simple ruling that we had to open it and we had to make sure that there was a proper chance for competition. We had to make sure that that was the case.

The second principle which he applied was that he had to be prudent, that we had to see that this was a safe, appropriate body capable of protecting this industry and ensuring that licences were allocated properly. So he had to have the best and they had to be up to standard. For taking time to do that, we make no apology. It is utterly the appropriate thing to do.

In the second criticism levelled by our friends in the opposition, they drew a comparison between what Australia is doing in relation to ozone protectionâand they acknowledge that it is an outstanding set of activities which go back both to this government and to the previous government; and I recognise the work of the previous governmentâwhat it is doing in relation to greenhouse gases. That is the criticism. On both ozone protection and greenhouse gas abatement the Australian government has an outstanding contemporary record. The key thing to remember is that not only is the Ozone Protection and Synthetic Greenhouse Gas Management Act world-leading legislation but also we are achieving our targets in terms of our Montreal and Kyoto protocol obligations in relation to greenhouse gas. Australia is one of the only countries in the world to actually be achieving both our ozone and our greenhouse gas targets.

We happen to take exception with the mechanism within the Kyoto protocol because we believe that it could well have a net detrimental effect to the general approach of dealing with climate change and greenhouse gases. But we have met our targets and we are one of the very few Annex 1 or developed world nations to be so doing. We are in an almost unique group to be achieving both our Montreal protocol targets in relation to ozone and the Kyoto protocol targets in relation to greenhouse. That is an exceptional situation.

The second point that I want to make today is in relation to the ozone and synthetic gas amendments contained within this bill. We agree and accept that there is a critical need to protect against ozone depletion. That threat is real and tangible, but there is extraordinary progress. Australia has performed exceptionally by international standards, and has been progressing very well.

The third point is that within the ozone protection element of this bill there are two important amendments. The bill amends and streamlines the licensing requirements for the import or export of used or recycled methyl bromide or hydrochlorofluorocarbons and, in addition, it amends and requires that Australian manufacturers of synthetic greenhouse gases report to the government consistent with the existing requirements for importers and exporters of synthetic greenhouse gases.

This brings me to the last part of my summaryâthe Sydney Harbour Federation Trust amendments. I am delighted to be able to make this summary in the presence of the member for North Sydney, who has fought with absolute ferocity to protect and expand the areas under the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust. When we look at the seven sites of the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust, we apply two key principles to dealing with them. The first key principle is public accessâopening these lands to public access for the first time in many cases not just for 10 years, not just for a generation, but forever. That is an extraordinary legacy which will be left by the member for North Sydney, the member for Warringah and others involved in the establishment of the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust. The second principle is in relation to the use of these public areas. This may include use for marine science, marine education and for the communityâall of the things for which the community has pushed and which are currently being delivered.

The next step is in relation to HMAS Platypus. That submarine base should be turned over as quickly as possible from defence land to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust. The member for North Sydney has been unstinting. He has set a deadline and we are working to that a deadline. This bill puts forward a practical land swap that is all about protecting the environment, and it delivers on that.

Ultimately I thank everyone who has spoken on the bill, both government and opposition. I thank the government speakers, the members for Bowman, Fisher and Maranoa, who talked about the legacy that we leave to future generations. They summarised what we are doing in relation to the ozone amendments and in relation to the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust. It is about leaving a legacy for the next generation, and with that I am delighted to commend the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 to the House and I urge its speedy passage.

speech.para: The Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 is a part of the Howard governmentâs continuing reform of the family law system. The bill contains a range of amendments to the Family Law Act 1975, designed to improve the operation of the current family law system. Some of these are technical amendments intended to improve the actâs operation, such as amendments to modernise the terminology used. Other amendments relate to procedural matters, including appeal processes.

These amendments to the Family Law Act 1975 are ongoing reforms, separate from the package of family law reforms that respond to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report, Every picture tells a story. The government has announced part of its response to that report, and I will introduce an exposure draft of legislative amendments shortly for comment.

Following its introduction into the House on 1 April last year, the Family Law Amendment Bill was referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, which reported in July 2004. The committee recommended that the bill should proceed, subject to a number of amendments.

The bill lapsed with the proroguing of parliament before last yearâs election and was therefore reintroduced in the other place in March 2005. The recommendations made by the Senate committee have been taken on board and are incorporated in the bill before you.

The bill contains amendments to address the issue of parenting orders not working in practice. A number of parenting orders, particularly those made by consent, are found not to actually work. The bill contains amendments to allow a court of its own motion to vary orders relating to children. This is aimed at situations where contravention proceedings have arisen because the original parenting order is unworkable and allows the court to fix the problem before it leads to further contravention proceedings.

Another important amendment in the bill provides a right for persons who are determined not to be a parent of a child, through DNA testing or by other means, to recover any moneys paid or property transferred for the benefit of that child under maintenance orders. During its passage in another place, both government amendments and Democrat amendments were made to this section. The government proposes to introduce further amendments to remove the Democrat amendments, to ensure that this provision gives a clear and predictable resultâthat is, if a person is found not to be a parent of a child, and that person has paid child maintenance under a court order for that child, the person can expect to bring a claim in the court that made the original order, and to recover what has been paid, unless there are exceptional circumstances.

A number of amendments in this bill clarify the Family Courtâs powers in a range of areas, including the courtâs rule-making powers to support the Family Law Rules 2004 which commenced on 29 March 2004, and in relation to the ability of the court to change the venue of proceedings and to clarify the effect of offers of settlement.

The bill also clarifies a number of issues relating to the operation of appeals. One amendment removes the power of the full court to issue a certificate that no special leave to appeal is needed from the High Court to appeal to that Court where âan important question of law or public interestâ is involved. This amendment was made in response to a recommendation of the Australian Law Reform Commission with which the High Court and the Family Court both agreed. The government accepted the recommendation as it considers that the High Court, through the special leave to appeal process, should be in control of what matters are dealt with by that court.

The bill provides for the transfer of family law proceedings from state courts of summary jurisdictionâthat is, magistrates and local courts, direct to the Federal Magistrates Court on the state courtsâ own initiative. Many proceedings instituted in state courts in relation to property with a value of over $20,000 or in relation to contested parenting orders will be appropriate for determination by the Federal Magistrates Court.

Currently the Family Law Act provides for transfers in such matters from courts of summary jurisdiction on the courtâs own initiative to the Family Court but not to the Federal Magistrates Court. The Family Court then transfers appropriate matters on to the Federal Magistrates Court. This amendment will enable matters to be transferred directly to the Federal Magistrates Court and therefore reduce delays.

The bill also widens the range of matters which can be the subject of private arbitration. Currently the matters that can be dealt with by a private arbitrator under the Family Law Act are limited to matters which relate to property, spousal maintenance and maintenance agreements. The bill expands the scope to include financial agreements and certain orders in relation to superannuation. Parties must consent before matters can be referred to private arbitration.

Also included in part 16 of the bill is an amendment to the Bankruptcy Act 1966 to support reforms recently made under the Bankruptcy and Family Law Legislation Amendment Act 2005 that relate to bankruptcy and family law reform. This amendment will ensure that the Family Court of Western Australia, along with the Family Court of Australia, acquires all necessary bankruptcy jurisdictions in concurrent family law proceedings where a party is bankrupt. Part 17 also supplements the reforms that are made in that bill, reinforcing the role of the bankruptcy trustee as representing the interests of all creditors in family law property proceedings where a party is bankrupt or subject to a personal insolvency agreement.

The bill also modernises the terminology of the act to terms which are commonly used and widely recognised, thereby increasing the publicâs understanding of the act and accessibility to family law. This should be particularly beneficial in aiding self-represented litigants. It will no doubt surprise many that the term âdivorceâ does not appear in the act. The term âdissolution of marriageâ is simply replaced with âdivorceâ.
There are a range of other minor amendments in this bill.
The government is committed to enhancing and making more accessible and efficient the family law system and this bill is part of the governmentâs commitment to that goal.
Full details of the measures contained in this bill are included in the revised explanatory memorandum to the bill, which I table.
I commend the bill to the House.
Leave granted for second reading debate to continue immediately.

talk.start.para: âAs the Attorney-General indicated, the Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 is very similar to the Family Law Amendment Bill 2004, which was introduced in the last parliament. That bill was examined by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, which made a series of very useful recommendations. Labor is pleased to see that the government has clearly taken on board many of those recommendations in the preparation of the new bill. This has been one of many examples of the Senate committee process facilitating constructive bipartisan work on important policy issues.

speech.para: As with the last bill, Labor welcomes this bill as a positive contribution to improving the existing Family Law Act. This is an omnibus bill dealing with amendments in 16 parts. For the most part this bill is non-controversial. Many are technical changes that will ease practical difficulties faced by the courts and court users. Part 10 deals with terminology. This may seem trivial, but in fact it is very important that the Family Law Act makes use of plain English. This is, as we note, an area of law that touches more people than almost any other. It is also an area where, as a result of economic circumstances, there are a substantial number of self-represented litigants. If ever there was a case for making an effort to clean up arcane language in our statutes, it is in this act and we commend the government for that.

Part 5 would extend the range of matters that can be dealt with through private arbitration. This creates a welcome new pathway for certain cases that do not require the expense and delay of litigation but cannot be resolved through mediation alone. Part 16 cleans up a gap in the recently passed Bankruptcy and Family Law Legislation Amendment Bill to ensure that the Family Court of Western Australia has the same jurisdiction as the Family Court of Australia in the area of crossover between family law and bankruptcy law.

There are some parts of the bill that are controversial, and these have been the subject of amendments in the other place. The most important is part 14. This would allow claims for the retrospective recovery of maintenance by a person who finds out later that they are not the childâs biological parent. Labor supports the intention of this provision. As I will note shortly, it would have limited application, but we have serious reservations about the sorts of outcomes it could produce if applied too rigidly.

In most instances, we are talking here about cases where a mistake has been made as opposed to deliberate deception. That is, we are talking about a case where one person was thought to be the father, and a maintenance order was made requiring them to pay maintenance to the mother to support the child. It is a situation where everyone has shared in the mistaken belief: the mother, the purported father and even the court. The question is really about who should bear the cost of the mistake. A good argument can be made for both sides. The man can rightly say that the maintenance order should never have made and that he should never have been required to pay for a child that is not his. But the mother could also argue convincingly that she is incapable of paying all the money back while continuing to support herself and her child or other children in circumstances where a genuine mistake occurred. The Family Court, of course, cannot be required to force a mother and her children into povertyâand should not be required to do soâto correct an honest mistake.

Labor thinks there is only one fair way to deal with this dilemma, and that is to ensure that there is sufficient judicial discretion to have regard to the entirety of circumstances. In short, every case could be different. In some cases mothers may well be doing it tough, and recovery of the full amount could be disastrous for them and their children. In other cases, the mother might have ended up in a new relationship or in secure employment whereas the purported father may have struggled to find the money to pay the maintenance every fortnight. In some cases it will have been an honest mistake; in others a court would regard seriously circumstances of deliberate deception. In some cases the man will have acted quickly upon finding out that he is not the biological father; in others he may have left it for many years, with the result that recovery will be all the more onerous for the mother. We cannot predict all the permutations that will arise and devise a formula that is fair in all circumstances. We need to trust the authority and wisdom of the courts to closely examine each case and make an appropriate order in the circumstances. For this reason, Labor has been anxious to ensure the bill provides the courts with adequate discretion over the amount that is recovered and how it is to be paid. In the Senate, Labor supported an amendment that would have that effect.

It is also important to ensure that, where a mother has been required to repay maintenance under these provisions, she is able, in turn, to recover maintenance from the actual biological father of the child. It would hardly be fair if a mother could be liable to retrospectively repay maintenance when the biological father cannot himself be found accountable. Moreover, in many cases the mother will have forgone other income in reliance on the maintenance. In particular, she will have received less in social security benefits. This makes it all the more important that the mother have a right to retrospectively claim maintenance from the actual father.

Labor raised this concern with the Attorney-Generalâs office and we were advised that the Family Law Act already provides the court with the power to award backdated maintenance. We received advice from the Attorney-Generalâs adviser which I will quote for the record and perhaps to assist in some way in the future interpretation of the legislation. The adviser replied:

quote.para: I am advised by our Department that a right for the mother to claim maintenance from the biological father already exists under Division 7 of Part VII of the Family Law Act in respect of children to which the new s66X would apply. Under section 66G of the Act, the court has a wide discretion to make any child maintenance order it considers appropriate against the parent of a child. The period covered and the amount of that order would be a matter for the court, considering the principal object in Division 7 to ensure that children receive a proper level of financial support from their parents.

speech.para: We are satisfied with this explanation. It is the case that section 66G provides a wide discretion for the court to make orders for maintenance, and nothing seems to prevent them making backdated or retrospective orders if that is appropriate. As I said, this goes a long way to easing the concerns that Labor had with this particular provision.

I should note here also that this provision does not have as profound an effect as I flagged earlierâto the extent that it is already the case that retrospective repayment of maintenance can be ordered by a court where the maintenance has been paid under the administrative assessment scheme of the Child Support (Assessment) Act, in particular under section 143 of that act. This bill would affect only those cases where the maintenance order has been made under the Family Law Act. We are advised by the Attorney-Generalâs office that only around 2.8 per cent of child support liabilities currently administered by the Child Support Agency arise under Family Law Act maintenance ordersâand that figure includes some spousal maintenance orders that would not be affected by this amendment. We are talking about a very small minority of cases that could be affected by this bill. Most of the cases that would be affected by the change are those where the maintenance order was made before 1989. This means that not only does the bill affect a small minority of cases of mistaken paternity but that that minority is clearly defined and ever shrinking.

As noted, it is desirable to bring the regime under the Family Law Act into accord with the Child Support (Assessment) Act. Having considered these issues, Labor are inclined to support a change to the Family Law Act that would ensure mistaken paternity cases are dealt with under that act as they are under the child support act. However, where we disagree with the government is on the words used to obtain that objective. We therefore supported the amendment in the Senate because it brings the language of the Family Law Act closer to that of the child support act. In doing so, the court has been given a greater discretion to ensure that mistaken paternity can be dealt with in the manner most just and equitable in the circumstances. In this way, it is an amendment which has improved the bill.

The other part of the bill that might be controversial is part 1, concerning the parenting compliance regime. The provision in this part would do two things: provide that the court can order parents to participate in counselling or parenting programs before making orders in enforcement proceedings; and provide the court with the power to amend parenting orders where enforcement proceedings have been brought but either no contravention was found or there was a reasonable excuse for the contravention.

With respect to the first of these, it is already possible for the court to order a couple to participate in counselling or parenting programs in other types of proceedings. This change is extending that power to enforcement proceedings. This is a positive move, as counselling and parenting programs have proven very successful at getting to and resolving the issues at the heart of noncompliance. We as members would have seen many instances of constituents coming in and, in one way or another, expressing their grief about serial noncompliance. It is obviously desirable all round if they can be resolved appropriately. Of course, counselling is not appropriate in all cases, especially where there is a history of violence, but we are satisfied that the protections already in the Family Law Act provide sufficient guidance to the court as to when these orders should and should not be made.

The second change in this part allows the court to vary parenting orders in enforcement proceedings, even if no contravention is found or there was a reasonable excuse for contravention. This will allow the court to iron out the practical or other problems in parenting orders that gave rise to the complaint of noncompliance. In some cases it will also allow a reasonable excuse for noncompliance, such as an apprehension of violence, to form the basis for a substantive change to the orders. Currently these changes require separate proceedings for variation of orders. It makes a lot of practical sense for courts to be given the power to deal with variation at the same time as hearing enforcement proceedings.

The National Network of Womenâs Legal Services has recommended that this new power be limited to certain cases, such as those where violence is an issue. When this was raised in the Senate committee on the 2004 bill, the Attorney-Generalâs Department advised the committee that the courtâs power would be effectively limited by the considerations the court must always have when making parenting orders: the best interests of the child and the factors set out in section 68F(2). Labor is comfortable with the response provided by the Attorney-Generalâs Department.

In summary, although this is a useful bill containing several practical reforms to the workings of the family law system, we did have some concerns with part 14 in its original form. But we believe those concerns have substantially been addressed by the amendment that was made in the Senate. Given that amendment, the opposition will be supporting the bill in the House.

talk.start.para: âBecause of the time frame allocated to this debate it is necessary to reduce at the request of the whips the amount of time taken to speak on the Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 to five minutes. I will therefore have to truncate somewhat what I was otherwise going to say. There is probably no area of Australian law which affects people more significantly than family law. Tragically, many marriages in our country collapse. Indeed, I suspect this is the case right around the Western world. It is incumbent on governments, therefore, to have the very best family law system to endeavour to manage, on behalf of families, in the best possible way a situation which is often less than entirely desirable.

speech.para: The Australian government is committed to doing all that it can to ensure that Australian families are given the best possible chance to live their lives with as few unwanted disruptions as possible. The Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 does back up the commitment of the government to ensuring the best possible outcomes for Australian families, particularly given family breakdown. The bill endeavours to ensure that the most vulnerable during these times of immense stress and hardship, the children, are given the best support and protection that can be provided by a legal system.

There is a long list of improvements afforded by this bill to the Family Law Act 1975 and, as has been mentioned previously, a number of these changes have come forward as a result of a Senate inquiry report. The amendments are ongoing reforms, as I think the Attorney has pointed out, quite different from the package of family law reforms which will respond to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report, Every picture tells a story. There will be a government response to that report and legislation will be brought forward, possibly in the form of an exposure draft.

The changes in this bill, however, include clarification of the own motion powers of the courts to modify parenting orders and the courtsâ power to order parties to attend counselling or post-separation parenting programs. There are changes in the provisions relating to the costings as well as offers of settlement to allow aggrieved parties to settle out of court, thereby avoiding the draining expenses of legal costs and further pressure on family members. The bill includes an increase in flexibility in courts in their dealings with parties who breach parenting orders, giving the court power to order a suspended prison sentence. This deterrent will be a useful tool in encouraging the compliance of some family members and there are provisions for sentences to be revoked at a later date. There is simplification of the processes involved with issuing a warrant for a parent who fails to comply with a parenting order and an expansion of the various matters that can be dealt with through private negotiation and arbitration. This will include issues such as superannuation and other financial issues.

It also follows up on the desire of government to encourage the use of alternatives to the courts to once again reduce the psychological and financial burdens of the courtroom. There is an ability to change the venue of a proceeding, replicating the powers also available to the High Court and to the Federal Magistrates Court, and clarification of the definitions of those depositions that could be set aside by the court. This becomes relevant when one party has made a submission that has the sole purpose of counteracting or nullifying an existing or anticipated court order. There is an extension of the list of procedural applications for the purpose of the appeal provisions, and provision for the magistrateâs court or local court to have the power to transfer Family Court proceedings directly to the Federal Magistrates Court in order to reduce unnecessary delays. The bill includes modernisation and clarification of some of the language in the Family Law Act to make laws more user friendly. For example, the term âproceedings for principal reliefâ is replaced by the term âdivorce and validity of marriage proceedingsâ.

The amendments in the bill also allowâand this may surprise someâthe use of the word âdivorceâ in legislation for the first time. There is clarification of guidelines related to when leave to appeal is required and the introduction of power enabling the court to stay or dismiss the appeal where the court is of the opinion that the appellant has not presented a proper ground for the appeal. The bill allows the removal of a time-consuming procedural hurdle whereby the full court of the Family Court is required to issue the certificate requiring the High Court to hear an appeal. There is a provision that a person who is found by the court not to be a parent of a child will be able to recover the money outlaid or the money transferred for the child under a maintenance orderâand this is a very important initiative. Whether a person is a parent or not, of course, is most often determined through DNA testing.

The bill gives judges of the Family Court the ability to delegate to judicial registrars, allowing them to make orders that vary parenting orders in relation to complying with existing court orders. It ensures that bankruptcy jurisdiction is correctly given to the Family Court of Western Australia, as it is to the Family Court, to supplement reforms made under the Bankruptcy and Family Law Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. It varies the Bankruptcy Act to add a provision previously omitted that limits the application of the Bankruptcy and Family Law Legislation Amendment Bill 2005.

In summaryâas, alas, my five minutes has almost elapsedâthe amendments relate to procedural matters such as appeal processes and improvements and clarification in terminology, all designed to improve the operation of the current family law system. All of these amendments address the issue of parenting orders issued by the court that are failing to deliver on their intended outcomes. These outcomes, as I mentioned at the commencement of this speech, are intended to improve the smooth operation of the Family Law Act 1975, with the overall motivation of protecting parents and children from as many as possible of the difficulties associated with family breakdown. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âI express my disappointment that we have such a short time to speak, but I live in expectation of a wonderful change coming forward from the Attorney-General to the Family Law Act based on the comprehensive inquiry conducted by the members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs. The inquiry report to which I refer is Every picture tells a story. I believe it was a report done over a short period of time and it proposes some substantial changes. I look forward to the governmentâs and the Attorneyâs response to the recommendations of the committee.

speech.para: I note that the changes in the legislation tonight do move in part in some areas towards the recommendations of that report. Substantially, this legislation is that which was offered to the House prior to the elections and which lapsed with the proroguing of the parliament. We now have that legislation back with some changes. I note in particular that parenting orders are a part of these proposals and that the cost and offers of settlement, enforcement processes and private arbitration, changes of venue and other matters are involved in these changes.

I have always considered the Family Law Act would be better entitled the âdissolution of marriage actâ, but that is a personal view and I am pleased to see that in this legislation there are some changes which reflect common usage by replacing references such as âdissolution of marriageâ with the term âdivorceâ, which is simple and easily understood. There is no doubt that in this area of intense human relationships the warfare that is conducted or may be conducted by a smallish percentage of those whose marriage is dissolved or is on the point of breakdown is a terrible thing to see and is a daunting thing to cope with as far as a legislative framework is concerned. I am very pleased to see in this legislation that there is a shift towards the prospect of private arbitration, which can be recommended by the court. I think that is a direction that needs to be pursued and, I hope, will be pursued: firstly, conciliation; then arbitration, if necessary; and finally a court decision at the end of the day. That court decision must be the indication that there has been a final and absolute breakdown and the judge has to make the settlement.

Australia has one of most legally interventionist forms of family law in the world. Other parts of the world, generally those of English-speaking traditions, tend to look to a process whereby the partners in the dissolution take greater responsibility for the resolution of the problems that they themselves have created, so they are asked to resolve, under supervision, matters such as the custody of the children and the settlement of property. I believe that process is superior to the one that we have pursued for such a long time and I suspect that there will be changes to that process. I note that even in this legislation there is pressure to refer more matters to a federal magistrate. In many ways it is a crazy thing that 60 per cent of the work of the High Court of Australia is taken up by immigration mattersâand we have been dealing with immigration matters today. Family law matters are dealt with by a superior court and I do not know that that is necessarily the process that we are looking for. A superior court normally requires rules of evidence along with other very tight rules of the court that cannot be fulfilled by the Family Court. Much of the evidence given in the Family Court is evidence that is untested and simply taken on hearsay. I think unproven evidence is dangerous because it encourages people to make extraordinary claims and statements which do not have to be justified.

I note that the costs of and the processes of changing orders are dealt with here. I think it is a very good move to waive the costs and make the changing of court orders a simpler factor, and the compliance problem is in part dealt with too. I look forward to a future occasion when we will deal with substantial changes which have been agreed to by both sides of the House, and with that progress I trust that we and the Attorney, in particular, will be successful in the advances we seek to make.

talk.start.para: âI have the same time limit as other speakers have, so rather than go through this bill in detail, item by item, I would like to put it in the context of some of the broader changes that this government is looking to make to value families in our society. I would also like to look at some of the linkages of areas that the changes to this bill make to the broader changes that are coming in. The Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 is part of the governmentâs continuing reform of the family law system. The changes that are being proposed will be the most significant changes in over 30 years. In the budget this year nearly $400 million was put aside over four years as one of the biggest investments to be made in the family law system. Importantly, what we are looking at here are not just changes in legislation. The government are looking to fundamentally change the way that Australia looks at its families, the way we support them in marriage and, where necessary, the way that family breakdowns are then handled.

speech.para: The comprehensive package includes an expansion of services to assist families, as well as changes to the laws and the courts. Together, these changes aim to promote the involvement of both parents in their childrenâs lives, to reduce the impact of conflict on the children and to reduce the enormous emotional and financial costs to families and the community of relationship breakdown and separation. A key part of the governmentâs initiatives is a network of 65 family relationship centres. As well as providing information, advice and dispute resolution, the centres will work closely with other services and agencies and will refer families to the help that they need. One of the key elements of this package is that we are looking to provide the opportunity for families to have a less adversarial approach to dealing with disputes and relationship breakdowns. I am pleased to say that at the moment in Parramatta, in Sydney, family law courtsâas their own initiative and using consent by parents rather than legislationâare already seeing terrific developments in terms of a reduction in conflict, a reduction in time in the courts and a reduction in cost as well as better outcomes through an increased level of mediation and the use of direct discussion between parents and judges. The courts are using community and other services to provide the kind of support and counselling that families need.

Importantly, these services, under the governmentâs proposed reforms, will have a large proactive element as well as supporting people during separation. The services will also aim to reduce conflict after separation and help non-resident parents maintain contact with their children. The nonresident can be either a mother or a father but, generally speaking, it is a father. I cannot overstate the importance of fathers in the lives of their children. These reforms are an important step to making sure that that contact is possible. So while this bill that is being considered today contains important amendments to the Family Law Act 1975, it does not represent the package of law reforms that I have just talked about. But it does provide the start of some enabling legislation which will support those reforms.

As other members have mentioned, this legislation has been to the Senate, which proposed a number of amendments which have been incorporated, so today I wish to touch briefly on the aspects of increasing coordination between agencies and services, suspended sentences, disputed parenthood and increased scope for private arbitration. The aspect of coordination with other services is really one of looking at the issue of parenting orders that are not working. As most members of parliament would know, this is one of the significant sources of discontentâin fact, more than that: despairâfor many parents who do not have their children resident with them. I welcome these moves in this bill, as the measures underpin the concept of increasing coordination between the courts and other services that can help the two parties come together to reduce the conflict which affects their children.
