They increase the ability of both parents to have a role in their childrenâs lives. Professor Parkinson, in his report on reforming the child support system, said:

quote.para: There is strong evidence that dealing with separating parents through the legal system alone can entrench conflict, rather than resolve it.

speech.para: Because the government sees that and recognises that, not only through this bill but through other measures, it is continuing to explore the best way to have good outcomes for children. A Griffith University report on childrenâs contact services highlighted the very good outcomes that the childrenâs contact services have. Through some of the broader reforms I mentioned earlier, the government has committed an additional $17 million to fund 30 new contact services throughout Australia. The bill also talks about suspended sentences. In terms of easing the angst of parents who see that orders that have been made by the court are being breached continually, the option for the courts to be able to impose a suspended sentence means that there is a very real lever that they can use to provide the incentive for the parent who has custody to provide access to the other parent.

On the issue of disputed parenthood, I welcome the move to make it easier for people who can prove that they are not the biological parent to reclaim money. A gentleman in my electorate of Wakefield has been in this situation and went bankrupt through the actions of the CSA before it was proved that he is not the father. I notice that Professor Parkinson also highlights this as something that is needed and proposes in his report that, where a court makes an order for repayment of an overpaid amount, that payment should be registered with the Child Support Registrar as a registrable maintenance liability for enforcement. I welcome the increased scope of matters that can be the subject of private arbitration, opportunities to make them less adversarial and to help people achieve better outcomes for them and for their families.

In summary, it is important to note that these amendments support the direction in which the government is reforming the family law system. I welcome the fact that we are not just changing rules and legislation but really looking to bring about cultural change in the way we support families and the way the government is committing to a more proactive approach to keeping marriages together in the first place. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âThe Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 contains a mixed bag of amendments. That is not to say that they are not positive, but there is a raft of amendments which are not related other than that they are amendments to the Family Law Act. I would like to speak about giving people who have paid child maintenance incorrectly under a court orderâincorrectly because they are not actually the parent of the childâthe right to recover moneys paid or property transferred. All of us over the years have received representations from constituents who have paid child support, often for many years, only to find that the child is not theirs. It is a very bitter pill in many circumstances. When the person has sought to recover money paid, that has virtually not been possible. In some circumstances, on presentation of absolute proof of paternity, the Child Support Agency has still been unable or unwilling to address that matter. On behalf of parents in Townsville in that situation, I am very pleased to support this amendment to the Family Law Act.

speech.para: There was quite a celebrated appeal case in Victoria last year. It related to a person who had discovered that he was the biological father of only one of his three children and had paid child support for seven years. The judge in the Victorian County Court found that the personâs former wife had knowingly lied when filling out the birth certificates for her two youngest children, who had been fathered by a family friend. That case raises a number of very 21st century questions. Should any man, rich or poor, be made financially responsible for a child found not to be biologically his? Should courts hold mothers accountable when they make false statements regarding paternity? That inevitably leads to deeper questions of what defines a fatherâchild raising or genes? In my view and I think in the view of the government, the father is the biological father of a child.

It is appropriate that we address this because every day in Australia at least 10 men open their mail to find the potentially explosive results of a DNA paternity test. Between two and three will receive the unhappy news that they are not the biological father of their child. Fortunately it is now possible to determine with virtually foolproof accuracy whether someone is the father of a child. I also note that one in four men taking a paternity test in Australia discovers that he is not the father of his children. According to a US survey, up to 30 per cent of unwed mothers who sign affidavits of paternity name the wrong man as the father. That is why it is important that it be made clear that a person who is not the biological father of a child should not be responsible for child support payments.

I thank the Labor Party for supporting this very important principle. I am aware that the Democrats tried to amend the governmentâs legislation, basically saying that this amendment should not be passed because it is not in the best interests of the child, but it is very much in the best interests of a personâs biological children. So I thank the Labor Party for changing their view and supporting the government on this amendment. This will be widely supported in my electorate in Townsville and Thuringowa. I appreciate the privilege of supporting this bill in the House tonight.

talk.start.para: âI rise today in support of the Family Law Amendment Bill 2005. The first amendment in this bill inserts an additional part 17 to schedule 1 of the original legislation. The purpose of this insertion is to correct an oversight. The amendments are designed to limit the role of third-party creditors in family property proceedings in cases where the trustee in bankruptcy can appropriately represent the interests of third-party creditors in those proceedings.

speech.para: The second series of amendments included in this bill propose to amend section 66X in part XIV of the act. The changes would allow the recovery of child maintenance paid or property transferred under a Family Court order in cases where a person is later found not liable for child support. This would apply, for example, where a paternity test later confirms that a father who has been paying child support is in fact not the father of the child he has been supporting. In this case, under the current system the father may have paid out tens of thousands of dollars in supporting a child and would instantly lose any access rights he had to that child.

This legislation makes the situation much fairer for de facto couples in relation to property settlements. Under the current legislation in South Australia, a de facto couple must live together in a de facto relationship for three years, or have a child, before the courts can intervene to make an order in relation to property. For example, an individual in South Australia may have owned their own home for some years and, after the birth of their child to their partner, the de facto partner and the child of the relationship may move into their home. If that relationship were to break down six months later, the mother may have a claim over half the house by virtue of having a child with her de facto. Under this legislation, if a court order were made that there was an entitlement to a percentage of the property, any moneys paid out would be recoverable in the event that the home owner was later found not to be the parent of the child.

There is no doubt that relationships are difficult, and they are even more difficult when children are involved. The breakdown of relationships in these circumstances is devastating to all parties involved. This legislation is about making the law that little bit fairer. At the end of the day, no amount of legislation is going to stop parties to a failed relationship from feeling hurt and angry. All we can do as legislators is make the basis for those situations as fair as possible. At the end of the day, if an individual has been financially and emotionally responsible for a child, only to find out that the child was not their responsibility, they should have a right to recover what they have lost. No law can ever help them to recover the emotional costs, but we should enable them to recover what they have mistakenly outlaid financially.

While this government feels it is important to enable the recovery of financial outlays in situations where a party is deemed at a later time not to be liable for child support, we accept that every situation is different. Accordingly, this bill also seeks, through the amendments to section 66X, to introduce a provision which will allow the court to order only partial repayment in cases where child support has been wrongfully paid. However it is important to note that, with this provision, the court will only be able to make such an order in cases where there are exceptional circumstances. An example of exceptional circumstances is where recovery of the child support paid in error would result in the bankruptcy of the mother. For the reasons I have outlined, it is important that this provision only be available in exceptional circumstances. This bill and these amendments are about making the law fair and it should be only in very exceptional circumstances that that fairness is taken away.

In considering the exceptional circumstances provision, it must be remembered that paying child support is often a very heavy financial burden. An individual who has struggled to meet that burden for years, only to discover it was not his burden to bear, should have his right to recovery altered only where the circumstances are exceptional.

Another government amendment being sought to section 66X relates to the Child Support Agency. This amendment makes it clear that any application for the repayment of child support outlined in this legislation must be against the mother, not the Child Support Agency. The Child Support Agency attempts to intervene in situations which are exceptionally complicated and which are influenced by a very high level of emotion. Those working at the agency make decisions based on the information which is available to them at the time. These changes seek to protect the Child Support Agency from action to recover child support under these amendments. These amendments make it clear that actions for the recovery of incorrectly paid child support must be taken against the mother involved.

These changes are not meant to penalise single mothers and will not affect the large majority of them. I have no doubt that the cases where these new laws are invoked will be rare, but we cannot ignore the fact that these cases do occur, and we have a responsibility to those who suffer in these circumstances to do the right thing. These amendments are necessary to ensure there is equality in our family law system and to ensure that those who come in contact with the family law system have faith that the outcomes will be just and fair.

The Howard government is committed to improving outcomes in the family law system. We will continue to introduce further major reforms in accordance with the committee report entitled Every picture tells a story. We will continue to do all that we can to ensure the family law system provides appropriate and just outcomes for all who come in contact with it. No government can make the separation of a family an easy thingâwe do not for a moment fool ourselves into thinking that we canâbut these changes and the raft of changes that this government will introduce are aimed at making the system as fair as possible and at assisting families in what are exceptionally difficult times. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the Family Law Amendment Bill 2005. Anybody who knows me in this place or in my community knows that I very much believe in the importance of the family unit. I believe in doing everything we can as individuals, as a government and, indeed, as a parliament to support families, especially children. The bill we are debating tonight contains a range of amendments to the Family Law Act 1975. The bill is designed to improve the operation of the current family law system. Some amendments in the bill, such as those that modernise the terminology used, are technical and are intended to improve the actâs operation. Other amendments relate to procedural matters, including the appeals process, and the Attorney-General has covered those extremely well.

speech.para: Families are the cornerstone of society, and they certainly are the cornerstone of Australian society. I do not think there is a person in this place, despite the different brands of politics that we might follow, who would disagree with those statements. It is so important that we get a perspective on this and that we recognise that, since the introduction of the Family Law Act in 1975, in the Whitlam era, we have seen a growth in the rates of divorce in Australia that probably nobody in the parliament of that day would ever have expected to see. That brings great sadness to me. I recognise that families, and indeed relationships between adults, break down for all sorts of reasons, and I reluctantly say that sometimes it is probably for good reason. However, if we are to be honest with ourselves and with each other it has to be said that families are breaking down far too often in this country. While politicians will never be in a position to dictate the relationships that people share and the way in which homes and families can function in the future, we do have a responsibility to make sure that we have covered ourselves and are satisfied that we have provided families with the support they need.

An example that springs to mind is one in which a government policy, and I will not try to think of one, may put more pressure on families. If that were to happen, we in this place would have to take some of the blame for some of the growth in the rates of family breakdown. This is not a political point, other than to say that everything we do here that will have an impact on families has to be very carefully scrutinised as to the consequences it will have in homes around Australia.

As this bill relates to the Family Law Act, I would like to touch on the issue of access after divorce or separation. I have spoken in this House before on the need for children to have both male and female role models. We need to make it fair and equitable for both a mother and a father to have fair access to children after a relationship has broken down. I feel it is appropriate at this stage to acknowledge a letter I recently received in relation to the growing movement of people who are crying out for change to the Child Support Scheme and the Family Law Act. I quote from my correspondentâs letter in which he said:

quote.para: I am writing to you to add my voice to the growing movement of people who are crying out for change to the Child Support scheme and the Family Law Act. There is almost an epidemic of family separation going on and there has to be a fairer outcome available not only for the parents but most importantly for the children. All children of separated parents should be able to see both their mother and father as close to equal time as possible.

This just does not happen at the moment. The norm has been for mum to keep the kids with her and quite often she keeps the house etc. and dad is lucky if he sees the kids every second weekend. If the mum chooses to be adversarial she can withdraw the kids from their father. Dad keeps paying child support and he doesnât get to see his children.

speech.para: It is very important to recognise that this letter came from a man in a situation where his former partner is cooperative and has a respect for the children that means there is not the conflict between them as he has described. He has himself said to me that he enjoys fair access to his children. His point, I think, is that he is scared to think what could happen if that were not the case, how devastated he would be, the sense of loss he would experience and the sense of loss of his children were they not in a position to enjoy a healthy relationship with their dad. I think we all know of cases where his example is true.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report entitled Every picture tells a story: inquiry into child custody arrangements in the event of family separation is provocative reading. It provides very important recommendations relating to the custody of children after broken relationships. It is clear that the committee kept the best interests of children in mind when they listened to witnesses, took submissions, made deliberations and, finally, made recommendations. I was very delighted to see the Attorney-General make a public statement earlier this year in which he said that the governmentâs agenda in this regard, in responding to this report, means that we will see the biggest ever investment in the family law system in Australia and that the governmentâs proposed changes will bring about not just tinkering but generational change in how family conflicts are managed in the future following a separation.

I am very encouraged to see a growing movement towards mediation rather than litigation. That is a very healthy move. I was very sad to read the ministerâs observation that as many as one in four children from separated families will see one parent once a year or not at all. These changes to the law will recognise the rights and needs of children and, importantly, the right of a child to know both his or her parents. I am also greatly encouraged to see a commitment to open a network of 65 family relationship centres around Australia. I suspect that not many people at this stage appreciate how significant these family relationship centres will be. I think we are in for exciting times.

I know the Attorney-General and the Minister for Family and Community Services have been very receptive to suggestions as to how they could function in the future. I and some of my colleagues have made public our view that these family relationship centres should not in practice, or indeed in a perceptive sense, be seen as divorce shops, as avenues or first stepping stones that you must overcome in order to achieve a divorce. A good many people would like to see these family relationship centres as places where families can go for advice, referrals or even counselling, not with a view to achieving a divorce but with a view to strengthening their relationships and marriages and provide an even better atmosphere for children to be nurtured to grow into healthy young Aussies.

Coming to the end of my remarks tonight, I would like to congratulate the government on the work it is doing. I am very proud to be a member of this government. I said in my first speech in this place, standing where I am tonight, that I believe the rate of family breakdown in this country must be identified. It must be addressed and, if we can, it must be reversed. A final observation I make tonight is that this country has come a very long way in its attitude to family breakdown since 1975. It has been said to me that in 1975, when this legislation was first debated, even Paul Keating as a backbencher voted against it. I do not think we are yet settled in this country on our final views on family breakdown. We as a government and I as a member will always respect the various reasons that families cannot survive. But where they can survive we will continue to hold the family up as the ideal and something that should be supported. With those remarks I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âToo often we hear and see the tragic consequences of relationship breakdown. Too often children, despite the best efforts of their parents and the courts, suffer as a result of these breakdowns. All of us in this place want to believe that we can help those in needâthat somehow we can come up with the right outcomes and that somehow we can fix peopleâs problems. But with family breakdowns we can never really achieve this. There is no magical legislative outcome or formula to alleviate the pain of relationship breakdown.

speech.para: The Family Law Amendment Bill 2005, while it cannot ameliorate the pain or rectify all the problems, will at least correct some of the anomalies in the Family Law Act 1975. It is an important step forward and it is evidence of this governmentâs determination to monitor what is happening, adjust the law to meet societyâs expectations and address some of the concerns and grievances. In the past I have been quite a critic of many aspects of family law and the operations of the Child Support Agency. While I would have liked to have seen some of these issues debated earlier in this place, I am very pleased that we are doing so now and that the Attorney-General has brought this legislation forward.

The bill makes a number of technical amendments intended to improve the operation of the act. For instance, it deals with the enforcement of court orders. It introduces the term âdivorceâ and also, and in my view this is very significant, allows for a person to recover child support payments made when they are found not liableâthat is, when they are later found to have, in fact, not been the parent of the child. On this point, I really want to make it clear that taking child support maintenance from someone who does not have a moral obligation to pay it cannot be condoned. It is bad enough for someone to be emotionally duped into falsely believing that they are the parent of a child, but to add a financial burden to this is an additional and unforgivable insult. At least now there will be some opportunity for financial redress by allowing the courts to make orders to recover payments or transferred property when there is no liability for a child. We can see the start of justice in this area.

The bill widens the range of matters that can be the subject of private arbitration, and this is also a very positive step. For instance, financial agreements and certain orders relating to superannuation will now be able to be arbitrated. The bill will remove some of the adversarial judicial features from the current arrangements and therefore prevent some of the destructive actions that often occur. The bill provides for the transfer of family law proceedingsâfor instance, from state courts directly to the Federal Magistrates Courtâon the state courtâs own initiative. This will potentially save large sums of money and reduce a lot of the delays involved in the court processes.

In contemplating any changes, we really have to ask: will these changes make the circumstances less painful for those involved? Are we going some way towards mollifying the damage caused by family breakdown? In asking these questions, the fundamental issue is the best interests of the child. In addition to that, we need to look at the issue of fairness to parentsâfairness to parents in custody arrangements, fairness to parents in terms of input into the lives of their children and fairness to parents in the financial contributions that they are called on to make.

It is worth differentiating, though, between the changes to the Family Law Act contained in this bill and the more substantial changes that, hopefully, will occur following the parliamentary report Every picture tells a story and the task force review into that report headed by Professor Patrick Parkinson. That report is a very important stepping stone to future family law and child support improvements. For instance, coming out of the recommendations of that report we saw the governmentâs commitment in the last budget of $397 million over the next four years that, hopefully, will bring about a cultural change in the way that family breakdowns are handled.

Of this allocation, $180 million will go towards establishing 65 family relationship centres. These will be a critical entry point into the family law system and will provide mediation services. They will refer families to other appropriate services. They will reduce the expensive resort of adversarial action through the courtsâaction that so often exacerbates the bitterness of family breakdown and separation and just intensifies the pain that all parties experience. Other important changes need to come about as well. The report made a number of recommendations regarding changing the formula for child support arrangements. I know there are many in the community who are distressed by the inadequacies as well as the perceived and, dare I say, actual inequities in the way the child support system currently works.

Further changes are needed to revolve around custody and parenting arrangements. All children, except in extreme circumstances, need the input of a father and a mother, particularly in their formative years. All children need to have access to the care, the nurturing and the leadership that a mother and a father can provide. On the other hand, both parents deserve a right to have an input into the lives of the children that they have parented, that they love and that they want to care for. Both parents need to have adequate opportunity to share parenting arrangements and to have that input into the lives of their children.

These amendments to the Family Law Act are a first step, but they bring with them some very welcome and overdue changes. I believe that in this place we have the opportunity to make generational changes in both family law and child support. While the amendments that we are debating today do not provide those fundamental changes, they are a very positive step in the right direction. I commend the bill to the House, and I look forward to the subsequent improvements that we will see coming out of changes to child support arrangements and to the way that parenting and family law work in this country.

talk.start.para: âin replyâI thank all honourable members who have contributed to the debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill 2005. Firstly, I thank the member for Barton, who acknowledged that from time to time there are contributions made by Senate committees. I am hopeful that we will see an opportunity to place more emphasis on members of this House contributing through committee discussions to the improvement of legislation, and to avail myself of the opportunity of receiving that advice.

speech.para: Committees can be very useful if their work is undertaken quickly and delivered in a timely manner and is not used to produce constructive delay for other purposes. I can assure the member for Barton that I am always willing to hear constructive views. If they can improve legislation that I am dealing with, I will take them from any quarterâparticularly from the member for Barton, whom I usually find very constructive. Further to the advice that my advisor gave in relation to that reference, I understand that the remedy does exist, as he outlined, but it is clearly a discretionary remedy in the hands of the court to be able to provide.

I thank the members for Fisher, Mitchell, Wakefield, Herbert, Kingston, Bass and Macquarie for the issues they raised about our new family relationship centres, the rights of children to know their parents, allegations of violence and enforcement of contact orders. I am gratified by the very wide level of interest in family law issues and the very constructive comments that have been made.

It is recognised that the Family Law Amendment Bill 2005 is largely a technical bill. While there are some issues that are important, such as those which allow a court to vary a parenting order of its own making in contravention cases, nevertheless, major reforms will follow the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report entitled Every picture tells a story. I hope to release shortly an exposure draft containing a range of measures and many of the matters that members have referred to. When I am in a position to release that exposure, I look forward to referring it to one of our House committees so that it can hear the input on the draft. I want that to happen quickly. I am anxious that we should proceed with these measures this year. I do not want to see them delayed unnecessarily.

Finally, I foreshadow two government amendments to section 66X that will be moved to the bill in the consideration in detail stage. These amendments will have the effect of removing the amendments that were made in the other place on 20 June. Those amendments allowed the court a very wide discretion to decide how much child maintenance a person could recover. The government sees this discretion as too wide and leading to variable results that would undermine the right of recovery that we are wanting to see in place. The government amendments will allow the court to recognise that in exceptional circumstances it may be appropriate to reduce the amount to be repaid. It is to give the court some direction but it acknowledges that in exceptional circumstances those matters can be addressed. I thank honourable members for their contributions. I commend the bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move government amendments (1) and (2):

amendment.para: (1)Â Â Â ScheduleÂ 1, itemÂ 136, page 34 (lines 25 to 27), omit âmay make such order that it considers just and equitable in the circumstances, includingâ, substitute âmust make such order as it considers just and equitable in the circumstances, forâ.
(2)Â Â Â ScheduleÂ 1, itemÂ 136, page 34 (line 28) to page 35 (line 6), omit paragraphs 66X(2)(a) and (b), substitute:

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (a)Â Â Â if the purported order was of a kind referred to in paragraph 66P(1)(a) or (b)âthe repayment to the maintenance provider, by the person to whom the amount or amounts referred to in subparagraphÂ (1)(b)(i) of this section were paid, of an amount up to, or equal to, that amount or the sum of those amounts; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (b)Â Â Â if the purported order was of the kind referred to in paragraph 66P(1)(c)âthe return to the maintenance provider of:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (i)Â Â Â the property referred to in subparagraphÂ (1)(b)(ii) of this section; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (ii)Â Â Â an amount up to, or equal to, the value of that property.

speech.para: The court may only order the repayment of an amount that is less than the amount, or the sum of the amounts, referred to in subparagraphÂ (1)(b)(i) of this section, or the return of an amount that is less than the value of the property referred to in subparagraphÂ (1)(b)(ii) of this section, in exceptional circumstances.

The government is committed to making amendments to the Family Law Act to ensure that fathers have a statutory right to recover certain maintenance payments where they have had no right before. The governmentâs amendments give the right to recover child maintenance in a court having jurisdiction to make the original maintenance orderâa right that is presently not available. The right will be offered to people who have paid money that they were not in fact liable to pay. Under current law, all that a person in a situation can do is to seek a civil remedy in a state court using remedies and torts in restitution. It is unfair that a person in this position cannot access the courts that have special expertise in these matters.

The advantage of the government amendments is that they will give the parties some certainty as to the likely outcome so that there is a real right of recovery of wrongly paid maintenance in appropriate and relevant circumstances. The current subsection 66X(2), passed in the Senate on the Democrat motion, is for a wide and expanded version of the courtâs discretion to adjust the amount of child maintenance that can be recovered based on what the court thinks is just and equitable. That provision would look similar to section 143 of the Child Support (Assessment Act) 1989, which allows the court to make such orders as it considers just and equitable for the purposes of adjusting or giving effect to the rights of a party or a child concerned. This is a wide and variable discretion which in practical terms means that it is very risky to pursue recovery action because it is very difficult to predict how courts will deal with the application.

The government amendment to this provision will ensure that court action under section 66X produces results. It should be obvious that a person in this situation should be able to recover what they have paid unless there are exceptional circumstances for ordering a less than full repayment. The phrase âexceptional circumstancesâ shows up already in sections 66M(4), 68L(2A) and 111CR(3) of the Family Law Act and in subsection 74(4), 74(7), 79(13) and 79(16) of the Bankruptcy Family Law Legislation Amendment Act 2005. It is also used in subsection 17B(1) of the Crimes Act 1914.

The government have proposed an amendment which is reasonable. We have preserved the right of recovery but given the court the ability to reduce maintenance in exceptional circumstances. The court could take into account extreme hardship caused by giving recovery, such as the fact that it may force a mother into bankruptcy. Another example of exceptional circumstances might be where a father has insisted on a purported child going to a private school. In such results it should be obvious to parties that the money should be repayable except in exceptional circumstances. I commend the amendment and I present a supplementary explanatory memorandum to the bill.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition will be opposing the amendments but, for the benefit of those who may be considering attending a function this evening, I can indicate that we will not be dividing on them. Essentially, there is a distinction between the Labor opposition and the government with respect to the extent of the courtâs discretion, and the Attorney-General fairly put the competing arguments. The amendment moved in the Senate and adopted with the majority vote of the opposition parties there provides that the court would be given a broad discretionâin fact, the wording is âto make such order that it considers just and equitable in the circumstancesâ. Effectively, this gives quite a broad discretion, having regard to what we would anticipate to be commonsense provisions.

speech.para: On the other hand, the governmentâs approach has been to have a presumption in favour of recovery, if you like. It is perhaps an appropriate thing that there be a presumption in favour of recovery, but it may be too far on the spectrum to say that that presumption is only displaced in exceptional circumstances. I note that in his concluding comments the Attorney-General gave some guidance as to what may constitute an exceptional circumstance, but effectively there will be a presumption that the moneys will be repaid. This is a complex area. While this bill applies to about 2.8 per cent of cases, I think there will probably be circumstances in the future where DNA technology makes it easier to identify parentage and, in those circumstances, it will be an issue not infrequently coming before the courtsâcertainly not infrequently coming before the Child Support Agency.

We believe that commonality between the respective provisions is desirable, but we would obviously oppose the government amendments so that the amendments moved in the other place stand. Having said that, I think from a broader perspective there probably does need to be a review of the situation downstream. Obviously the government amendments will succeed in this House and ultimately we will pass the legislation in the Senate, because it is desirable legislation. But downstream I think there will need to be recognition that perhaps an innocent party in all of this will be the children who have benefited from financial contributions from a man who was not their father but, nonetheless, in circumstances where there was not appropriate recovery from the actual father. Consideration should perhaps be given to whether there is justification, for instance, for supplementing social security payments or a right on behalf of that family and/or child specifically to recover moneys that otherwise would have been payable with respect to social security. These are issues that may require revisiting and review as the effect of the legislation becomes apparent. I flag those but formally, as I said, oppose the government amendments.

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for his indication as to how the matter might progress. I simply say that I obviously do not foreclose looking at these issues if experience suggests the measures have not operated as the government intended. The point I made in the earlier clarification was that the person who is ultimately responsible as a partner for the bringing of the child into the world may of course pick up some of those responsibilities. We will see how it works out in practice.

speech.para: Question agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being approximately 7.30 pm, I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: â I rise to draw membersâ attention to the harsh realities that face workers in my electorate and around Australia under the Howard government. I want to use the example, with his permission, of David Noel Thomas, a constituent in my electorate recently retired from his job after 48 years of service as a semitrailer driver for WM Jago and Sons. When he left the workplace Davidâs employer threw him a farewell party and he was told that his entitlements would be available for him to collect the next day. David Thomas returned the next day only to be told that the cheque had not yet been signed. Following a week of fruitless phone calls, fob-offs and contradictory stories, David returned to the office where he was told by the store manager, âI have bad news for you: they have the administrators in.â David Thomas is still waiting for $25,500 in entitlements that are owed to him.

speech.para: Ken Day also worked for the same employer, giving 32 years of service and is accordingly owed approximately $32,000 in long service and other leave entitlements. David and Kenâs former colleagues are also still awaiting their entitlements. David has since made an application to the General Employment Entitlements and Redundancy Scheme, GEERS, for his outstanding entitlements. His application to GEERS was rejected outright. He was told that because he retired a week prior to the company going into receivership he was unable to access any assistance under the scheme.

After 48 years of service David Thomas is now left to survive on his pension. After a combined 90 years of service, David and Ken have been left high and dry by the failure of the Howard government to adequately legislate to protect entitlements. Innocent workers like Ken and David are left with only financial uncertainty and distress. Instead of protecting workers and ensuring financial security for them and their families, the Howard government intends to reduce their job certainty. This governmentâs proposal to change the unfair dismissal laws to exempt small business and to undermine the job certainty and security of some four million workers is outrageous. This antiworker and, ultimately, antifamily attitude is typical of this governmentâs ideologically indulgent agenda. Employees who have served their probationary period can currently challenge their dismissal in the relevant industrial commission within 21 days, but this right, this basic and fair process of appeal, will be removed under this governmentâs regime.

Workers in businesses employing up to 100 people will have no appeal to an industrial commission and new workers will have to serve a double period of probation. The Howard governmentâs proposals could see workers sacked without explanation, perhaps sacked for something they did not do, without recourse to challenging the decision and no way to prove that they did not do it. There will be no warnings for these workers and no justice when they are unfairly sacked. This government intend to see these workers thrown on the scrap heap just as they have done with David Thomas, Ken Day and their former colleagues at WM Jago and Sons.

The governmentâs legislation will also remove the right to collectively bargain. David is represented by, and is a proud member of, the Transport Workers Union. Unions have played a proud role in this nation, going back to the very beginning of defending workers in situations such as this, of representing them, but the government is determined to take away that right due to an ideological agenda.

The government is also determined to take away minimum wages. In spite of question after question in question time, Mr Speaker, you would recall that we have received no guarantee whatsoever that no worker will be worse off, because the government knows that this will drive down wages particularly for those people who are most vulnerable. There is no justification for this attack on the hardworking people of my electorate, workers like David Thomas. Workers and their families deserve protection, they deserve job security and they deserve financial certainty. They do not deserve the Howard governmentâs package of ideologically motivated attacks on their working conditions and, ultimately, on their families.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight rather reluctantly to speak about an issue that arose out of an article by the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, in the Sydney Morning Herald on 21 June 2005. Mr Speaker, you would realise that I have spoken before about some of the comments that Mr Evans has made on the public record in regard to the parliament, and I have been very concerned each time I have seen them, but this one arose apparently out of inquiries from the Sydney Morning Herald about committee reports from this parliament which in fact had not been replied to by the government. It is probably interesting to find out why the Sydney Morning Herald made inquiries in the first place; nevertheless Mr Evans, instead of replying to the inquiry, has then put his own view of the world to the Sydney Morning Herald about this establishment of parliament.

speech.para: I would have thought it was the responsibility of the clerks either of the lower house or of the Senate to uphold the principles of this parliamentary democracy, and considering that the Clerk is not prepared to do that I, as Deputy Speaker, feel that I should make some comments. Mr Speaker, if you have a look at part 3, section 10(1)(a) of the Parliamentary Service Act 1999, you will see that it says:

quote.para: ... the Parliamentary Service provides professional advice and support for the Parliament independently of the Executive Government of the Commonwealth ...

speech.para: Part 3, section 10(1)(c) says:

quote.para: ... the Parliamentary Service has the highest ethical standards ...

speech.para: Section 12 of the Parliamentary Service Act 1999 says:

quote.para: A Secretary must uphold and promote the Parliamentary Service Values.

speech.para: In my opinion, a clerk of either the House of Representatives or the Senate has no right to go out and make public comments about the parliament. In fact, if you look at some of these commentsâand I will quote from the article which in fact Mr Evans has writtenâ

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, on a point of order: I seek your guidance. I know that privilege for an attack such as this would rest in members of parliament, but I wonder whether it is appropriate for an attack such as this to take place on the Clerk of the Senate during an adjournment debate.
âThe member for Page is in order because he is not talking about a member of the Senate.
âIt is interesting that the member for Grayndler is not prepared to support the parliament either. The Clerk was talking about the founding fathersâ
âMr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Now the member for Page, the Deputy Speaker, has gone from attacking the Clerk of the Senate to sayingâ
âThe member for Grayndler will resume his seat.
âI ask that the member for Page withdraw the words that I do not support the parliament. I ask that they be withdrawn.
âIf the member for Grayndler wishes to join the debate later, he is entitled to,
âThe Clerk says about the founding fathers:

quote.para: Their basic principle, as one of them expressed it, was that the law-making power should never be vested in a single authority, whether a single man or a single assembly, because that is the definition of tyranny.

speech.para: If you go a little bit further into the article, it also says:

quote.para: Giving a monopoly of power to one party is not the essence of good government but, under the way our parties operate, a sure route to corruption and misrule.

speech.para: These are the words of the Clerk of the Senate. I would have thought they were reprehensible to say the least. He also says:

quote.para: ... the Governor-General is hired and fired by the Prime Minister; the Prime Minister who is the executive government controls the House of Representatives through an ever-reliable party majority; the Senate has been a restraint on the Prime Ministerâs will ...

speech.para: So in other words the Clerk of the Senate is attacking the institution again, the highest part of the institution, by saying that, in fact, the Governor-General is just a lackey of the Prime Minister. He also goes on to say:

quote.para: ... High Court judges are appointed by the Prime Minister with regard to their ideological persuasion.

speech.para: Now he is attacking the High Court. I find this an extraordinary statement. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is Drug Action Week and I was pleased to attend the launch by the honourable member for Sturt, Chris Pyne, earlier this week. I know honourable members are busy this week but I was somewhat disappointed to see so few members and senators present at the launch. With the tens of millions of dollars expended by this government and the bipartisan nature of the issue, it would have been wonderful for more of us in this place to be there.

speech.para: What is Drug Action Week? As honourable members would know there are so many worthy causes for us to support and a plethora of coloured ribbons which we wear to show our solidarity with causes such as MS, motor neurone disease, youth suicide, diabetes, cancer and Daffodil Day et cetera. For me, Drug Action Week is probably one of the most important causes that I support. The week is an annual initiative hosted by the Alcohol and other Drugs Council of Australia. It is the premier event to raise awareness about alcohol and other drug issues in Australia and this year it is being held from 20 to 24 June.

The week is part of a host of activities to raise awareness about issues relating to alcohol and other drugs and to promote the achievement of those people who work to reduce drug related harm. The week also aims to promote public debate about good practice strategies for reducing drug related harm. Each year, Drug Action Week has different theme days to highlight the diversity and complexity of alcohol and other drug issues. The theme days reflect suggestions received from the sector as well as other identified priorities while maintaining the core themes of prevention, treatment and Indigenous Australians. The theme days for 2005 are: Monday, young people; Tuesday, treatment; today, prevention; tomorrow, Indigenous Australians, and Friday, consumers and carers.

Alcohol remains the most commonly used psychoactive drug in Australia, with 2001 data showing that over 80 per cent of the population aged 14 years and older consumed alcohol in the previous 12 months. The proportion of the population who used any illicit substance in the previous 12 months was 14.27 per cent. Cannabis is the most commonly used illicit substance with 33.1 per cent of Australians aged 14 and older having used cannabis at some time in their lives.

Alcohol misuse and tobacco use are overwhelmingly the cause of most drug related morbidity and mortality in this country and are therefore associated with the greatest social costs. Of the estimated $34.4 billion in costs attributed to problematic drug use each year, alcohol and tobacco combined account for more than $28 billion, with over $21 billion of these costs related to tobacco use. As someone who represents an electorate that contains both a rural as well as an urban component, I am concerned with the following statistics. Rates of smoking are up to 25 per cent higher in rural areas and the proportion of smokers outside of major cities has not decreased in recent years. In 2001, females in inner and outer regional areas were 1.15 and 1.27 times as likely to smoke as females in major cities. Younger males in outer regional areas have been shown to be 1.3 times as likely to smoke as males in major cities. Finally, males in regional areas were more likely to engage in risky alcohol consumption than males in major cities.

These are rather startling figures and when said quickly can easily be glossed over. These figures are why programs and campaigns should focus on regional areas, to start making inroads into such risky and costly behaviour. These figures are a cost to Australian society in many ways: hospitalisation, family dislocation, road trauma, suicide, lost productivity, diminished life spans, domestic violence and so on. It is hard to imagine that so much distress can come from the two most commonly accepted and legal drugs in our community, yet we persist in hiding behind the myth of legality and shade our eyes from the destruction caused by misuse of alcohol and tobacco.

This year 640 separate events make Drug Action Week the biggest ever, compared to last yearâs 450 events. It is my fervent hope that this year Drug Action Week will open the eyes of many Australians to the damage done, and that they will take the necessary steps to substantially reduce their abuse of alcohol, tobacco or illicit substances.

talk.start.para: âTonight in the parliament, I want to speak about Pooh Corner in the western suburbs of Brisbane. On 21 April, the federal government announced that it intended to transfer the ownership of Pooh Corner from the Department of Defence to the Brisbane City Council for the nominal sum of $1. I want to take this opportunity again to congratulate and commend the federal government and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence for being involved in this transaction and for making it happen. The alternativeânamely, the sale of Pooh Corner to private developers for the purpose of high-density residential livingâwas not acceptable to me or the local community. In my capacity as the federal member for Ryan, I was pleased to have played a small part in lobbying the parliamentary secretary and the government to see through some of the difficulties that existed and to ensure that the transfer of the land to the local Brisbane City Council could take place smoothly.

speech.para: I want to speak about Pooh Corner for two particular reasons. The first reason is that it is a fine example of where a genuine and relevant local community organisation and its members can work with their local federal member to achieve a very good outcome for the wider community. The second reason is that it is a fine example of how the federal government and the Brisbane City Council can work together for the good of the people they both represent in their respective ways.

Pooh Corner is a very special piece of land just outside my Ryan electorate. It is adjacent to the Ipswich Motorway, Sanananda Barracks and the Centenary Highway. The Ryan suburbs of Riverhills, Middle Park and Jamboree Heights are only minutes away by car from Pooh Cornerâs peaceful and serene environment. I was very pleased to be able to support the many Ryan residents who contacted my office to ask for my support in this matter. Pooh Corner is about 1.4 square kilometres in size and has a very high conservation value. It is a piece of real estate that is home to a large population of eastern grey kangaroos that are frequently seen eating and relaxing near Wacol Station Road. It is also a site that is home to 26 species of animals and 16 plant species that are rare and vulnerable. Clearly, the size of the land and the nature of the land meant that Pooh Corner had to be protected and preserved not only for the future residents of my Ryan electorate but for other people of Brisbane.

I mention again that the April announcement about Pooh Cornerâs future would have been a great relief to the wider community. The alternative, as I said, was that it would be sold to private developers. It was going to be put on the market for sale. Once it was purchased by a local developer, the outcome would have been, first, the decimation of an attractive and valuable piece of family friendly land. Secondly, there would have been a massive increase in the amount of traffic onto the local road network and infrastructure following construction of residential homes or units. I campaigned strongly against such a commercial transaction taking place because it was not in the best interests of the local Ryan community.

Apart from the major conservation value that the land has, it is very significant that private development on Pooh Corner would have had a tremendously negative impact on the roads in the community. The Ipswich highway and the Centenary Highway, which are very close to Pooh Cornerâin fact, adjacent to itâand Moggill Road a bit further down the road are well over capacity. They are in desperate need of major attention. The oppositionâs policy is simply to upgrade the Ipswich highway. This is, quite frankly, a bandaid solution. Together with the member for Blair, I worked very strongly with the government to come to a long-term solution that will deliver to the people who use the Ipswich Motorway a more sustainable outcome. Centenary Highway and Moggill Road in the Ryan electorate are state roads. I call on the Queensland Labor government to use some of the money from its massive GST funds on the roads in the Ryan electorate. The Queensland government is awash in funds. It has nearly $8 billion of funds out of an Australian total of $35 billion. It is high time that the Queensland government spent more of this money on the roads in Ryan. Moggill Road is desperately in need of funding. I call on the transport minister and the Queensland Premier to spend more money on the roads. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThis year 68 people have died on South Australian roads already. We had an absolutely horrible month in March, with 27 people being killed, compared with just eight people last year in the same month. The South Australian Labor government has been committed to reducing that devastating figure and has introduced legislation to crack down on dangerous driving and improve the conditions on our roads. Groups like Neighbourhood Watch, including the Morphettville Neighbourhood Watch group in the electorate of Hindmarsh, have been particularly active in calling for a crackdown on the behaviour of motorists.

speech.para: I am aware of a number of roads within the electorate of Hindmarsh which are used as racetracks by inexperienced and inconsiderate drivers. I am relieved that legislation to stop this sort of behaviour has been introduced by the Rann state Labor government. Since the laws came into effect earlier this year, 176 drivers have been reported and at least eight vehicles impounded. In 108 of those cases, motorists were reported for âsustained wheel spinâ, or burnouts, which have been causing residents sleepless nights for years.

The first phase of the reforms was introduced in February and created the new offence of misuse of a vehicle and an offence of failing to obey police orders to reduce noise from a car stereo. Both offences attract a maximum fine of $1,250, as well as other penalties. The second phase, introduced last month, gives police the power to impound for 48 hours vehicles suspected of being used for hoon drivingâeven before the matter reaches courtâas long as there are proper grounds for laying charges. Upon conviction, a court can impose a second period of impoundment. The penalty is up to three months for one prior offence and up to six months for two priors. Those with three or more prior offences risk having their vehicle forfeited permanently. The proceeds from the sale of forfeited vehicles will go directly to the Victims of Crime Fund. This is commonsense legislation, because it takes away what these drivers value mostâtheir cars. The risk of losing their lives or of hurting or killing someone else seems to mean nothing to them, but the risk of losing their car really hits home.

The state government is also targeting other irresponsible driving behaviour. Drink-drivers now face an immediate loss of licence if they are caught driving with a blood alcohol level above 0.08. Last year 36 per cent of those killed on our roads were driving with an illegal blood alcohol content, and more than half of these had levels more than three times the legal limit. Some 28 per cent had been using marijuana or amphetamines. Motorists who drink and drive are now more likely than ever to get caught, because of the Rann state Labor governmentâs changes to drink-driving laws. South Australian police can now conduct full-time mobile random breath testing. The risk of immediately losing their licence might make a difference to people who are too stupid to take a taxi instead of driving home when they have had too much to drink. If it is not enough of an incentive, then at least it will get a few of these fools off the roads and make it safer for other people who are doing the right thing.

South Australia is aiming to reduce its road toll by 40 per cent by 2010. This yearâs toll already makes that a huge challenge. In 2003 the state Labor government in South Australia introduced restricted mobile random breath testing, which is only allowed at certain times of the year, because the Liberal opposition refused to support full-time testing. Since then South Australian police have detected more drink drivers than when they were limited to stationary breath testing units. Because it was a success the government tried again to convince the Liberal opposition to allow police to mobile breath test all year around and this time the state Labor government succeeded.

The new legislation means that if you get caught driving between 0.05 and 0.079 more than once you lose your licence. If you get caught with a blood alcohol level between 0.08 and 0.149 you lose your licence immediately for at least six months. If you are driving with a blood alcohol count higher than 0.15 you lose your licence for at least 12 months, effective immediately. There are no second chances for people killed in car accidents; why should there be second chances for people who are a risk to themselves and others on the road?

This year the state government has also allocated a further $40 million over the next four years to improve the chances of catching drivers who speed or run red lights. Red light cameras reduce the number of casualty crashes, and over the next four years there will be 48 new cameras installed around South Australia. On urban roads the speed limit has been reduced to 50 kilometres per hour, which reduces the risk of crashes and the sort of damage they cause. Of course, road crashes are not just about driver behaviour; road conditions are also a factor and it would be great if the federal government would look more closely at its responsibilities to improve road safety in South Australia.

In closing I would like to thank the many residents and community groups who have raised their concerns about driver behaviour with me over the years, both as a candidate and as their local federal member. The feedback they have provided to me, and to other members of parliament, provided the information and input required to get something done about dangerous driving. Now when we report hoons to the police in South Australia, the police can do something about it.

talk.start.para: âTwo extraordinary individuals from the bayside of Queensland were recognised this year with Australia Day awards: Helen Elmslie is the first and the second is Mary Preston. Mary Prestonâs work with the Coochiemudlo Island Bush Care Group dates back 10 years when their love of the island spurred them to form a group of 20 who would fight to protect the glorious foreshore of Coochiemudlo Island. They were concerned about exposed root systems and damage to ecology and habitats. Their work over 10 years has shown that they have achieved enormous steps not only in education and in encouraging young groups to take an interest in ecology and the environment but also in practical improvements. Together with Redland Shire Council, who I know they will be thanking, their workers, the division 10 councillor Peter Downing and the staff of Indigiscapes they have, where necessary, fenced off fragile areas of the coastline and conducted annual curlew counts, weed for tree programs and, most importantly, adopt-a-coastline so the residents of Coochiemudlo Island can reconnect with their own foreshore in a practical way.

speech.para: Probably the best way of measuring their achievements is that this year their foreshore management plan has been submitted to the state government and is awaiting approval at this time. Should you ever visit Coochiemudlo Island, which is Aboriginal for red rock, if you find Mary Preston down by the foreshore she will probably invite you in for a cup of tea to talk about how the island is going. It is no better exemplified than in the words of poet Mary OâBrien:

quote.para: If I could be a mermaid with tail strings of glossy brown kelp rescued from Morwong Beach Iâd learn to dip and sway to the rhythm of the moon as you do together we could shimmer restless oceans from shore to shore sharing songs and dreamsâ until one day soon weâd find ourselves again lapping the fringes of Coochiemudloâs beachesâ

speech.para: Helen Elmslie has had an extraordinary life in the Moreton Bay area. Born in Sudbury, Massachusetts, in 1938, she travelled out to Queensland to complete her zoology undergraduate degree. After defending her thesis in the United States she returned to marry her husband, Leo, have four children and live in the historic township of Dunwich on North Stradbroke Island. From there her two great passions were art and the environmentâand her life is one of opening the door for hundreds of people to both of those. It was her children, Daniel, David, Virginia and Leona, and their love of the intertidal mudflats, with its shags, cormorants and sea snails, that drew her down to the water to share her zoological knowledge. Soon there were school groups following in their footsteps. She spent a number of years on her passion for art with the North Stradbroke art and craft group.

In 1962 she moved across to Ormiston and joined the Yurara art group where they were running Mount Gravatt TAFE courses in art for art and design students. There she met Robert Barnes, an inspiration to her, and she began teaching art and art history. Of course, one of the great disadvantages of teaching art is that you do not have enough time to do it yourself. So in the early 1990s Helen decided to open an art gallery in Manly. From there she became an institution in the area, painting on the footpaths and down by the waterside. She won Redlands Shire Council awards in 1991 and 1992; had a joint exhibition at the Manly Gallery in 1993; in 1994 was featured artist with the Redlands art and craft festival; and in 1995 had a sole exhibition at Manly Gallery and was featured artist for the Manly sailing festival.

In 1996 Helen Elmslie was diagnosed with Parkinsonâs disease. We all know her commitment and energy to tasks throughout her life. This was no different. She joined Parkinsonâs Queensland and thought about helping those who lived with Parkinsonâs. She developed a board game called Parkinsonâs Daily Olympics. It is her hope that that will now be distributed free through Parkinsonâs Queensland to schools, nursing homes and doctors surgeries around the country. Helen Elmslie is a woman who has shared her love of art and her love of nature with hundreds of people in the Moreton Bay region. She was awarded an Australia Day award, as was Mary Preston with her Coochiemudlo Island Bush Care Group. I congratulate them both for their awards and for devoting their lives to their passions on the bayside.

talk.start.para: âI would like to use the time that is left to congratulate the federal Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Pru Goward, on the discussion paper Striking the balance: women, men, work and family, which was released and widely reported today. The paper is about prompting submissions to HREOCâs inquiry into paid work and family responsibilities. The paper shows that the balance between work and family is just not there currently and that is especially the case for working women. The paper shows in stark figures that women employed full time are putting in 14.3 hours per week of unpaid work in the home and women employed part time are putting in 20.1 hours per week of work into the home, compared to six hours and 5.2 hours respectively for men employed full time and part time. While this situation continues, it is a serious issue not just for those exhausted families trying to cope with the juggling act but for Australia generally.
âOrder! It being 8 pm, the debate is interrupted.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. IR Causley) took the chair at 9.30 am

talk.start.para: âThis coming Saturday, 25 June, I will have the great honour of launching Ron Ritterâs latest labour of love, Triumph, Tragedy and Port Adelaide, a history of the port. And what an authentic history it is. We all know the cliches about history: to the victors the capture of history, the narrative captures the history, and so on. This history is nothing like that. As I said earlier, it is authentic; it is a labour of love. It is nine years since I launched Ron Ritterâs previous work, Spanning Time and Tide, now sold out at the Port Adelaide Sailing Club.

speech.para: This second book continues the virtues of his first book: authenticity, accuracy, sound research and the presentation of rare photographs. However, it deals with a much broader range of topics, which include the following: the Port Adelaide New Yearâs Day regatta; the history of Black Diamond Corner; leisure time activities at Semaphore and Largs Bay beaches; the circumstances surrounding Tragedy Dock; the fire and explosion on SS City of Singapore; Fletchers Slip, South Australiaâs first slipway; the 1928 waterside workers strike; the saga of Outer Harbor and much more.

On this last matter, the building of the Outer Harbor gave my grandfather Walter, Wattie, a second nickname: the Punt Man. Prior to the building of the Outer Harbor, my grandfather worked for the Marine and Harbours Board. After storms it was my grandfatherâs job to recover the punts that broke away from their moorings, and he did this single-handedly in a longboat with oars, oar over the stern. In his book, Ron refers to Sawfordâs crew on Native winning the working menâs race at the port regatta in 1895 and my grandfather being beaten by Robert Angelinowich in a dinghy sculling race, oar over the stern, in ketches for a prize of 30 shillings. He would not have been too happy about that.

Ron Ritterâs book Triumph, Tragedy and Port Adelaide makes a significant contribution to the history of Port Adelaide. It must be said that a great deal of the history of the port has been lost and that our ancestors did not always record what we would have likedâthe quite remarkable history of Port Adelaide. That loss has been addressed in recent years by the Friends of the Maritime Museum in their magnificent publication Port Adelaide Tales from a Commodious Harbour by John Couper-Smartt and Christine Courtney.

Ron Ritter continues that tradition. He is to be heartily congratulated. He has researched topics thoroughly for nine years in his spare time and funded his bookâs publication in South Australia. Hyde Park Press of Richmond has done an excellent job; and good friend Errol Chinner edited the book. The foreword was written by Brian Samuels, who, more than any other person, has encouraged the written history of Port Adelaide. The launch will most appropriately take place in the South Australian Maritime Museum, Port Adelaide, this Saturday, 23 June at three oâclock in the afternoon. I very much look forward to launching this most invaluable history of Port Adelaide, by a man who has shown again his great love for Port Adelaide. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise today to support the work of Reynella East High School, a local high school in my electorate of Kingston, and in particular to make my colleagues aware of a project within the school that will send 10 students to Sri Lanka to assist with the rebuilding process in areas which were affected by the Boxing Day tsunami. The group of 10 students, accompanied by three staff members, will be leaving on 2 July for just over two weeks, returning on 17 July. Three projects will be undertaken by the group. The first task will be making bricks at the Maharagama National Youth Centre. Once completed, the bricks will be donated to various housing projects in Galle.

speech.para: The second project involves working at Lake Maduganga Environment Education Camp. Here students will be clearing tracks, working on simple construction tasks and assisting with the rebuilding of local housing. Finally, the students will be going on a three-day adventure expedition. During the trip, the students from Reynella East will be linking up with students at Nalanda College. These students will then be visiting Australia later in the year as part of a reciprocal exchange with Reynella East High School. The school has fundraised for the trip, and, as part of their curriculum, students are learning about Sri Lankan culture. The trip is being organised through the Duke of Edinburghâs Award and Ausquest. Students, staff and their families are attending cultural nights sponsored by Adelaideâs Sri Lankan community in their temple at Oaklandâs Park.

This nation saw a massive outpouring of support for the nations devastated by the tsunami, but it is so easy to forget the tragedy once the news images stop and there are no longer any phone polls seeking support. This school in my electorate still remembers those who suffered and are still suffering in the tragedy on Boxing Day. The school is going to lend a hand in the rebuilding effort. I congratulate the students and staff at Reynella East High School for this very generous effort, and I congratulate their principal, Rob Mutton, on this outstanding effort. It is with great pride that I stand here today as their local federal representative.

talk.start.para: âI rise to condemn the continued indefinite detention of David Hicks at Guantanamo Bay and the lack of effort on the part of this government to have him returned to Australia. I wrote an article in the Australian on 15 January 2003, and I have raised the issue on a number of occasions. Mr Hicks was captured by the US military in Afghanistan in November 2001. It is now 3Â½ years later. What is known is that Mr Hicks did not contravene any Australian law as it was then. A special American process has been defined for him, and others, where he has been labelled an âunlawful combatantâ. That was done so that he might be excluded from the protections of the Geneva Convention.

speech.para: The US government has sought to use Guantanamo Bay, a piece of Cuban sovereign territory leased to the United States, to create a legal black hole where people can be excluded from the American judicial process and not have the protections of the American constitution. Guantanamo Bay should never have been established. Charges have been delayed due to appeals, and there is a question mark over the charges Mr Hicks currently faces. He should be released and returned to Australia.

There is a suggestion that there are some continued security concerns about Mr Hicks. These should be dealt with by ASIO if and when he is returned to Australia. He should be subject to Australian law as it stands today. We cannot condone the continued indefinite detention of an Australian citizen on the basis that there is some perceived threat to security. This is a national disgrace. Australian citizenship must count for something. Americans cannot be detained under this process, so Australian citizens at Guantanamo Bay are subject to second-class laws. Unlawful combatants are second-class citizens.

American citizens must be dealt with under the American constitution. The Australian government must demand Mr Hicksâs immediate return to Australia. I repeat: he is being kept over there because there are no charges that can be laid within Australia. That is the paradoxâwe are punishing an Australian citizen because he did not breach any Australian laws in place at the time of his detention. It is inexcusable and it cannot go on.

talk.start.para: âThis morning I propose a five-point plan to help with the development of the wonderful town of Baxter. Baxter is a tremendous town. People work hard and retired people and young families live there. In many ways Baxter has not been given the full respect and full resourcing that it deserves.

speech.para: The first of the five points is that we want to work to ensure that there are additional aged care places to meet local demands. Point 1 is all about aged care for Baxter. The Baxter village, which has now passed from the electorate of Flinders to Dunkley, does a tremendous job and it has been getting great support from the member for Dunkley, Bruce Billson. I am delighted to be working with Bruce on providing assistance with aged care places for Baxter and the surrounding area.

The second issue that I want to raise is about working to deliver additional before school and after school child-care places for Baxter. This town has a lot of working parents, a lot of two-parent working families, and child care is an issue that needs to be focused on. One of the things that I want to doâand we have already been able to deliver some significant results for Baxter Primary Schoolâis to work with the primary school and with any other providers on additional out of school hours care places for children. I think that is very important.

The third thing I want to do is look at the facilities for both the preschool and Baxter Primary School. Baxter Primary School is a well-managed school. I think we can work with them through Work for the Dole projects or through other forms of assistance to try to upgrade some of the local facilities. I think that is important. We have already had tremendous success through a formal Commonwealth program with upgrading the facilities at Baxter preschool. But we can go further, and I have already spoken to the leaders at Baxter preschool about that.

The fourth pointâa critical one for Baxterâis working to upgrade the dangerous Baxter-Tooradin, Hawkins and Fultons roads intersection. It is a dangerous intersection, and everybody in the area knows it. It is one of Victoriaâs principal black spots, and we will keep pushing until this is properly upgraded. This leads to the fifth and final point, that we need to upgrade the train station and beautify itâexactly the same sort of thing that we are proposing at Hastings. Taken together, these five points in terms of aged care, child care, the schools, the roads and the rail hub will all work to make Baxter an even better place. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on a matter that is causing residents in the electorate of Hindmarsh a great deal of grief. The Adelaide airport land is a large area right in the centre of the electorate, surrounded by about 15,000 homes. Unlike many airports around the world, Adelaide airport is located just six kilometres from the CBD. That is great if you are getting on or off a plane, but for the people who live next door it is not without its problems. Aircraft noise has been an issue for some time, but more recently another challenge has emerged. The land has been made available for commercial development.

speech.para: The federal Minister for Transport and Regional Services last year signed off on a master plan for the airport land which includes provisions for non-aviation related development, including retail, recreational and commercial uses. Because the land is owned by the Commonwealth, it is not a requirement that development on the land comply with state or local government planning laws. The upshot of this is that residents often feel powerless to make a difference when developments that affect them get under way. But the Adelaide airport developments are also creating a very active and aware community, and residents are not taking these things lying down. Instead, communities are becoming increasingly active. There are about six very active residentsâ groups around the airport, but today I only have time to mention two.

Recently, a group of residents in West Beach became aware that the Adelaide Airport Club would be relocated opposite their homes. Unhappy with this decision, they rallied together and formed a residentsâ group. Before long, they came to see me. They also spoke with Adelaide Airport Ltd and with their local councillors and their state MP, the member for West Torrens, Tom Koutsantonis. They have also written to the federal Minister for Transport and Regional Services. I was pleased that Adelaide Airport Ltd, particularly the Managing Director, Phil Baker, was prepared to discuss this issue at length with residents and with me, and he has been willing to request that the club makes several changes to the plans for the new premises so as to reduce the impact on residents.

The residentsâ group has also collected hundreds of signatures from those living in the immediate area and asked me to table their petition opposing the relocation, which I was able to do earlier this week. The core members of this group have dedicated their time and energy to fighting this decision and to representing the many other residents in the area who would be affected by it. Already, they have achieved much. Efforts are now under way to ensure that the clubâs licence recognises the needs of local residents.
