Another challenge for local residents is that which faces the Netley residentsâ group. Whitegoods and electronics manufacturer, LG, has a warehouse on the Adelaide airport land opposite residents. Residents have repeatedly raised concerns about noise at the warehouse, and now the developer, Australand, wants to expand the building. I am told the expansion plans are not consistent with what is outlined in the master plan, and residents have every right to be up in arms about the proposal. In the interests of good corporate citizenship, I believe Australand should think again. Their plan is not within the intent of the master plan, and the residents are far from happy about it. Given the track record of the residents living around the airport, I would advise Australand to bow out early and gracefully, because these residents understand how to be part of a democracy and take action.

There will be many challenges like this for residents in the coming years. They knew they were moving in next to an airport when they bought their houses but they did not know that they would be living next to factories, warehouses and enormous retail outlets. They did not know that they would be woken up in the middle of the night by forklifts dropping their loads on concrete floors or by security alarms that are set to deafen intruders. So they will fight for their rights. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI place on record that I am pro-life and I am certainly opposed to the Medicare funding of abortions. I want today to commend Senator Santo Santoro for a meeting he organised here in Parliament House yesterday at which the Rev. Dr John Fleming and Selena Ewing from the Southern Cross Bioethics Institute were present. There is currently going on in Australia a new debate based on common ground, as Dr Fleming and Ms Ewing said on issuing their media release yesterday, and a path forward is rapidly replacing the pro-life versus pro-choice debate. I quote from the media release:

quote.para: âPhase One of our research found that the overwhelming majority of Australians believe the number of abortions is too high, and 87% want that number reduced without restricting legal access to the procedure,â...

âPhase Two of our research examined exactly how the number of abortions could be reduced. Australians were clear that we first need to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies through education/information and helping women manage risk, and secondly we need to offer pregnant women more options so that abortion becomes the option of last resort.
âPopular options for pregnant women included changes to policies on taxation, health and welfare; as well as options such as counselling, better information and family/community support,â...
Dr Fleming said there was considerable discussion about counselling including:
That counselling should be available on the alternatives to abortion as well as on the risks associated with the abortion procedure
That there was strong support for further funding for counselling services
That Australians believe health professions should be more active in providing information, advice and support for pregnant women
That counselling should be provided on an optional basis

âThere is considerable common ground amongst Australians in their respect for motherhood and their desire to move forward with the debate on abortion. We believe this data, the second phase in a four phase project, provides the evidence and opportunity for change,â...

speech.para: Senator Santoro has suggested that, prior to Medicare funded abortion procedures taking place, there ought to be mandatory access to Medicare funded independent professional counselling. Many Australians believe that there are too many abortions in this country and that more options should be given to women. They should be aware of what is available to them. At the present time I believe that many women are being pushed into abortions when they have not considered the available alternatives. I want to commend Senator Santoro, Dr Fleming and Ms Ewing on their contribution to this very important debate involving the lives of unborn Australians.

talk.start.para: âI rise to bring the attention of the House to the Howard governmentâs litany of deception and distortions when it comes to their proposed detention centre at Pinkenba, in the Lilley electorate. I rise to inform the House of the governmentâs broken promise to engage in genuine consultation with the people of Lilley on their plans to build this unwanted detention centre at Pinkenba and to report on the continuing indifference of the government towards the legitimate concerns of local residents.

speech.para: The government has finally owned up and admitted that it recently bought the Damascus Barracks site in Pinkenba in late May to build a 550-bed medium-security detention centre. This is a significant revelation because it confirms the governmentâs determination to force a medium-security prison of 550 beds onto an unwilling local community. Since 2001 the government has refused to come clean with the people and to reveal its plans for the site. There has been one deliberate deception after anotherâone thing said before the election and entirely another thing said after it. There has been underhanded sneakiness of the highest order.

During the 2001 election, Minister Ruddock promised that the government had no intention of forcing a detention centre on an unwilling community and that any decisions that would be taken would be taken after the completion of the community consultation processes. They gave residents hopeâfalse hope in the endâthat the government would take on board their views. But clearly this was all window-dressing of a decision that had already been made. Two public meetings in the electorate and 90 per cent of residents surveyed voiced their opposition to a detention centre at Pinkenba, but the governmentâs mind was made up. After the 2001 election, Minister Ruddock wrote to me in July 2002 and said that they would go ahead with their plans whether locals approved or not. So the people of Lilley quickly learned that the government would say and do anything to get them through an election.

It was the same old story before and after the 2004 election. Before the election Minister Vanstone denied that a decision had been taken on the centre at Pinkenba, but the budget documents after the election belled the cat, showing that money had been set aside for the project. Of course, this was confirmed when the government purchased the Damascus Barracks site in the last month or so. The people of Lilley will not forget the lies and the distortions of the Howard government when it comes to Pinkenba, especially those local residents who have fought hard against this proposed detention centre, including Margo Canavan, Betty Baldwin and Sandy Spadotto.

Now that the government have admitted to buying the site without any meaningful consultation they are one stop closer to building a medium-security prison right within the metropolitan area. Building this detention centre in the middle of a built-up community is simply ridiculous. It is even more ridiculous, given what the government have been saying more recently about the nature of detention. I just do not see the need to continue with a 550-bed medium-security prison for the centre if their policy has changed fundamentally. The government like to pretend that this facility is only for visa overstayers, but there are very few of those each night in Brisbane. This is not some small holding centre; this is a fully-fledged, 550-bed medium-security prison located close to the airport and close to built-up communities. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOn Friday evening I met with a number of local charter fishing operators who are very concerned about the proposed impost of some $30,000 per vessel in annual costs to their chartering operations being determined by the state government. While I understand the need to tighten maritime regulations and introduce a sense of uniformity to national navigational and safety guidelines, the blanket application of these rules without reference to local maritime conditions or safety conditions is draconian and deeply unfair to local business people. The new rules, which are contained within part D of the National Standard for Commercial Vessels, came out of four years of work by the National Marine Safety Committee. This process sought to review and replace the uniform shipping laws and provide an updated framework upon which state and territory governments could base new codes. Part D provides for a national standard of crew competency as well as standards for minimum adequate crewing levels.

speech.para: Most of the charter fishing vessels operating out of the shire do so on a shoestring budget. Often these businesses are operated by people who have retired from their principal job and use their charter business as a way of ensuring they have fuel in their boat and a modest income in retirement. In other cases these businesses are full-time professional careers for residents trying to support young families. Adding between $30,000 and $90,000 to the annual operating costs of these businesses will ensure that most of the small operators will be forced out of businessâin the short term and at great personal financial loss.

The National Standard for Commercial Vessels does specify a minimum crew, but it also specifically provides for local equivalent solutions for crewing. I put it to the New South Wales Maritime Authority that it is within their power to ensure the continued viability of these local small businesses. When framing these kinds of rules, clauses that provide for a local solution are not inserted merely for fun; they are drafted to provide for specific instances of where risks are lower. In an area like Cronulla, where the boats are operating within sight of land and close to the best rescue facilities in Australia, I firmly support a local equivalent solution. There is no pressing safety requirement for these changes. There have been no fatalities in New South Wales waters which have been the result of a lack of crew. The only recent death on a charter fishing vessel was at Narooma in 2003, when the vessel capsized while crossing Narooma bar. In Cronulla, Botany Bay and Sydney Harbour there are no bars to cross, with deep channel entries to the ocean circumventing these kinds of problems. The New South Wales government and the New South Wales Maritime Authority need to look at proposals from local boat operators in a constructive way to ensure that they do not drive local operators out of business.

talk.start.para: âIn the Australian parliament today I wish to pay tribute to three local identities in Logan City who all gained life membership of the Australian Labor Party at the most recent ALP state conference held in Cairns. They are Wes Young, Michael Eborn and Don Wilkie.

speech.para: Wes Young joined the party 35 years ago in 1970. In 1976 he transferred from the Acacia Ridge branch to Woodridge branch. Wes has never sought an official position within the ALP, but whenever he was called upon to provide any voluntary assistance he was always happy to do so, often manning single-person booths in the olden days. Wes is a very valued member of the party and also of the broader community. He has a talent that, for reasons best known to Wes, he himself has hidden, and that is that he is a very well-performed singer. We had the pleasure of listening to Wes on one occasion in my office and I would encourage Wes to display his talents more often. He is a great contributor and good on Wes for the contribution that he has made already over 35 years.

The second person rewarded with life membership at the state conference in Queensland was Michael Eborn. Michael is one of natureâs gentlemen. He is always available and volunteers to help. Within the ALP he has organised all of the branches in the state seat of Woodridge for more years than most of us can remember. But, in a sense more importantly, Michael is a great contributor to the broader community. He is a regular attender at St Bernadineâs church, a terrific guy and, I think, an ornament to the local community in Logan City. He has made an enormous contribution, very quietly going about his business but always available to help those who need a helping hand.

The third of the three amigos is Don Wilkie. Don too is a very gentle soul. Don works in my office. I met him in the early 1990s when I was being introduced into the local area of Woodridge. There were a lot of tough nuts in the suburb of Woodridge but Don had lived in and around the area for many years and he introduced me to the local characters there and that ultimately led to my preselection and entering parliament. Don has enriched the lives of so many people, particularly migrants, because he works very hardâand I must say very successfullyâon family reunion programs. It is just so delightful to see the beaming faces of people when Don is able to help them. So good on all three of them.

talk.start.para: âI rise in the Main Committee to draw attention to the issue of the Pacific Highway, a major element of our transport infrastructure that is producing problems along the east coast of Australia. Certainly within my electorate, and particularly in the community of Coffs Harbour, the issues of traffic congestion and the high rate of accidents along the highway are causing great concern. I welcomed a visit to Coffs Harbour on 27 May 2005 by the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr John Anderson, to discuss issues about the Pacific Highway with local government representatives and concerned members of the business community. I am pleased that the federal government is currently working hard to negotiate an ongoing 10-year agreement for the continued upgrade of the highway. I think it is vital that this work continue just as quickly as possible. I certainly welcomed the announcement last year of $765 million to continue the upgrade of the road until 2008-09. This is vital work that just needs to occur.

speech.para: One particular item of local infrastructure that can substantially assist traffic flows and substantially improve safety around Coffs Harbour is the completion of the Hogbin Drive extension. This road runs parallel to the existing highway, and completing the last elements of this road has the capacity to take some 15,000 cars a day off the Pacific Highway and allow for separation of local traffic from highway traffic. It is vitally important that people going about their local business are able to travel an alternative route to the highway and be separated from the large numbers of heavy vehicles that are commuting along the Pacific Highway.

Council has already invested a substantial amount of funds in completing the northern section of this road but there is still one missing link in the project which will cost in the order of $15 million. If that section of road were completed we would see an improvement in traffic flows along the highway, a reduction in the road congestion around the Bray Street intersection and an improvement in the environment around the jetty area by removing some of the traffic which flows through that very fashionable jetty area of Coffs Harbour. A further substantial benefit would be that travel times would be dramatically reduced, particularly from the airport to the resort developments on the northern side of Coffs Harbour.

The completion of the Hogbin Drive extension will have substantial benefits through reduced congestion, improved safety and improved environment within the city of Coffs Harbour. It is a project that must go ahead. I have certainly been lobbying the Deputy Prime Minister to see in what ways the federal government can assist to provide funding for this much-needed road upgrade. A partnership between state, federal and local government could achieve this much-needed work and these improvements in environmental outcomes and in traffic flows that our community so greatly desires and so greatly needs. I think that it is a vital piece of infrastructure that must be completed. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âIn accordance with the resolution agreed to on 21 June 2005, the time for membersâ statements has concluded.

subdebateinfo.title: Economics, Finance and Public Administration Committee

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 23 May, on motion by Mr Baird:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to comment on the committeeâs report, which focused on the first public hearing with the Reserve Bank governor since the formation of the 41st Parliament. Importantly, these hearings provide for public interchange and go some way towards satisfying the expectation that, although the Reserve Bank should make its decisions independently of government, monetary policy decisions should have some degree of transparency and accountability, given their potential impact on all Australians.

speech.para: In his statement, the Reserve Bank governor gave an overall picture of the national economy that was somewhat different from the rosy view we get in parliament from the Treasurer. But the main interest is always in the movement of interest rates, and at that hearing it was clearly evident that rates would riseâas they did in March, when they rose by 25 points, remaining at that level since.

Significantly, the Governor of the RBA departed from standard practice and expressed concerns regarding some imbalances in the economy. He gave a clear signal to the government that, while monetary policy could influence the interplay between demand and supply to maintain economic growth, only the government could institute reform that would reposition the economy and allow it to take full advantage of the economic opportunities presented. The governor claimed that, without reform to address capacity constraints, infrastructureâespecially ports and export transport chainsâand skills, the risk of wage increases was high and the ability to maintain commodity and resource export levels could be compromised.

Inconsistency in economic indicators was also canvassed by the committee when it was revealed that 2004 GDP growth actually came in at 1.5 per cent, much lower than the forecast of 3.75 per cent. This clearly suggested to some committee members that a slowdown was occurring and that therefore an interest rate rise would not be justified. However, the governor was of the view that anecdotal evidence suggested consumption and demand were continuing to increase, and that was worrying to him. Interestingly, the ABS have since revised their retail sales figures upwards for the last years, apologising for their deviation from their usual high standard of reliable statistics. However, upward trends in retail sales, consumer confidence and wage growth had at the time clearly convinced the Reserve Bank that there was a need to dampen demand.

The Secretary of Treasury has put forward a conflicting view since the hearing, which is that capacity constraints and skills and infrastructure blockages will not damage the economy sharplyânor, he claims, will they fuel inflation. His confidence in the ability of the market to adapt to these constraints is not surprising, and I think the Port of Newcastle is an excellent example of that. However, it seems that any attempt to apologise for the failure of government to anticipate, plan for and respond to these important determiners of economic success through real reform would be indefensible.

At the time of the hearing it was not known to us that the May budget would take on the supply constraint challenges by offering big tax cuts to the suppliers of capital for the economyâthe wealthiest individuals, who could be counted on to increase their savings and their investments as a resultâwhile providing very small tax cuts for over seven million taxpayers, ensuring that there would be no inflationary or expansionary impact from the tax cuts. That is the lazy approach to economic reform, matched by some equally ineffectual welfare to work measures and skilled immigration increases. I anticipate that the governor will be asked about that approach to reform when we meet again in August.

I attempted unsuccessfully to gain some insight into the normalising of regional data by the Reserve Bank and into how the Reserve Bank responds to divergences in the economy. Now that area of concern has since taken on some very different dimensions. The new divergence evident in our economy is between the states, not just between the regions and the capital cities. Growth in energy- and resource-rich states like Western Australia continues to be strong, whilst growth in the most populous states of New South Wales and Victoria is significantly slowing. This is another area for future discussions with the governor.

The current account deficit and the terms of trade conundrum will require further deliberations by the committee and the Reserve Bank of Australia. It has been suggested by some analysts that this presents a new dimension in our economy. We now have greater personal wealth, greater demand and consumption, increased ease of access to our markets by other countries, a continuing strong dollar, an exchange rate that favours imports and a domestic supply that does not match our consumption tastes or our demand levels. We are learning that some of the consequences of what some infer is the âGregory effectâ may include continuing unfavourable current account deficits and lower GDP figuresâfigures which, according to the governor, we will have to become more used to.

What must also be mentioned is what was not disclosed at the initial hearing with the Reserve Bank. After the announcement of the interest rate rise in March, public statements were made by some board members suggesting that the decision to increase rates was far from unanimous. This is unusual, but perhaps points to the need for more transparency in the deliberations and decision making by the Reserve Bank. In fact, some members of the committee were interested in the deliberations that preceded the decision by the Reserve Bank not to raise interest rates in October 2004, when the housing boom was continuing apace. However, these were not disclosed.

The complaint to the AEC by the Reserve Bank regarding the governmentâs interest rate election advertising material compromising, perhaps, the independence of the RBA was not raised during the hearing. However, clearly we would like to discuss such an important issue, given the importance this country places on separation of responsibilities.

In concluding, I thank the Governor and the Reserve Bank of Australia for this important dialogue and express my appreciation to secretariat staff. I thank Bev Forbes in particular, David Richardson from the Parliamentary Library, economists Chris Richardson and Saul Eslake for their assistance to the committee. I also acknowledge the media and community interestâin particular, the presence of many high school students at the hearing.

talk.start.para: âThe closing remark of the honourable member for Newcastle, Ms Grierson, noting the large number of school students at the Reserve Bank hearing in Sydney reminds me that many of these school students have a knowledge of economics that would put most professional economists to shame. One of the most challenging experiences I have in my electorate is visiting classes of senior economics students, who subject me to a grilling, the intensity of which I would like to think the standing committee on economics might be able to emulate at some point.

speech.para: In the course of the governorâs presentation to the committee he discussed, as the member for Newcastle has observed, the current account deficit. I wish to make a few comments about the nature of the current account deficit, reflecting on the governorâs observations. The current account deficit is at a record highâthere is no question about thatâbut it is not producing a record high of anxiety either among the business community or the economics community. Some of the reasons for that were identified by the governor. Firstly, we have a floating exchange rate, which is able to absorb the changes in international investor sentiment and the changes in flows of investment around the world. That gives us a great deal more flexibility than we had in the past.

Another feature of the current account deficit, or Australiaâs foreign debt, today is that it is not denominated in a foreign currency. The vast bulk of our borrowings is either in Australian dollars or hedged into Australian dollars. So in that sense, the foreign lenders are taking the currency risk. That, of course, is an enormous change from previous periods of high current account deficits. There are two other features about the current account deficit today. Firstly, the composition of it has changed remarkably. If we go back to the early or mid-1990s, we see that the current account deficit was composed of a very large fiscal deficit. The government was running deficits. It was a net borrower. Now Laborâs debt has been largely paid off and the federal government is moving to be a net lender. So the fiscal deficit has been largely eliminated.

At the same time, in years gone by, Australian businesses were net borrowers; now they are net lenders. The switch that has occurred is with Australian households, which have gone from being net lendersâon a modest scale, to be fairâto being relatively considerably more indebted. That level of indebtedness has caused considerable concern not least to the Reserve Bank, not so much because of its impact on the current account deficit but simply because of the fact that, if households are highly leveraged, they are exposed to greater risk if financial conditions deteriorate, if income declines due to changes in the business climate or unemployment or if interest rates were to rise.

The rise in this household debt has been largely driven by the property boomâsome would say the property bubbleâand there is a very instructive analysis of this in a speech made late last year by the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank, Glenn Stevens, in which he looks at the change in Australiaâs saving/investment position as a percentage of GDP over different periods where there has been an increase in the current account deficit. What is remarkable about the last period, which he sets out as being from September 2001 to September 2004, is that, as in previous periods, there was a decline in savings and an increase in investmentâthat is what produces the deficitâbut the three per cent increase in investment, which consisted of investment in dwellings, was extraordinarily high. So, in the period from June 1997 to March 1999 there was a 2.9 per cent increase in investment as a percentage of GDP, of which only 0.7 per cent was investment in dwellings. In the more recent period, 2001-04, that change in investment was three per cent, of which 1.7 per cent was investment in dwellings. What has driven the change is our fascination with real estate. That is why, in my view, we have seen this increase in borrowings by households, because obviously homesâpropertyâare very easy to borrow against. It is much easier to borrow against bricks and mortar than it is for a business to borrow against its own cash flow.

More recently, there have been some signs that the air is leaking out of this bubble and, again, I refer to a recent speech by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, who observed that this slowing in domestic demand, which is taking pressure off the current account deficit because there is less demand for imports, is driven by change in the housing sector. In the last year we have seen a flattening of house pricesâin some markets, a declineâa slowing in mortgage lending and, so far, a relatively modest contraction in house building. All that represents a slowing in domestic demand and will, in due course, feed into a reduction in our current account deficit.

The opposition have raised the current account deficit issue and sought to criticise the government over it, but, on the several occasions I have heard the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer speak about this issue, I have never heard them identify any measures that the government should take. They have not, for example, suggested that the government should promote a recession in the manner of âthe recession we had to haveâ, which was the previous Labor tactic to address current account deficits. They have not suggested we should impose tariffs, I am pleased to hear. But they have rung the alarm bellsâ

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speakerâ
(Hon. IR Causley)âOrder! Is the member for Melbourne Ports seeking to ask a question?
âYes.
âWill the member for Wentworth allow a question?
âNo.
âCoward!

âTo return to my train of thought, the opposition when dealing with this issue has been rather like somebody that calls out âFireâ but does not nominate any exits or any measures that can be used to address this apparent emergency. Historically, the logical response for governments when facing a current account deficit has been to put their own house in order and to save themselves. The Howard government has already done that.
Mr Danby interjectingâ

âI will come to your question at the end, if that is all right. Just let me finish the point I am making, and you will then be much better informed. You may be no wiser, but you will definitely be much better informed.

speech.para: What are the measures that the government should be undertaking? In an MPI last week, the Leader of the Opposition quoted from an article in the Economist which referred to the current account deficit. Probably because of a lack of time the Leader of the Opposition was not able to refer to two other factors in that Economist article. They were the remedies or the measures that the Economist urged the Australian government to undertake. What were those? Taxation reform and workplace relations reform. Is the government undertaking those? Yes. Does the opposition support them? No.

The Economist, which was relied upon by the opposition in that MPI, also cast its own judgment on Australiaâs capacity to deal with this issue. It did so by predicting that next year the current account deficit will have been reduced from somewhere over seven per cent of GDP to around five per cent of GDPâand some forecasters estimate it will go below five per cent. What that very distinguished economic journal was saying was that the economic reform measures that the government should be undertaking to deal with the current account deficitâamong other thingsâare exactly the measures that this government is undertaking and exactly the measures that are opposed by the Labor Party. The Economist cast its own judgment into the future and expected that those measures would be successful.

Before I accept the question from my friend the member for Melbourne Ports, I make one last observation on the importance of tax reform. It is quite clear that a major driver of the property boom has been the fact that, for taxpayers on higher incomes in higher brackets, leveraged negative geared property investments have offered a very attractive form of tax-effective investment. That has been the subject of commentary by a wide range of commentatorsânot least among them, the Reserve Bank governor himself. There was a very perceptive article in the Financial Review on 20 June, which made the observation that in the budget we saw a welcome reversal of adverse recent trends in policy towards household saving. The author, Geoffrey Kingston, said:

quote.para: By abolishing the superannuation surcharge and cutting the proportion of households exposed to the top two marginal rates, it offers big incentives for middle Australia to save less for retirement via leveraged property and more via superannuation.
It should help remedy the inordinate 63 per cent of our private net worth locked up in dwelling assets and the upsurge in our foreign debt to 50 per cent of GDP.

In these ways, the 2005-06 budget truly brings home the bacon. Assuming the budget fulfils its promise of lifting savings in vehicles other than leveraged property, the task of future budgets will be to reinforce success.

talk.start.para: âIs the member for Melbourne Ports seeking to ask a question?
âYes.
âWill the member for Wentworth allow a question?
âYes.

âIn his discussion about the ways of fixing the current account deficit, I ask the member for Wentworth: does he agree with US congressmen who argue that floating the Chinese currencyâthe yuanâwould be a way of handling their countryâs deficit and might have an effect on ours. What is your attitude to the floating of the yuan?

âThat is a question which will take a little while to answer. You might regret asking it. America has a very different relationship with China than Australia does. America has a wide range of manufacturing industries which are subject to increasing competition from China. Chinaâs competitiveness in the manufacturing sector is extraordinary and, obviously, if the yuan is revalued, that will make, prima facie, Chinese exports to America more expensive. That is obviously what American manufacturers seek.

speech.para: There is a very interesting dimension to Chinaâs manufacturing journey from Australiaâs point of view. One of the reasons our terms of trade have improved is not simply because the price of our raw material has increased but because the price of our imports, particularly manufactured goods from Chinaâthe worldâs leading manufacturer nowadaysâhave decreased. (Extension of time granted.) Chinaâs ability to produce higher value, more complex manufactured goods, which have traditionally come from higher cost countries, will not only impact adversely on manufacturers in the United States but also benefit Australiaâs terms of trade. We will benefit from that because, of course, we are not producing those capital goods and equipment ourselves anyway.

talk.start.para: âLike cars.

âI make the observation for the member for Melbourne Ports that China is already a big producer of motor cars. There are obviously risks and threats from China to everybody in its domination of the manufacturing universe, but the risks to the United States are considerably greater than ours and the opportunities for Australia outweigh the risks. As Chinaâs manufacturing activities move into higher value products, there is likely to be a continued improvement in our terms of trade both as the price of imports declines and as demand for our raw material exports from China increases.

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Mr Hartsuyker) adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation Committee

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 14 March, on motion by Mr Barresi:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

talk.start.para: âI rise to comment on the report Working for Australiaâs future: increasing participation in the workforce tabled in the House some months ago. This report, the result of a significant amount of work by 10 members of the House of Representatives, points to some of the deficiencies we have currently in the way in which the government is handling very important matters and provides the government with an opportunity to attend to those deficiencies in its policy.

speech.para: First, I would like to express my appreciation to all members of the committee, who worked long and hard to produce a very significant report. In particular, I would like to extend my appreciation to the chair of the committee, the member for Deakin, who led the committee well in its proceedings. I would also like to make particular reference to the members for Calwell, Shortland, Swan, Brisbane and Canberra, and the shadow minister for small business, Tony Burke, who also participated. This effort has covered two terms of this parliament. The report had its inception in the last parliamentary term, but much of the analysis and construction of the report, based on the evidence before the committee, was done in this term. So there are a number of members to thank. Along with the member for Deakin, there were certainly other government members who put a lot of time and effort into ensuring that this important committee handed down a very broad-ranging report on increasing participation in our work force.

Parliamentary committees are a very important function of democracy and of our system. I am concerned about the revelations that were outlined by the Sydney Morning Herald on Monday and since thenâand I understand that they may continueâthat have highlighted the failure by government to respond to the majority of committee reports in recent years. I am most concerned about that because parliamentary committees are a reflection of how democratic our institution is. If the findings of parliamentary committees are not properly responded to and respected, it means the parliament is not being respected. I should not have to remind the government that enshrined in the Constitution are not only powers to the executive but also separate powers to the parliament. With the coming 1 July change to the composition of the Senate and the governmentâs political opportunities in having majorities in both houses, today is a good time to remind the governmentâin light of the Sydney Morning Heraldâs articles on the abject failure by government to respond to parliamentary committeesâthat they have an obligation, not only by convention but pursuant to the Constitution, to respond to and respect the parliament and not allow the executive to run roughshod over the parliament. I say that because, as the member for Deakin already outlined, there are many unanimous recommendations in this report that go to fundamental issues concerning our economy. Yes, it is true to say that there were some significant areas of disagreement and dissent. Indeed, four membersâopposition members, it so happensâfelt the need to dissent particularly in areas that went to how industrial relations and disability pensions operate.

I will firstly focus upon those areas that we agreed upon, because government and Labor members of the committee agreed on 20 of the 23 recommendations. I want to touch upon a number of them. The committee got it right when it said there was a real need for us to attend to the skills crisis in this country. The committee made some recommendations, firstly by listening to evidence not only from the ACTU and social institutions like ACOSS but from peak employer bodies, who quite clearly said that their No. 1 concern in the workplace was not industrial relations but the skills shortagesâthe skills that workers need for us to respond to the changes in the economy. We now know that there has been a revolution in the workplace as a result of the changes in our economy as a result of a rapid change precipitated by what is called globalisation. Indeed, the newer economies are growing at a much faster rate than what are termed the older economies. But unfortunately, the government has failed to anticipate the skills required. Therefore, it is brave, wise and proper that not only Labor members of the committee but also government members of the committee point to those deficiencies.
Recommendation 2 is:

quote.para: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government in cooperation with the State and Territory governments, industry, unions and educational bodies expand programs to maximise the uptake of apprenticeships in areas of skills shortages and ensure that the training is relevant to the apprentices, the businesses and the industry.

speech.para: That recommendation seeks to attend to the deficiencies that we currently experience and to get the executive of the parliament to respond to our concerns. Whilst there was passing reference by the Treasurer to some of these things, we think that what should have happened, if the executive had been listening to the parliament, is that the executiveâindeed the Treasurer on budget nightâshould have announced in the budget in the second week in May some comprehensive response in the area of skill shortages and taken up the recommendations made by opposition and government members in relation to skills. Unfortunately they fell on deaf ears. We do not really believe to date that the government has properly responded to this recommendation or incorporated it into its thinking and its policy. There have been a lot of words spoken about skill shortages but little proper response. The government would be wise to start considering our recommendations in that area.
The committee recommended unanimously:

quote.para: ... that the Australian Government establish, as a priority, a dedicated cross-portfolio approach to develop a coordinated long-term strategy, including a series of newly funded programs and defined outcomes, to address national skills shortages.

speech.para: We believe there has to be some proactive intervention by the government to attend to the deficiencies in the economy, to attend to a matter that they have neglected for nine years and to really start anticipating what every other commentator and participant in the economy has already anticipatedâthat is, as the economy evolves and as the skills mix requirements change, we must be proactive in anticipating those changes. Indeed, I applaud the government members who have come to that realisation, although they had no choice in this regard because they listened to the evidence. The evidence from the ACTU and ACOSS and, more significantly, the peak employer bodies was that employers have major problems in finding people to undertake new work and work that is evolving and developing in our economy. I do want to applaud all members of the committee in finding common ground in that area.

I also want to quickly touch upon some other recommendations. There was a recommendation for the government to attend to the effective marginal tax rates. We really believe, again, that this was another opportunity lost by the Treasurer and by the government. It is very clear to us now that the effective marginal tax rates are way too high for lower to middle-income earners. They are effectively an institutionalised, entrenched disincentive to find employment, when you have a combination of taxes and subsidies that could actually lead to people paying 70 per cent and 80 per cent. In fact, there was one situation where the combination of an amount of income, youth allowance and Newstart allowance actually resulted in a 104 per cent tax impost upon a person. So in fact they lost money when they worked.

I moved a motion in the House in 2003 on effective marginal tax rates and the need to reduce them. The committee has recommended that that matter be attended to. Again, six government members, along with four Labor members, agreed that the government should attend to this matter so that those people on middle and lower incomes who are in receipt of some government assistance would not be penalised because they seek work. Again, instead of looking to mitigate the problems associated with that matter, the government has decided to ignore the fundamental concern here, give 45 per cent of the $24 billion to 10 per cent of income earners and really not address the systemic problems in our tax system. I do applaud the wisdom, courage and good sense of all members of the committee in relation to those matters.

I turn now very briefly to the three areas of dissent that existed. It probably does not surprise you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we did have some difficulty reconciling our views in relation to industrial law, industrial relations and industrial governance. The evidence we heard from a variety of groups indicated a number of things. Firstly, flexibility in the workplace can be achieved in all manner of waysâthrough temporary employment, casual employment or part-time employment, for example. There are all sorts of ways for any employer with any wit at all to ensure that they have a flexible workplace. Indeed, what we were given by way of evidence was that amongst the OECD countries we have the most casualised work force. However, notwithstanding that, the majority of the committee decided, against the will of the four dissenting members, to recommend that government pursue strategies for further award simplificationâby reducing the number of allowable matters and encouraging greater work force customisation. Indeed, they also recommended that the government examine mechanisms to remove barriers to part-time and casual employment in industrial awards and other industrial arrangements.

If an employer in this country cannot use the current system in a flexible way then they really have no idea what opportunities they have under the current arrangements. You can employ people using fixed term arrangements, casual arrangements or part-time arrangements. What else is required to provide flexibility? I guess that when government members talk about flexibility they are talking about a one-way flexibility. Their idea of flexibility is really an assault upon the maintenance of some balance in the workplace for workers, who deserve a decent quality of lifeâand the capacity to balance work and familyâand some decency and dignity when they spend so much of their time in their workplaces. Instead, on this occasion government members of this committee blindly followed the ideology of John Howard, Peter Costello and other government frontbenchers and actually contradicted the evidence provided to the committee.

Finally, I had concerns about the disability support pension recommendation. We clearly see this so-called welfare to work proposition as a completely bogus proposition. There has been no money properly afforded to this area to ensure that people with disabilities will find genuine work. This is a way of placing people with disabilitiesâthe most vulnerable people in our societyâin a situation where they will not have the same amount of assistance. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the member for Gorton, the Deputy Chair of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation, on the excellent work he did on that committee. An increase in labour force participation is necessary to deal with the problem of Australiaâs ageing population. With an ageing population and a higher proportion of the population not of working age, it is necessary to have more of the people who are within working age actually in work. On that the government and the opposition are in the white heat of agreement.

speech.para: We also agree on the benefit of work for individuals. Work can provide a sense of achievement and a sense of worth. There are few things worse for a community than a sense of welfare dependency. This is apparent in some of the public housing communities in my electorate and other electorates where three generations of welfare dependants live side by side and young people have very few non-welfare-dependent role models. This report is a good exposition of the economic need to increase Australiaâs participation rate. I do not agree with all its conclusions, but I do think it has put the case well for urgent action to increase the participation rate.

Before I turn to Welfare to Work, I would like to talk about productivity and particularly research and development, which this report deals with in its early stages. As a nation, we need to invest more in research and development. I was drawn to the Australian Industry Groupâs submission to this inquiry, which pointed out that Australia and New Zealand are the only two countries in the OECD where private investment in R&D is less than public investment. We have seen R&D investment levels in Australia in recent years much lower than they were in 1996, and only now are they approaching the levels that they were at when the Keating government left office in 1996. Personally, I believe this governmentâs decision to reduce the tax concession for R&D from 150 per cent to 125 per cent to be probably the most backward decision it has taken in the realm of economics. The report correctly highlights the need for more R&D. The committee makes no specific recommendation about going back to a 150 per cent tax concession, but I think the thrust of the committeeâs report was certainly heading in that direction. The committeeâs work lends itself to that conclusion, and restoring the tax concession to 150 per cent would be logical place to start.

On another matter, the report correctly highlights the growing issue of brain drain, of people leaving Australia. Over the last five years, the number of Australian-born people leaving to live overseas permanently has doubled. Of course, many of these are young and well-educated people. There are two ways of looking at this. On the one hand this is a problem which the government and society need to addressâand I do not make a political point about this, because there is no easy answerâbut there are advantages and opportunities here.

I was drawn to a recent report by the Lowy Institute called Diasporaâthe world wide web of Australians, by Dr Michael Fullilove and Dr Chloe Flutter. The report deals with this issue of the growing number of Australians living permanently overseas and the wealth of talent and networking that Australians working overseas in very high-ranking positions can provide to Australia, particularly with the trade opportunities that that can create for Australia. The report calls on the government and the parliament to take this issue seriously, to develop those networks and to make it a major goal of our diplomatic corps to have links with the Australian diaspora living overseas.

The Lowy Institute report actually recommends the establishment of a parliamentary committee on the diaspora. Whether or not that is a good thing, I am not sure. But it is certainly something this parliament needs to consider, and it lends itself quite easily to the work of this committeeâs reportâthat the government and the parliament need to deal with the matter of more Australians living permanently overseas. On the one hand we need to take steps to encourage them to come back to Australia when they have learned great skills in places like America, Europe and Asia and to contribute to the Australian economy. But on the other hand, while they are living overseas, we need to encourage them to make the most of their experiences and the networking opportunities that are available.

I would now like to turn to the major part of this report, which is of course the issue of Welfare to Work. The committee concentrates on the issue of disability pension and parenting allowance, and it does this for good reasons. I wholeheartedly endorse recommendation 4 of the committee, which is:

quote.para: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government review the tax-free threshold, taper rates, effective marginal tax rates and income test stacking to maximise incentives to move from income support payments to increased participation in paid work.

speech.para: This was a bipartisan recommendation of the committee, as the deputy chair pointed out, but unfortunately it has not been taken up by the government. The government did not lift the tax-free threshold in the recent budget. Admittedly, it did propose a reduction in the lowest marginal tax rate from 17 per cent to 15 per cent, but this would be nowhere near as effective as Laborâs proposal of an extended low-income earners rebate, which would see the effective tax-free threshold at $10,000 a year. So Labor has taken up the committeeâs recommendations; the government has not.

In relation to taper rates, the governmentâs actions have been counterproductive. The taper rate for the so-called enhanced Newstart allowance is 60c in the earned dollar; however, the taper rate under the disability support pension is 40c in the earned dollar at low incomes. So the government has actually increased the effective marginal tax rate for people trying to move from the disability support pension into work.
An opposition memberâIt is disgraceful.

talk.start.para: âIt is disgraceful. Labor has taken up the committeeâs recommendations and the government has not. The government has failed to act to improve the effective marginal tax rates. NATSEM modelling has shown that the effective marginal tax rates of over 60 per cent are a real disincentive to work. Tax rates are more than 60 per cent under the governmentâs proposed Welfare to Work changes. So, again, Labor has embraced the issue of reducing effective marginal tax rates, reducing taper rates and providing increased encouragement for people to move from welfare to work. This government has ignored the issue. Just this week, we saw the government ignoring a range of parliamentary inquiries and reports, and this is another one where the government had a golden opportunity in the budget to take up the bipartisan recommendations of this committee and it has completely ignored it. The OECD has also identified reductions in the effective marginal tax rates as one of the most pressing needs for the Australian economy.

speech.para: Reduced effective marginal tax rates were an important part of the welfare to work reforms implemented in the United States in 1996 and Great Britain in 1998. These two nations have introduced earned income tax credits, which is one way of reducing the effective marginal tax rate. Whichever way is chosen, the government must take action to reduce effective marginal tax rates. We will not see real welfare to work reform until this happens.

In relation to the parenting allowance and the transition of sole parents from welfare to work, the committee also received some interesting submissions. I was drawn to the submission of Associate Professor Austen of the Womenâs Economic Policy Analysis Unit of Curtin University of Technology. I endorse her submission.
Part of that submission says:

quote.para: ... womenâs ability to successfully respond to labour market opportunities, without sacrificing fertility, will depend on support given to them as they try to balance their paid and unpaid working roles. The gender division of unpaid labour; institutional support such as childcare and elder care, and availability of parental and other forms of paid leave will be vital in securing both economic outcomes for the nation and the wellbeing of Australian women.

speech.para: I have said on other occasions in the House just how inadequate the governmentâs actions have been in promoting welfare to work amongst sole parents. The government has reduced sole parentsâ benefits by moving them onto an allowance that is lower than the one they had before. Worse still, the enhanced Newstart Allowance actually has a more punitive taper rate than the parenting payment, with a taper rate for low-income earners of 60 per cent instead of the 40 per cent taper rate that applies under the parenting allowance. Just as we saw with the disability pension, we see with the parenting allowance the government increasing the effective marginal tax rates for people trying to do the right thingâtrying to move from welfare to work. Instead of the government encouraging them, as its rhetoric says it does, it punishes them. The government takes an ideological stake and drives it through as it punishes people trying to move from welfare to work. If you believed the governmentâs rhetoric you would believe that it was trying to help people moving from welfare to work, but what it is doing is punishing people who are trying to move from welfare to work.

The government has also clearly failed to create anywhere near enough out of school hours care places to cater for sole parents returning to work. I note that even the Treasury, in its submission to this inquiry, says that women might find it easier to return to the work force with adequate and affordable child care. I would put it a little bit more strongly than the Treasury. The Treasury says child care might help; I think it is pretty obvious that it would help. But even the Treasury recognises the importance of child care. The government has not followed this up with adequate action. There will be 80,000 places created, but there is a shortfall already of 30,000 places. Before anybody moves from welfare to work, we have a shortfall in this country of 30,000 out of school hours places.

I make a prediction that the 80,000 places now being created will be woefully inadequate and that the government, perhaps in the budget next year or the year after that, will create more places. It will be forced into action, it will claim credit and say, âLook how wonderful we areâ, but really it should be creating all those places right now, as people move from welfare to work. Half of the funding for these places does not come online until 2008-09, while these reforms apply from 2006. Even when the extra positions do come online, they will be inadequate. The government will then create more positions, and will claim all the credit, but really it should be doing that right now.

The UK government has taken a very different approach to the Australian government. Despite all the measures of support and assistance that the Blair government has provided, it still does not require sole parents to work until the child in question is 16. In contrast, this government has provided hardly any support for sole parents to return to work, yet it requires them to seek work when the youngest child turns six.

There is also a contrast when it comes to assisting disabled people to return to the work force. Recipients of a disability pension in Great Britain are also able to access a personal adviser, who helps them develop an individually tailored plan to return to the work force. Government members should take note that, in addition, the Blair government has introduced a disabled personâs tax credit, at a cost of Â£120 million. Again, this reduces effective marginal tax rates for people moving from welfare to work.

So this government, in its wisdom, increases effective marginal tax rates, reduces support and pushes people back into the work force. The Blair government reduces effective marginal tax rates and puts Â£120 million into a personal work force access plan so that each person seeking to move from the disability pension into the work force has a personal adviser to help them work out their travel plans, how to get around on public transport in their wheelchairs et cetera. They get very personal and individually catered support from the Blair government, which still does not require sole parents to return to work until their youngest child is 16. This punishing government, by contrast, requires people to return to work when their youngest child is six.
A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ

interrupt.para: Sitting suspended from 10.50 am to 11.04 am

talk.start.para: âAs I was saying before the calling of a division, the contrast between the Blair governmentâs approach and the Howard governmentâs approach is stark. To continue that theme, in the area of child care the government of the United Kingdom has taken action to extend child care and out of school hours care. It has spent Â£330 million to provide out of school hours care for up to half a million people. It has also provided Â£100 million to improve training for child-care providers, taking all the steps necessary to encourage and support people as they do the right thing and try to move from welfare to work.

speech.para: The early figures in Britain on the number of people returning from welfare to work are encouraging and heartening. It is too early to say just how successful the British governmentâs scheme has been, but, as I say, the early figures are encouraging. I am not saying that the Blair governmentâs approach is perfect or that it should or could be adopted lock, stock and barrel in this country. However, one thing is clear: the Blair government has taken the approach that people on welfare often face great challenges in making the transition to work. The government of the United Kingdom has adopted the approach that these people should be helped and supported as they face the challenges involved in moving from welfare to work. The Howard government has taken the approach that the best way to encourage people to move from welfare into the work force is to reduce their benefits and to increase their effective marginal tax rates. Given a choice, I know which model I preferâand it is not the Australian model, I am sorry to say.

This is one of the most important economic issues facing our country. This report does a good job of outlining why it is so important. However, the Howard governmentâs reforms do not maximise the chances of moving people from welfare into work and they are based on bad economics. I hope the government listens to the alternative approaches, embraces them for the sake of our economy and listens to the unanimous views of this committee, both government and opposition, on the sorts of things that the government should be embracing to encourage people to move from welfare to work. I do not expect the government to embrace the minority report, although I hope it might, but I do expect it to embrace the unanimous report, which it has so far ignored. I encourage the government to do that.

talk.start.para: âAs a person who served on the Standing Committee on Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation for the entire period of the inquiry this report is aboutâfrom June 2003, when the terms of reference were given to the committee by Tony Abbott, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations at the time, right up until the report was tabled in parliament in March this yearâI want to put on the record my thanks to all those people who gave evidence to the committee and to the staff attached to the committee. It was very much appreciated by all of us. We learnt a lot from those people and from hearing about their experiencesâthe experiences of people within the work force, the experiences of people who tried to obtain work and the experiences of people who were involved in various industries, training organisations and unions. The committee received evidence from a wide range of people.

speech.para: During my contribution today I would like to go through some of the issues that were raised during the inquiry. I have to say that I strongly support the recommendations of the report that were unanimous and those which were contained in the dissenting report. I will spend some time going through the dissenting report later, but I would like to start with the issue of skills shortages. The committee received overwhelming evidence from a variety of people about the fact that there are significant skills shortages within the Australian economy and community. That evidence came not just from one group but from a wide variety of people.

Manpower Australia believes that Australia risks economic irrelevance unless its skills shortages are addressed. The shortages occur in a number of key areas. We need to address the shortages in those key areas if we are going to be competitive in the global market, but I really feel that the government has failed to address this issue of skills shortages and failed to address the fact that we are facing chronic shortages in the area of trades. We need to put significant investment into the area of developing and skilling up our work force. We do not need rhetoric. We need action. We need to listen to the messages that we are getting from organisations such as Manpower, Employment Services Australia and the Australian Industry Group. The message has come from a wide range of people that we have a chronic skills shortage in Australia. If we do not address that, we are going to become irrelevant.

We need to put significant investment into the area of developing and skilling up our work force. We do not need rhetoric. We need action. We need to listen to the messages that we are getting from organisations such as Manpower, Employment Services Australia and the Australian Industry Group. The message has come from a wide range of people that we have a chronic skills shortage in Australia. If we do not address that, we are going to become irrelevant.

I would like to spend some time discussing issues surrounding mature age employees. One of the most disappointing submissions that the committee received, from my perspective, was from Professor Saunders. Professor Saunders tended to write off mature age workers. He was of the opinion that it is a waste of money to try to retrain a blue-collar worker and get that person back into the work force. I find that highly offensive. At a time when we have an ageing population and when we need to encourage mature age workers to re-enter the work force, somebody who puts himself up as an expert says that these menâhe highlighted menâare irrelevant. These negative stereotypes that exist in the community affect Australiaâs ability to utilise a vital part of our work force.

I agree with the Treasurer when he says that we need to get more mature age workers back into the work force. We should value these people. They are a valuable asset to Australia. With ideas like those expressed by Professor Saunders, we will go backwards, rather than forwards. I believe it is possible to retrain mature age workers and that, if we make the proper investment, as a nation we will be rewarded.

One of the organisations from which the committee received evidence was Westpac. Their evidence was in stark contrast to the evidence that we received from Professor Saunders. Westpac have adopted a policy of employing mature age workers. They can see that this is of great benefit to them. It puts them in a very strong competitive position in relation to other banks. Westpac believe that mature age people relate better to older people when they come into the bank. Westpac are employing mature age people within the client service area. People feel a certain confidence when a mature age person serves them at the counter. Westpac have employed somebody who is in excess of 70 years of age. That is highly commendable. That is the type of approach we would like to see taken by businesses in Australiaânot the negative approach of Professor Saunders, but rather the positive approach of Westpac.

The level of unemployment amongst Indigenous Australians is a condemnation of what is happening in Australia. All the strategies that have been introduced have failed this group in our community. They are over-represented in our jails and they are well and truly over-represented in the unemployment figures. For too long the approach to addressing Indigenous unemployment has been to start another CDEP program. It is time we were serious about addressing this issue. Until we do, we cannot hold our head up high as a nation.

This brings me to people with disabilities. We received a large body of evidence relating to people with disabilities. The recommendation of this committee with regard to this issue is one that I dissented from. I have a long history of working with people with disabilities, helping them access employment. I spent 13 years working as a rehabilitation counsellor, helping people with disabilities enter the work force. The current proposal and the recommendation put forward in this report will undermine the ability of people with disabilities to enter the work force. The first thing that a person with a disability needs to have before they are prepared to enter the work force or are able to even think about entering the work force is confidence that they will not be worse off. You must appreciate that there is a big risk associated with it. A person with a disability could obtain a job and only be able to maintain that employment for a very short period of time. Once you go over the magic 15 hours a week that is being proposed by the government, it will cause all sorts of difficulties for these people.

To be able to assist a person with a disability successfully move from being on a disability support pension or Newstart, you need to have in place a proper program with a proper case manager. You need to have in place all the support that that person will need to successfully make that transition. If you have somebody who is moving from working in a manual occupation and is looking at entering something like a clerical position, you need to make sure that they have the proper ergonomic furniture, you need to have the workplace looked at and you need to make sure that you are not setting that person up for failure. One of the easiest things to do is get the job; it is maintaining the employment that is the difficulty.

When I was very new in the position of finding jobs for people with disabilities, I developed a relationship with a number of people who were going through a program. These people were alcoholics. When they were sober, it was very easy to find a job for them. I managed to find employment for five or six of them. Unfortunately, it was only for a very short time that they maintained their employment. One of those people ended up being murdered. Once they found employment they felt secure, they felt that they had money, they felt that they were okay and they were tempted to have a drink, and they did so. The reason they failed was that there was no proper support in place for them after they found that jobâat that time I was working as a disability officer with an organisation that only had placement procedures. Subsequently I worked with an organisation that provided ongoing support, and the outcomes were much better. So I say to the government: be very cautious about where you go with these disability support changes, because there can be very negative outcomes if the proper supports are not in place. It is long-term support that is needed. Unless that happens, we are going to be setting a whole lot of people up for failure.

I am sure members on the other side of this House do not wish to do that. I am sure they want to see people with disabilities succeed when they re-enter the work force. The Treasurer said in his budget speech that he would particularly target people with back injuries. Once again, that group needs to have the proper support in place, including the proper ergonomic furniture that I detailed earlier.
In the last couple of minutes remaining to me, I will turn to the dissenting report. Recommendation 1 of the committee states:

quote.para: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government pursue strategies for further award simplification by reducing the number of allowable matters and encouraging greater workplace customisation to suit industry and regional conditions.

speech.para: I cannot think of one occasion on which that proposal was presented to the committee. That was not the tone of the evidence we received. The government members took this up and ran with it.

We do not feel that casualisation and part-time employment is benefiting the Australian work force. Increased casualisation means less security in the future, which does not in any way benefit workers. If this government is truly about building a strong economy, workers need security so they can plan for the future, obtain housing loans, buy houses and care for their families. This increasing casualisation is not the choice of workers. Some people have been employed for seven years as casuals. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am very pleased to speak to the report on workplace participation. I was Deputy Chair of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Work Force Participation during the 40th Parliament but, unfortunately, the federal election was called while the draft report was being considered. As I did not rejoin the committee in the 41st Parliament I was unable to participate in the final presentation of this report, so I am particularly pleased to be given the opportunity to speak to the report today and to thank the member for Shortland, other members of the committee and the staff of the committee for their contributions and their assistance.

speech.para: The inquiry into the long-term unemployed was a valuable experience. The evidence submitted by so many individuals, organisations and stakeholders was challenging, and the inquiry was very much an eye-opening experience for me and my colleagues. This inquiry took place at a time when all the critical issues surrounding employment in this country were being discussed and debated, so clearly the report is current and very relevant. As a result, its recommendations will be helpful to government, to the opposition and to policy-makers alike.

I agree with the comments made by the committee chair, the member for Deakin, that the report tackles some of the critical issues that relate to building both the size and the capability of Australiaâs work force. Like all other members of the committee, I was concerned to hear evidence that, by the year 2030, Australia would have over 500,000 jobs with no-one to fill them. This is indeed an alarming prognosis and, if true, it means we must act immediately to address the looming work force shortage. At a time when alarm bells are being sounded about the skills shortage we are currently experiencing, it is imperative that we address these issues immediately or we will have no hope of averting a potential crisis 10 or 15 years down the track.

This report is pertinent, and its importance is also highlighted by the fact that the committee was almost unanimous in its recommendations. Of the 23 recommendations, there was unanimous support for 20, including the recommendations on apprenticeships uptake, on addressing long-term unemployment, on expanding and improving child-care assistance and services and on all but one of the recommendations relating to the disabled. These recommendations are of particular interest to me because they are of great relevance to the people I represent in the electorate of Calwell.

I have mentioned many times in this place that my electorate has a large number of residents on disability pension support. We also have a large number of young people who take up apprenticeships because we are fortunate enough to have the Kangan Batman TAFE in Broadmeadows. It should also be noted that this inquiry was undertaken in the context of an ageing population and recommendations 8 and 10 go some way to addressing the increasing issue of mature aged unemployment, which is another significant issue in my electorate.

During the hearings, what struck me most was that the evidence being given indicated a strong trend towards ageism in the work force. I remember then remarking that what the submissions were stating was consistent with what many of my mature aged constituents were telling me: there is a real sense of discrimination against you if you are seeking employment and are 40 years of age. If you are 40 and over, you have a problem getting a job if you are unfortunate enough to become unemployed. Many people reported that they were simply overlooked on the basis of their age, with their experience and skills not seeming to carry as much weight as they deserved. These reports have been backed up by figures from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission which show that the majority of complaints before them, in respect of age discrimination laws, claimed discrimination in employment, with 65 per cent of those claims being lodged by men. Equally, many mature aged workers who lost their jobs were low skilled and had virtually no chance of re-employment despite being keen and often desperate to be employed. Given that most of these mature unemployed are simply too young to be out of the work force, it is clear that we need to re-skill this work force and provide incentives to stimulate employment recruitment.

Similar problems are faced by the disabled, by Indigenous Australians, sole parents, migrants and the long-term unemployed with a lack of employer interest in giving them a go. If this yearâs budget is about increasing work force participation then addressing all areas of disadvantage and hurdles becomes imperative. It is vital that, if the Welfare to Work reform is to be successful, it must tackle and look at employer attitudes and practices and see what can be done to alleviate impediments on that level.

Twenty of the recommendations in this report have received unanimous agreement and should be acted upon immediately by the government. The remaining three recommendations, however, have not received unanimous support with opposition members producing a dissenting report covering recommendations 1, 9 and 14 because these committee members have substantial concerns about these recommendations. As my colleague, the member for Gorton, has already stated:

quote.para: Our concerns about these three recommendations go to the negative effect we believe they will have on industrial relations in this country.

speech.para: As a former member of the committee, I also cannot support these three recommendations. I stand with the dissenting report of the opposition members for the following reasons.

I would like to address recommendation 1 at this point. It concerns award simplification by reducing the amount of allowable matters and encouraging greater workplace customisation to suit industry and regional conditions. Along with opposition members of the committee, I do not support this recommendation because it does not reflect the evidence received by the committee, nor is there any evidence to support the assertion that reducing allowable matters in federal awards would improve work force participation. The evidence received by the committee did, however, suggest that improving award provisions by including provisions such as paid parental leave or job sharing would, in fact, increase work force participation. In accordance with that evidence, I support the proposed recommendation 1 in the dissenting report which recommends that the government pursue strategies to improve participation in the work force by encouraging employment conditions that are mutually beneficial, such as job sharing, permanent part-time and paid parental leave.

Recommendation 9 concerns part-time and casual employment and recommends that the government examine mechanisms to remove barriers to the employment of part-time and casual employees in industrial awards and other industrial arrangements. I agree with the dissenting report in not supporting this recommendation as the evidence received by the committee highlighted that whilst there will always be a place for part-time and casual employment there are problems associated with such employment including a lack of training, an inability to save or secure a home loan as a result of being a casual employee, and difficulties balancing home and work responsibilities.
