I have to agree with the member for Gorton, who makes the very valid point that Australia already has one of the most casualised work forces in the world and a large number of workers in part-time employment. Both groups are heavily represented in my electorate, and I knowâbecause I speak with many of themâthat a great number would prefer to have permanent, full-time employment.

Although I agree that there is benefit in having flexibility in the workplace that allows for increased workplace participation, this is true only to a certain extent. A great number of Australians, far from feeling that the existing flexibilities provide greater opportunities for participation, are in fact feeling a greater sense of insecurity and underemployment. As such, I do not support this recommendation. Rather, I support proposed recommendation 9 in the dissenting report, which calls upon the government to undertake a comprehensive study on the growth of casual and part-time employment and the social and economic effects of such growth, so as to identify the impact upon industry, occupations, gender and age groups and to identify the adverse social impact on employees and their families.

Recommendation 14 concerns disability support pension recipients and recommends that the government introduce increased work capacity provisions in determining eligibility for those in receipt of the disability support pension. We have seen this recommendation incorporated in this yearâs federal budget. However, opposition members did not support the recommendation when included in the report, and we do not support the budget provisions which implement the recommendation. Much of the evidence presented to the committee indicated how difficult it was for people with disabilities to gain employment, largely due to the perceived attitude of employers that people with disabilities were not preferred. They were often seen as a burden, with employers often not prepared to pay for the adjustments required in the workplace. Generally, there seemed to be an attitude that people with disabilities were not worthy of long-term investment.

Within my electorate are many examples of companies giving disabled employees a fair go, and these organisations include Brite Industries and a local employer, Mr Gary Marshall, whom I have spoken about in this place. He virtually makes it his business to employ people who are most at risk, and most of his work force is made up of people with some form of disability, people with long-term unemployment or mature age workers, who, as the member for Shortland said, when given an opportunity are able to perform tasks efficiently and successfully. It is being given the opportunity that is the problem. There is ample evidence to suggest that there is discrimination in the workplace against people with disabilities and the mature unemployed, in particular.

I talk to Job Network providers, such as Distinctive Options, that specialise in finding placements for people with disabilities, and they have an incredible number of problems convincing employers that their clients are worthy of being given a go. So there is plenty of empirical evidence to suggest that it is very difficult for these cohort groups to find employment or to be given an opportunity. I talk to many of these people in my electorate, and they always raise the difficulties of perception and discrimination that they have. It is a real shame, given that in particular the mature aged unemployed have a wealth of experience and potential which, at this stage, remains untapped and needs to be harnessed if we are to avert a skills shortageâthe 500,000 jobs with no-one to fill themâby the year 2030.

I raise my concerns about the prospects of a large number of people in the Australian work force who are out there ready, willing and able to work should they be given an opportunity, and I reiterate that we need to concentrate very much on employer attitudes. There are recommendations in the report that go some way towards providing encouragement for employers to take on what are, I guess, perceived to be the less desirable unemployed, but I think we are going to require more than just incentives; we are going to require a stick as well as a carrot.

If we are going to be successful in the Welfare to Work policy that the Treasurer trumpeted loudly in this yearâs budget, and if we are going to arrest the skills shortage and give Australians an opportunity to participate in the work force, we need to be mindful of the fact that employers have a great responsibility to do their part and not to pick and choose as they see fit. After having gone through that inquiry, it is very obvious to me that that was one of the greatest problems, one of the greatest obstacles, in the way of a lot of people getting meaningful and long-term employment.

In conclusion, I do agree with the dissenting report that was put forward by my colleagues. I support proposed recommendations 14 and 14A in the dissenting report, which recommend that a broader and more comprehensive study be undertaken and that the 30-hour per week work test for disability support pensioners be retained, given the difficulties I have outlined that people with disabilities have in gaining employment and then, as the member for Shortland said, in being able to maintain it.

I would like to finish by saying that throughout this inquiry all committee members agreed that paid employment is important in reducing social disadvantage and improving Australian living standards and all members agreed on 20 of the 23 recommendations. What is now needed is for the government to take up the initiatives put forward in this report and to implement the recommendations which were agreed upon unanimously. I thoroughly recommend that the government also adopt the additional recommendations from within the dissenting report.

As I said earlier, I think that the report comes at a critical time in the history of employment and the work force in this country. It makes some very sound and sensible recommendationsârecommendations that I believe will go a long way to assisting with improving work force participation. In particular, the report goes a long way to assisting those people who happen to be in groups that at present are disadvantaged in the work force to be given a fair go and an opportunity to improve their livelihoods and build upon their aspirations for themselves and their families.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to comment on the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation entitled Working for Australiaâs future: increasing participation in the workforce. I take this opportunity to comment on the recommendations which prompted a dissenting report by Labor members of the committeeâa dissenting report that it would seem from the Prime Ministerâs recent statement on industrial relations he clearly chose to ignore.

speech.para: Before turning in particular to the three recommendations of the dissenting members, I would like to record my support for the reportâs 20 unanimous recommendations. I believe that it is very important that the recommendations that were made by the committeeâincluding reviewing the tax-free threshold; reviewing effective marginal tax rates; improving transition to work programs; expanding child care and after-school and holiday care; and improving access to employment programsâshould be closely examined by the government if it is truly intent on assisting an increase in work force participation.

I also support the recommendations of the dissenting report. It seems to me that the Labor members of the committee have considered the evidence more closely and clearly have a better understanding of the concerns of the average Australian. It seems that the dissenting members of the committee are more aware of the concerns that Australians have in relation to casualisation of the work force. It is true that more employees are facing longer periods of part-time and casual employment. Gone are the days when getting a job meant simply accepting regular, full-time working hours. Some have dismissed this as a change in the composition and structure of work in Australia. Nevertheless, it is occurring, and that fact is certainly supported by statistical evidence. In particular, it is interesting that in the statistics presented in the report the proportion of males employed on a casual basis has doubled since 1988. Additionally, over that same period, from 1988, the statistics show that total employment involving casual employment has increased by 50 per cent.

The labour force statistics for April, released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, record that more than 2.8 million people were employed on a part-time basis. Granted, a number of them will be happy to be employed on a part-time basis, as it will enable them to pursue other activities while earning an income, such as raising a family, caring for aged parents or, indeed, studying. However, many people do want to work more. In 2004, the ABS released a report on the underemployed workers of Australia, which was particularly revealing of the views of part-time employees about their employment status. The ABS conducted a survey throughout September 2003 to provide empirical evidence for that report.

At that time the survey showed that 2.7 million people were employed on a part-time basis. Of this 2.7 million people, 23 per cent wanted to work more hours; that is, more than 600,000 people employed on a part-time basis wanted to work more. Examining the data further showed that, of those 600,000 workers, 58 per cent wanted full-time employment and 77 per cent, during the four-week period of the survey, had actively looked for work that would provide more hours. It is pretty clear from the results of that survey that the majority of these part-time workers wanted to work more and they were ready to start working more. The ABS report goes on to indicate that 90 per cent of those who wanted full-time employment were available to start immediately.

This situation has not changed. In the lead-up to my own by-election campaign, a constituent in Werriwa approached me and described his experience of entering the work force. The fellow was on a Job Network program and had found some part-time work. As he said, it was great; this was what he wanted to do. This work was probably not the best in the world, but he wanted to participate in the work force. He was very pleased to have gained the job. He sought to inquire of his conditions from his employer. He turned up there and was told that, from the next day on, he would be required to bring his own vehicle because he would be required to travel for work purposes. So he was required to drive his own vehicle not only to and from work but also in the course of his employment.

After his first week at work, he had only worked for three days. He said that he was pretty shocked when he got his first weekly pay. After taking into account that he was using his own vehicle not only to travel to and from work but also to run errands during the day for his employerâs business, he found that he was worse off than he was on his former program. So being keen to continue working, he went in the next weekâgranted, one day was wetâto be told that he would be required only one day that week. The company that he was working for and that he named for me would be well known to everybody; it would certainly be found on the ASX. That is the way in which employment practices are starting to perpetuateâand I am sure that Werriwa is no exception with circumstances like theseâand this is one example that was brought to my attention. This bloke is just an average fellow who is happy to pay his taxes. He wanted to participate in the full-time labour market and do his bit in looking after his family. He certainly saw the way in which the system is stacked against many individuals.

Given the fact that at the time of the last census one in four workers in Werriwa was employed on a part-time basis, this gentlemanâs case that he related to me could hardly be considered as isolated. But it gets worse than that. Not only do part-time and casual workers face greater uncertainty of income; because of their own financial instability they also find it difficult to access a number of other services that many of us would take for granted. Part-time and casual employees have greater difficultly accessing financial services. Due to the uncertainty surrounding their future incomes, part-time and casual employees often report that financial institutions are more reluctant to give them access to loans and lines of credit than they would be had they been in full-time employment. Most of us would know that to be a fact. The evidence presented to the committee suggested that casual and part-time employees may also face reduced access to training and skills development opportunities, which are obviously so crucial for people making that transition into full-time permanent employment or trying to pursue a career.

I am also quite sure that, if we had a closer look at those who have Centrelink debts, we would probably find that a significant number of those debtors are either part-time or casual employees, as they would find it even more difficult than the rest of us to accurately estimate their annual income. Hence, at the end of the year part-time and casual employees receive yet another setback when they are notified that they have managed to accumulate a Centrelink debt. I guess these are the rewards for being employed under the so-called flexible working arrangements.

I would also like to take the opportunity to support the recommendations in the dissenting report concerning employment conditions. Once again, when making recommendations pursuing further award simplification and encouraging greater workplace customisation and flexibility, government members of the committee seemed to substitute ideology for evidence. As someone with a reasonably extensive involvement in the Australian industrial relations system, having worked in it from all perspectives, I find it difficult to believe that further simplifying awards will result in greater participation in the work force. I think such an argument does not hold much weight, particularly when one considers the claim that 77,000 more jobs will be created if small businesses are exempted from unfair dismissal lawsâa claim that, when placed under some scrutiny before the Senate committee, was found to be seriously lacking.

My views are reinforced by the findings of the dissenting report. The dissenting committee members found that the committeeâs recommendations for reductions in allowable matters and greater workplace customisation were contrary to the evidence received. The dissenting members reported:

quote.para: On no occasion had evidence supported the assertion that reducing allowable matters in federal awards would have any bearing upon improving participation in the paid workforce.

speech.para: Work force participation will not be improved through award changes or even the erosion of hard won conditions in awards. It will not be improved by exempting small business from unfair dismissal laws or reducing the right of entry into workplaces. And it will not be improved by effectively sidelining the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, which, after all, has acted as the independent umpire looking to protect the interests of both employers and employees engaged under the system.

Increasing participation rates requires increasing opportunities for unemployed people to enter the work force. These opportunities will only emerge when the hurdles that people face when they are seeking a job are effectively addressed. To address those issues really does require us to focus on matters such as the effective high marginal tax rates; child-care places, so that they are more abundant to facilitate people being able to translate into the workplace; and more affordable training places, when the opportunities are there, for people to become job ready to re-enter the work force.

I have spent many years working closely with both employers and employees in business improvement programs and also representing workers as a union official. Bearing in mind this experience, I cannot recall one occasion when I thought that the employment prospects of Australians would be enhanced by reducing award conditions or by reducing the number of allowable matters. I am yet to be convinced that Australians who for whatever reason are not participating in the labour market at the moment believe this will encourage them to re-enter the labour market.

The Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education References Committee recently explored the stunning statistic this government used to justify excluding small business from unfair dismissal lawsâthat is, that small business will create 77,000 new jobs if exempted from unfair dismissal laws. The assertion was found to be unreliable and based on opinion and perception rather than on any accurate data. In much the same way, once the claim that reducing the number of allowable matters and increasing the flexibility in workplace arrangements is subject to some harsher scrutiny, I suspect that it will be found to be lacking as well. With regard to the recommendations on disability support pensions, I support the expansion and modification of the Job Network disability support pension pilot. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThis report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation titled Working for Australiaâs future: increasing participation in the workforce was tabled in the House of Representatives on 14 March 2005. Although I was not a member of this committee, I understand the importance of its findings and its recommendations to future work force participation in this country, particularly the participation of older workers and other disadvantaged groups.

speech.para: We are all aware that no longer do any of us have a career for life. Many Australians will have two, three or more careers over their working lives. I note that the committee was told that by 2030 Australia will have over half a million jobs with no-one to fill them. I note also the committeeâs determination, in the face of low unemployment levels, to assist the work force participation of those groups who have traditionally been called disadvantaged. These groups include Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, the long-term unemployed, young people, migrants, mature age workers and people with disabilities. This report recommends that these people should be assisted by government and that this assistance must be targeted and delivered in an appropriate way.

Some members in this place may know that in my previous career I was a manager with the old Commonwealth Employment Service. I came into the CES at the time when Paul Keatingâs Working Nation programs were being implemented. This was exactly the range of programs which case managed so-called disadvantaged job seekers to increase their work force participation. Under these case management programs, there was a range of programs to assist the long-term unemployed, people with disabilities, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, and sole parents. There was a whole spectrum of programs. Whatever level a job seeker was at, there was a program that they could fit into and that would take them right through to the reality of getting a job.

These programs included, at one end of the spectrum, training programs to assist people with literacy and numeracy skills and programs to increase self-esteem and to address personal issues that related to working. Along the spectrum were skills training and eventually to what were known then as job clubs, where people were assessed as being work ready and were assisted in applying for jobsâin getting their CVs together and in the actual physical activity of getting out there, knocking on doors looking for work.

Other programs included the Jobs, Education and Training program, which assisted sole parents. That program was delivered between the CES and the then department of social security. It provided a lot of assistance for sole parents to assist themselves into the work force, including subsidies for child-care arrangements. I believe that program still exists, but it has been decimated under the Howard government.

There was training for Aboriginal people, which was the specific area that I was working in. There were a whole range of programs to assist particularly young Aboriginal people into work. I had the satisfaction of seeing many young Aboriginal people commence and complete traineeships and apprenticeships and get themselves into work.

There were also programs called disability support panels. These panels case managed each individual with a disability personally to assist that person into a job. The panels consisted of somebody from the CES, somebody from the department of social security and somebody from the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service. Those people would then also go out and assist people to sell their skills to employers and actively encourage employers to take these people on.

I want to make a point in relation to work force participation of Indigenous Australians. There are seven pages in the report, from page 151 through to page 157, which deal with participation in the work force by Indigenous Australians. However, there does not seem to have been a recommendation from the findings of the committee relating to Indigenous employment. The committee did note on page 154:

quote.para: While significant numbers of Indigenous youth are being helped to gain employment through Job Network and the Indigenous Employment Programme ... more needs to be done to ensure they have the skills, job search techniques, confidence and motivation to benefit from strong economic growth.

speech.para: The report went on to say at 5.101:

quote.para: The Committee is encouraged by the broad range of these initiatives and the improvements in employment outcomes. However ... significant focus is required to support and foster further increase in participation in paid work.

speech.para: I find it a bit disturbing that, although there had been some focus on Indigenous employment participation, there were no recommendations coming out of this report. As I said, the programs that had been in place in the old CES under Paul Keatingâs Working Nation were either abolished or decimated on the election of the Howard government in 1996.

I want to move now to changes proposed in this yearâs budget to the disability support pension. I note the recommendations relating to these changes were dissented from by the Labor members of this committee. The dissenting committee members noted:

quote.para: ... that while the Job Network Disability Support Pension pilot has shown some promise in assisting people on the DSP to gain employment, there are areas which require greater investigation before any long term conclusions can be made.

speech.para: The dissenting members also said:

quote.para: Less than half of the pilot participants and less than a quarter of DSP recipients who initially met the providers were successfully placed in employment or education. If this sample is representative then more than half of the DSP population could be penalised by the proposed changes to the DSP eligibility requirements despite their desire to look for work.

speech.para: The concerns that we have in the Labor Party in relation to the changes to the disability support pension have been expressed in this place. They include concerns about the changes in the eligibility criteriaâthat is, eligibility for a person who has a disability will be changed so that the number of hours a person is deemed as able to work without losing eligibility will be reduced from 30 hours a week to 15 hours a week. From 1 July next year we are going to see two classes of disability support pensioner. We are going to see those people who are on the disability support pension who cannot work more than 30 hours a week but may be able to work between 15 and 30 hours a week and those people with a disability who will be forced onto Newstart allowance because they have been assessed as being able to work more than 15 hours a week.

These people are also going to see a drop in their incomes. Once we have a person with a disability who is deemed to be able to work more than 15 hours a week, rather than being supported by a disability support pension where all the support mechanisms are in place for that personâas well as assistance in concessions and a little bit more incomeâthey are now going to be forced onto Newstart allowance. They are going to have lower incomes than disability support pensioners, but they are going to have the same health concerns and they are going to need the same assistance in trying to look for work as they would if they were on the disability support pension. Those people with disabilities who can work more than 15 hours a week are being told, âYes, you must look for work,â but they are also being told âYou are not going to get the same support as a disability support pensioner to look for work and you must do it on less money.â

We must remember that people with disabilities or chronic illnesses have variances in their day-to-day lives. They can have good weeks and bad weeks and good months and bad months. This particularly applies to people with mental illnesses. If a person with a mental illness who is assessed as being able to work more than 15 hours a week, subject to the work activity test, goes off and gets themselves a job that they can do, the next week or the next month they might have a bad week and not turn up for work. That person is then going to be penalised when they go back to the Centrelink office to resume their unemployment benefits. They will be penalised for leaving a job. But they have left a job through no fault of their own; they have done that because they have a particular illness which has not been catered for under these arrangements. A lot of these people would be working if they could be working. If there were jobs out there that were for 15 or 20 hours a week, with flexibility and arrangements to adapt to their health circumstances, it would be great. But the unfortunate reality for a lot of the people with disabilities who want to work is that the jobs which should be flexible to their needs just do not exist out there.

I want to move on now to the long-term unemployed and particularly the mature long-term unemployed. We saw in April the release of the Productivity Commissionâs report on the economics of ageing. Following the release of that report, Sid Marris, in the initial paragraph of an article he wrote in the Australian, said:

quote.para: The first priority for tackling the mounting taxpayer costs of ageing should be getting unemployed mature workers into a job rather than simply raising the pension age.

speech.para: The Productivity Commissionâs report was titled Economic implications of an ageing Australia. The summary released with that report stated:

quote.para: People aged over 55 years have significantly lower labour force participation rates than younger people. As more people move into older age groups, overall participation rates are projected to drop from around 63.5 per cent in 2003 04 to 56.3 per cent by 2044-45.

speech.para: Following the release of that report, a couple of statements were made. An article headed âWork for over-55 jobless the keyâ in the Australian of Wednesday, 13 April 2005 states:

quote.para: Council on the Ageing-National Seniors chief executive David Deans said that with work force participation for men aged over 55 below 50 per cent in Australia, a low figure by international standards, mature-age workers and employers had to think differently about work and training.

speech.para: Â That is also reflected in this report. The article later states:

quote.para: Combined Pensioners and Superannuants Association NSW president Morrie Mufsud said ... increasing the pension age to 70 or 75 was inhumane and would put greater stress on the health of older people.

speech.para: Over the years that I have been representing my constituents of Charlton here, I have received much correspondence regarding the barriers facing long-term unemployed, mature age workers when trying to get back into the work force. I have one such letter here, written by Graeme Winter and signed by nearly 40 constituents, parts of which I would like to read into the Hansard. These quotes touch on just some of the barriers and challenges that face mature age workers. Graeme writes:

quote.para: Dear Madam,
As a person over 45 years and looking for work, I am writing to make you aware of the challenges faced in my area.

Canberra and Little Johnny and his team have got to think of the age group who left school before 1980 and did not do well at school, and in a lot of cases, as far as computers go, we did not have any.
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

These days, with our age group all you have are the newspapers and going to Centrelink and playing with the touch screens ... they donât seem to want you. You are hard pressed to find jobs for people from thirty to forty-five, then after that it just gets even harder. That is also for all the jobs in the paper and with all of them you need certificates and other tickets and ... it can cost you one hundred to a thousand dollars.
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦
Transport in this area is and always has been a problem.
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

I know a lot of people like me who have only had 1 to 5 months work at a time ... and have a very hard time because of our work history but it is because a lot of the places go broke or just get rid of us for someone younger.

If something is not done soon by Little Johnny and his party about us 45 years and older age bracket there are going to be more and more of us out there in nowhere land just getting older and more depressed and not having much of a future and again that affects our health and costs more money on health benefits.

speech.para: Graemeâs letter concludes by saying:

quote.para: So I just think we need a fair go and work that is 30 hours a week and more otherwise we will never get off the unemployment benefits.

talk.start.para: (Mr Wilkie)âBefore I call the honourable member for Parramatta, I would just remind honourable members that, when quoting from documents, they need to be careful that the quotes do not make unparliamentary comments, because they are unparliamentary whether they are quoted or stated individually.

âThis report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation is indeed a very welcome report. I would like to start by congratulating the members of the committee on both sides for what is an extremely substantial and much needed report. I particularly congratulate the members of the government, who have contributed to an analysis of the current situation in Australia which is quite often critical of their own government.

speech.para: There are two issues in my electorate which are regularly raised with me. The first concerns unemployment. In spite of the rhetoric about low unemployment, one of the most common issues raised with me concerns people unable to find a job. Whether it is single mothers, mothers returning to the work force, people with disabilities, older Australians, skilled migrants or members of the Indigenous community, the difficulty in finding work is still very much alive in my electorate in spite of the rhetoric about low unemployment.

The second issue which is regularly raised is raised by the small business community in particular, and in my electorate that is a vibrant community indeed. The issue for them concerns future growth. It concerns the ability to find skilled people to work for them. It involves the need for greater investment in research and development and for the building of export markets.

This report contributes greatly on both of those issues. I have learned a great deal from reading it, and I know I will find it extremely useful in working with people in my electorate. It is a comprehensive and serious report involving over nearly 100 submissions and over 20 days of public hearings, and again I thank the committee, particularly on the government side, for the courage to be constructively critical of the government.

Many of the recommendations imply a failure by the current government to seriously tackle issues of workplace participation, particularly in the areas of skill shortages and marginal tax rates. But it is interesting to note that when committee members from both sides of the House get together and have a proper look at what is happening there is general agreement on what needs to be done. Of the 21 recommendations, the vast majority were passed unanimously. That is a very good sign of the health of our democracy when people get together and work collaboratively.

We have a comprehensive report making largely unanimous recommendations which was tabled at the beginning of this year and yet, in spite of its quality, those recommendations were not incorporated in the budget. On occasion the Treasurer referred to some of the issues, but it is fair to say that he did not pick up the main recommendations of that report. This is indeed a lost opportunity. The members of the committee, and the members of the public who contributed to this inquiry, made an extraordinary effort in putting this report together and their work deserves much more consideration than it received. It is interesting to speak on this report now, after the budget, when it was actually written before the budget because it throws the budget into an interesting light. The main issues raised, particularly that of skill shortages, were not addressed adequately in the budgetâand nor, for that matter, was the whole issue of how we get Australians back into the work force.

Instead of taking the positive approach recommended in this report in the main the government took a punitive approachâa stick approachâto forcing people back into the work force. It is clear from the recommendations in this report and the substance of the report that there are far greater barriers to people returning to the work force than a willingness to do so. There is a recognition in this report that employment is patchy, a recognition that I really appreciate having spoken to so many people in my electorate who are having difficulty getting back into the work force. It clearly recognises that, while we can talk about the overall low unemployment rate, that rate is not enjoyed by some sections of our community, particularly the Indigenous community, women, older Australians, younger Australians and skilled migrants. I would like to raise a couple of examples that have come up in my electorate recently of people who are facing extraordinary barriers to their re-entry into the work forceâbarriers which this report addresses but which the government has failed to address in the budget.

My first example is of a 29-year-old woman who emailed me a couple of days ago. She is married and has three children between eight months and six years old. She is a stay-at-home mum. Before she decided to stay home with her children she was quite a senior person in the public sector. She resigned from her full-time job in July 2004 to be a full-time stay-at-home mum. Since then, she and her husband have reviewed their financial situation and decided that she needs to return to full-time work. They have a mortgage and a car to pay off and their wage is barely making ends meet so they feel that she needs to return to work. She does not have anybody to help with looking after her childrenâshe does not live close to her parents, for exampleâso she needs to send one of the children to before- and after-school care and two of the children to full-time long day care while she returns to work.

She went to Centrelink with an estimated income of $95,000 to calculate the familyâs child-care benefit and family tax benefit. After she considered those and took into account child-care costs, which would be $95 a week for one child and $185 a week for each of the othersâtotalling $515 per weekâshe realised that child care would cost $27,000 per year. That would be more than 70 per cent of her pay and larger than their mortgage payment. She then went on to calculate their net weekly income less their expenses and realised that if she returned to work she would be $50 a week better off than if she did not. After taking into consideration the effect that returning to work would ultimately have on her relationship with her children and the pressures it would have on her marriage, she just cannot justify returning to work for $50 a week. The budget announced that there would be 80,000 extra child-care places but, as she says, that is no use if the price is not regulated. In her area long day care is charged at $57 a day for under twos and $47 a day for children aged two to six. With three children, that is not something she can afford.

This woman asks in her email what incentive she has to go back to work, even though she wants to. She has discussed this issue with other mothers in her area and has found it to be a common story, as have I in visiting child-care centres around my area. The single biggest topic of conversation among mothers, both those working part time and those staying at home, is the difficulty they have in finding a way back into the work force.

The second example I have is of a young woman I know who has a mental illness. She is bipolar. She is an extraordinary young woman and was highly skilled before the onset of her illness. She has been on the disability support pension for quite some time. Through the intervention of a small group of people, she has managed over the last four or five years to find her way back into the work force on a part-time basis, and she is now managing to control her illness. She has not had a serious bout of depression and has not needed shock therapy for nearly 2Â½ years. She is now looking at a situation where she is able to work more hours and can get the work. But, of course, if she does that she will have to go off the disability support pension.

This should be a time of great rejoicing for this woman. She has been on that pension for many years now and, through considerable work by her and a surrounding group of supporters, she has found a way back into the work force and has taken back control of her life. She should be celebrating. Quite to the contrary, she has a recommendation from her psychiatrist that she not take up this option at this time, for the simple reason that if she does go back to work and then lapses back into her illnessâwhich undoubtedly she will; this is a lifelong illness that she hasâand has to return to the disability support pension at some point, she will go onto the new pension, not the old one. She also may not be able to get back onto it because of her capacity at this stage, when her illness is essentially under control, to work considerably more than 15 hours a week.

Because fear of the future is one of the triggers for this womanâs illness, her psychiatristâs advice is that she will be better off in the long term working only a few hours a week, rather than doing the considerable hours that she can. When you understand that this woman is one of the leaders in the fieldâthat when she does work she is an unbelievably productive person who makes a great contribution to those around herâit is really quite a tragedy. This is a case of a person who is ready to return to work and really should be returning to work, but the very measures which the government introduced to try to force her to do so are those which will prevent her from returning to the work force.

The third example is mothers returning to the work force. I have just given part-time work to two mothers who are returning to the work force after a long time, and I would encourage every employer out there to consider finding a way to get some of these fabulous mothers back into the work force. For a start, they are quite often more mature women who have had experience in the work force at a very high level and who are looking for secure, ongoing work at a level which allows them to go home at the end of the day and concentrate on their family. They are those rare workers who bring skills to a job they can quite often handle easily. They do that job with their full attention and go home at the end of the day to concentrate on something else. They are incredibly valuable people.

What I have found in talking with these people and the many who come to my office looking for a solution to their dilemma is that they have difficulty in finding work which allows them to balance their responsibilities to their families. There is difficulty in finding work, for example, which while secure and ongoing provides time off during school holidays. It is difficult to find work close enough to their own home to be able to get to and from work, and to include travel time, between the hours of nine and three.

This report makes quite a few recommendations concerning child care. Child care is absolutely essential to these women. It also covers in some depth the area of family balance, which is one of the biggest barriers for women returning to the work force. Again, the budget which was recently delivered does not address this issue in any real way at all. We still have in our community thousands of women with great skill and great willingness to return to work who simply cannot find appropriate working conditions in which to do so.

The casualisation of the work force is an increasing barrier to these women. I met two parents recently when I was doorknocking in the south of my electorate. The first time I went to their house I did not actually meet them; I encountered their six-year-old child at home on her own. Sheâand this is quite scary to meâopened the door to me, and I suspect she would have opened the door to anyone who knocked. There was a six-year-old child at home on her own. So I phoned these parents after hours, just to see how they were and if they needed some help, and I found two people who got up every morning not knowing whether they were going to work that dayâtwo parents on casual work in a low-skilled area who phoned the office each morning to find out whether they were going to work. They were on extremely low pay and under very poor conditions with three children, actually, under the age of 10, all three of whom were at various times at home on their own.

These parents did not have a support network that could help them. These parents did not have the opportunity to find regular child care; in fact, child care does not work on that kind of basis. They really were doing the best they could. They were doing their best to pay their rent; they were doing their best for their children. Unfortunately, the best is still an appalling situation for these parents. Not only could they not guarantee that their children could be picked up at school; as a married couple, they could not even commit to each other that they would be there on Saturday to pick up the kids from soccer or that they would take care of the kids tomorrow. These were two people who were completely unable to make the commitments to each other that parents need to make in order to stay together, let alone raise three children.

The recommendation in this report that even suggests increasing the casualisation of the work force is an appalling recommendation for people who live this kind of lifestyle now. Anybody, any parentâany person, reallyâseeking to save for their retirement, to educate their children or seeking to build a life needs some form of planning in their life. You simply cannot commit to a family and children and a future if you cannot look ahead and know that you can earn this amount of money, that your pay will come in on a regular basis, that your job is reasonably secureâeven if irregularâand that you can commit to the people around you to do the things you need to do to hold your relationships together.

The casualisation of the work force is not just about work force and it is not just about business. It is actually about family. It is an extremely negative trend that has made it incredibly difficult for people who are already struggling with low wages and poor conditions and, in many cases, a low education level, to build lives for themselves and their families. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Neville) adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: His Holiness Pope John Paul II

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 26 May, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That the House take note of the document.

talk.start.para: âI rise to continue my comments of condolence on the death of His Holiness Pope John Paul II. I had only just started the speech when this debate was adjourned. I had been talking about the Popeâs life during World War II, which was extraordinarily hard in his native Poland. During that time he had become a priest and he had earned his first doctorate. He continued his studies and in 1953 he defended his thesis and was appointed a professor of philosophy at the University of Cracow. The following year he joined the faculty of the Catholic University in Lublin.

speech.para: He moved through the ranks of the Catholic Church swiftly. In 1958 he was named the Auxiliary Bishop of Cracow and in 1964, when the communist government lifted a ban on such appointments, he was promoted to archbishop. He was promoted to cardinal in 1967 by Pope Paul VI. As a cardinal, he was required to attend in Rome at the untimely death of Pope John Paul I who, as we all know, died after just 34 brief days in office.

On 16 October, after three days of deliberations in the Vatican Sistine Chapel and after eight ballots, Wojtyla was elected to the throne of St Peter. At 58 he was the youngest pope in 132 years. âIt is Godâs will,â he declared when the vote was announced, âI accept.â With those simple words, he began one of the most extraordinary reigns of any pope, creating a legacy that touches all parts of the globe.

Pope John Paul II led the worldâs Catholics for 26 years, which is the third longest reign of any pope. His capacity to travel was one of the hallmarks of his period in office. He transformed what was traditionally a Eurocentric church into one with a global outlook. His destinations included the United Nations, remote islands in the farthest reaches of the Pacific, the plains of Africa, the slums of Latin America and the Mall in Washington. His visits included non-Catholic areas such as India and South-East Asia. His extensive travels made him one of the most recognised figures in the world. I well remember going to the local racetrack in Perth when the Pope visited and I can remember him walking by and greeting the assembled children, to our great excitement at the time. He drew enormous crowds on his two Australian visits, and these crowds were repeated wherever he went in the world. No corner of the world escaped the Popeâs attention, and his popemobile was a very familiar sight on the evening news.

On his travels he reached out to men and women of other faiths. Indeed, he did more than any other pope to open dialogues with other religions. He was the first pope to enter a mosque and the first pope to visit a synagogue. He championed relations with the Jewish community, and one of his first official acts was to send a message to the Jewish community in Rome. Under his guidance, the Vatican opened full diplomatic relations with Israel. The process of reconciliation reached a dramatic climax during the Popeâs visit to the Holy Land in March 2000. At Yad Vashem, Israelâs monument to the Holocaust victims, he declared:

quote.para: ... I assure the Jewish people that the Catholic Church, motivated by the Gospel law of truth, and love, and by no political considerations, is deeply saddened by the hatred, acts of persecution and displays of anti-Semitism directed against the Jews by Christians at any time and in any place.

speech.para: In Jerusalem, Pope John Paul II prayed at the Western Wall, the most sacred site in Judaism, and he also visited the Dome of the Rock and the al-Aqsa Mosque, the third holiest site in Islam. I note that the Chief Rabbi of Rome, who once prayed with the Pope, has said that he believes that Pope John Paul II ushered in a new era of Jewish-Christian relations. I also note that following the Popeâs death he was eulogised by both the Israelis and the Palestinians and that the President of Israel and the Prime Minister of the Palestinian Authority both attended his funeral. I know that sadness over the death of Pope John Paul II was shared by both Jewish and Islamic communities in my electorate of Stirling.

Perhaps the real defining moment of his reign as Pope was in the role that he played in liberating the people of Eastern Europe from the forces of totalitarianism. He worked tirelessly with the people in his native Poland, in Hungary, in what was then Czechoslovakia and in other nations that were locked into the rigid sphere of Soviet domination. He visited Poland not long after he was elected Pope, in June 1979, and that was his second overseas visit. He received a rapturous welcome from Poles across the whole country. He used his visit to highlight the plight of the Poles, and he developed close ties with the Solidarity movement and a man who would be Polandâs first post-communist president, Lech Walesa. He is reported to have told a Polish cardinal after his election as Bishop of Rome, âI have become the Bishop of Rome but I have not ceased being a Polish bishop.â

The Pope visited his homeland eight times during his reign. These visits increased the confidence of the Polish people and ultimately contributed to their throwing off the yoke of communism. This in turn contributed to the extraordinary demise of this evil doctrine in Eastern Europe and in the Soviet Union. With hindsight, I often fear that we forget how soul-destroying communism was to the people who were literally trapped behind the Iron Curtain. Pope John Paul II, by his presence and quiet dignity, challenged those regimes to respect the dignity of the people that they ruled over.

By visiting these nations he was able to highlight the deficiencies within the governance of these countries and to shine a bit of light into corners of the world where information and hope were not readily available. I am reminded of the quote attributed to Stalin, âHow many divisions does the Pope have?â Of course, the Pope had no armies but he did have the power of his own ideas and I think that history has proven him to be the victor in that particular conflict.

Pope John Paul II was a man of very firm beliefs. He did not gauge the prevailing view before making up his mind but decided what was right and then stuck to it. This is in marked contrast to some of the more fashionable clerics who seem to be more malleable in their views. In fact, I am often struck by how some members of the clergy now seem prepared to jump on whatever politically correct bandwagon happens to be passing. Even in death, many have criticised Pope John Paul II for the rigidity of his viewsâand I had better add that I do not share them allâbut I respect the fact that he remained true to what he believed was right.

I heard a person who was randomly interviewed at the time of the Popeâs death make a comment that went something like this: âIâm not what you would call a true believer, but I believed in him.â This person, in one simple statement, was able to express exactly what it was that made Pope John Paul II so special. He was a man who was able to gain the love and respect of not only people of Catholic faith but people of all religions across all nations. His presence and counsel will be missed by many. His recent funeral will be recorded as one of the most memorable events of this century for two reasons: firstly, the unprecedented outpouring of public grief and, secondly, the sheer number of world leaders that attended. I cannot think of any other event that would have brought such a diverse group together. It will be recorded as one of the defining moments of its time.

I would like to conclude my remarks by congratulating Pope John Paul IIâs successor, Pope Benedict XVI. I am sure that the whole parliament will join me in wishing him well in carrying out his extensive duties on behalf of Catholics the world over.

talk.start.para: âBorn on 18 May 1920 and dying on 2 April 2005, Pope John Paul II was Pope of the Catholic Church for almost 27 years, the third longest reign in the history of the church. He oversaw a momentous period in world history, providing a moral force for his followers in the latter half of the 20th century as he travelled the globe, determined to reach as many people as possible, in the process becoming known as the âpilgrim Popeâ.

speech.para: Pope John Paul II lent a spiritual force to his fellow Poles in the rise of the Solidarity movement, which went on to destroy a regime in the thrall of the communist ideology he so vehemently opposed. He also rallied against what he saw as the dangerously secular hedonism of the West, a spiritual malaise he saw as caused by an excessive adherence to materialism and consumerism. Unwavering in extolling his belief in the sanctity of human lifeâfor example, in his vocal opposition to abortion, war and capital punishmentâhe nevertheless expressed traditional Catholic values in his attitudes towards marriage, sexuality and the role of women in the church. Pope John Paul II was unstinting in his advocacy of social justice and in the rights of the individual. Yet some of his views could be seen as challengingâsome even divisive.

As a student in southern Poland, Karol Wojtyla intended to become a professional actor. With the occupying Nazi regime closing the university he attended, and under threat of deportation, he was forced to support himself by working as a stonecutter. In 1942 he entered the underground seminary run by the Archbishop of Cracow and was ordained a priest in November 1946. In 1958 the future Pope was named Auxiliary Bishop of Cracow and four years later he assumed leadership of the diocese, all the while publicly rallying against communism and oppressive state officials and also secretly providing supportâfinancial and otherwiseâfor opposition groups and, it is reported, often clandestinely meeting their leaders, who were on the run from the government. He was at the time the youngest bishop in Poland. In 1962 he contributed to the Second Vatican Council and within five years was elevated to cardinal. He refused to attend the First General Assembly of the Synod of Bishops due to a fellow Polish cardinal being denied a passport by the communist government. He participated in the papal conclave that elected Pope Paul VI and then, after the sudden death of Pope Paul VIâs successor, John Paul I, he found himself, a compromise candidate, at only 58 years of age, the 264th Pope of the Catholic Church.

The new pope proved in the eyes of many, including the leader of the Solidarity movement, Lech Walesa, to be instrumental in the fall of communism in eastern Europe. His visits to Poland in 1979 and later in 1983 provided inspiration to the Catholic Church and to the growing non-violent Solidarity labour movement. In the words of future Polish communist leader Jaruzelski, his first visit was the âdetonatorâ for a train of events that eventually resulted in the collapse of the communist states in the East and the fall of the Iron Curtain. No less a person than Mikhail Gorbachev asserted that the disintegration of the Eastern bloc would have been impossible without Pope John Paul II.

During his reign, Pope John Paul II became the most travelled pope in history, making more visits to foreign lands than all the previous popes combined. Many of these trips were to the developing world and to countries never visited by a pope before, drawing some of the largest crowds in history. For instance, his visit to his Polish homeland in 1979 drew over two million people, while his mass in Dublinâs Phoenix Park in the same year drew one million people, a staggering one-quarter of the population of Ireland. He oversaw the global expansion of Catholicism, especially in Africa. His second visit to Nigeria saw the Pope canonize a Nigerian monk, greatly enhancing the Popeâs popularity in the region. Pope John Paul II was committed to spreading the influence of the church across the globe to Catholics and non-Catholics alike. I vividly remember his visit to Perth and our great family outing. We sat on a rug at the showgrounds for many hours to attend mass there.

Pope John Paul II, speaker of six languages, was determined to overcome religious divides, stressing the peace inherent in all religions. During his ceaseless travels he made several historical overtures to divergent faiths. He met with the Dalai Lama no fewer than eight times, finding common ground with a spiritual leader who had also suffered under communism. He was the first Catholic Pope to visit and pray in an Islamic mosque, and he subsequently visited the mosque where John the Baptist is understood to be buried. He was also the first pope to visit the United Kingdom, meeting the head of the Church of England, Queen Elizabeth II. In a powerful gesture at the time of the Falklands War, a battle he strongly spoke out against, he knelt to pray with the then Archbishop of Canterbury.

However, despite significant stumbling blocks, it could be said that his greatest success was in bridging the divide between the Catholic and Jewish faiths, with a Jewish-American organisation declaring:

quote.para: ... more change for the better took place in his 27 year Papacy than in the nearly 2000 years before.

speech.para: Such approval stemmed from several actions undertaken by Pope John Paul II. He made a formal apology for the missteps committed by the Catholic Church over the last 2,000 years, expressly apologising for the acts of anti-Semitism committed by the church. He visited the Auschwitz concentration camp in his Polish homelandâthe first pope to do soâand, in his historic visit to Israel in 2000, he left a written apology to the Jewish people in the Wailing Wall in Jerusalem. Furthermore, he issued an apology for the conspicuous silence that fell over the Catholic Church during the time of the Holocaust, and he became the first pope in modern times to visit a synagogue. Pope John Paulâs ecumenical efforts were instrumental in the emergence of a new, outward-looking Catholic Church.

The Popeâs belief in the sanctity of human life expressed itself in his stance against contraception, euthanasia and abortion. Yet his belief in the rights and inherent dignity of the individual also manifested itself in his fervent opposition to war. To the Pope, all war was unjust and, in his words, a defeat for humanity. He asserted that all avenues must be exhausted before contemplating aggressive means, a position that logically led to his opposition to the war in Iraq. The Pope sent a cardinal from the Vatican to meet with the President of the United States to relay his opposition to the actions of the coalition of the willing, seeing any unilateral aggression as a breach of international law and seeing diplomacy through the United Nations as paramount. By speaking out almost daily on the injustice of the war, the Pope provided moral support to the millions of antiwar protesters throughout the world. This search for a political solution was emblematic of the Popeâs reign, with the Vatican sending diplomats to the Middle East, East Timor, the Balkans, Africa and Asia in the search for peace during intense periods of conflict.

The Popeâs influence was strongly felt in his shaping of the Catholic Church as a defender of human rights and of the poor and disenfranchised. He was a vocal supporter of Jubilee 2000, the campaign to provide debt relief to the beleaguered nations of Africa. He issued apologies for the suppression of ethnic and indigenous groups by past Catholic missionaries and was a strong supporter of the rights and aspirations of indigenous peoples, creating in 1992 a foundation for the indigenous peoples of Latin America to promote the development of rural communities among the campesinos of Latin America and the Caribbean and the African-American peoples.
In a speech given here in Australia in Alice Springs in 1986, the Pope spoke compassionately and eloquently in support of the stolen generation and Aboriginal land rights. He said:

quote.para: Let it not be said that the fair and equitable recognition of Aboriginal rights to land is discrimination. To call for the acknowledgment of the land rights of people who have never surrendered those rights is not discrimination ... Christian people of good will are saddened to realiseâmany of them only recentlyâfor how long a time Aboriginal people were transported from their homelands into small areas or reserves where families were broken up, tribes split apart, children orphaned and people forced to live like exiles in a foreign country. The establishment of a new society for Aboriginal people cannot go forward without just and mutually recognised agreements with regard to these human problems even though their causes lie in the past.

speech.para: If only such emphatic words were more prevalent today. The Pope decried the structural excesses of neo-liberalism and economic rationalisation, highlighting the devastating effect such policies have upon the poor and marginalised. As he stated, the wealth produced often remains in the hands of only a few.

The Pope was a champion of workersâ rights. I have already touched upon his unwavering support of the Solidarity trade union in his homeland. In his encyclia the Pope affirmed the right of workers to join trade unions. In his 1981 statement, âOn Human Workâ, the Pope called for:

quote.para: ... ever new movements of solidarity of the workers and with the workers. This solidarity must be present whenever it is called for by the social degrading of the subject of work, by exploitation of the workers and by the growing areas of poverty and even hunger.

speech.para: The Pope continued by asserting the right of trade unions to exist and the right of workers:

quote.para: ... to form associations for the purpose of defending the vital interests of those employed in the various professions. These associations are called labor or trade unions... The experience of history teaches that organizations of this type are an indispensable element of social life.

speech.para: In another encyclical, Pope John Paul II reaffirmed the need for trade unions to:

quote.para: ... defend workersâ rights and protect their interests as persons while fulfilling a vital cultural role so as to enable workers to participate more fully and honorably in the life of their nation and to assist them along the path of development.

speech.para: Elsewhere he stressed the importance of a just wage, health care and workers compensation and the right to a retirement pensionâall mainstays of the labour movement. The Popeâs compassion and sense of justice meant he instinctively sided with the workers.

As progressives rightly point out, Pope John Paul IIâs reign was not without fault. His views on contraception and the role of women in the church have been highly controversial, and he has rightly been admonished for his slow response to sexual abuse scandals within the church. Yet Pope John Paul II has had an extraordinary impact upon the Catholic Church and hence upon the world, transforming the church under his charismatic leadership into an activist church based upon social justice, human rights and dignity and respect for the individual. A man of great integrity, compassion and conviction, his success was due to his ability as a world statesman to reach across to Catholics and non-Catholics alike. His words and actions during his 27-year reign will continue to reverberate. I wish to congratulate his successor, Benedict XVI, who, as confidante and right-hand man to the previous Pope, is no doubt aware of the great demands and requirements of the pontificate. I wish him well as he guides the Catholic Church into a new era.

talk.start.para: âI rise to express my condolences, along with those of other members of this parliament, to members of the Catholic Church, particularly the Catholic constituents of my electorate of Hinkler and the Catholics of the diocese of Rockhamptonânotwithstanding the fact that I am a Catholic myself. I think John Paul IIâs passing will be one of the seminal events of this new century that we live in because of the profound effect he had on so many lives.

speech.para: I wish to express my thanks for the life and work of John Paul II, Karol Wojtyla, who passed away on 2 April this year. He was truly a remarkable man. His 26-year papacy was marked by his drive to create a more inclusive churchâone that extended the hand of friendship to all faithsâand by his truly global appeal as a man of the masses. He made his first communion at the age of nine and was confirmed at 18. When the Nazi occupation of his native Poland occurred, he had to work in a quarry from 1940 to 1944. No doubt it was in this environment that he developed his love for the workers of the world and for the unionists whom he served so well. He then worked in the Solvay chemical factory, to earn a living and to avoid deportation to Germany. In 1942 he became aware of his calling to the priesthood and started courses in a clandestine seminary in Cracow.

After the Second World War he continued his studies at the major seminary in Cracow, being ordained there on 1 November 1946. His work took him to Rome and during his vacations he exercised his pastoral ministry amongst young Polish immigrants in France, Belgium and Holland. In 1948 he returned to Poland and until 1951 he was vicar of various parishes in Cracow and chaplain for the university students. Then he again took up studies in philosophy and theology. This led, 10 years later, to his being appointed the auxiliary bishop of Cracow by Pope Pius XII. He was consecrated on 28 September 1958. On 13 January 1964 he was nominated Archbishop of Cracow by Pope Paul VI, who made him a cardinal on 26 June 1967. His was a truly remarkable rise. In 1978 he became the 263rd successor to St Peter and the first non-Italian pope since Hadrian VI in 1522.

John Paul II has a special place in history. He made the worldâs business his business, especially in regard to human rights. Perhaps he will be best remembered for helping to deliver 400 million people from communist slavery. His profound effect on Eastern Europe was summarised by graffiti scrawled on one of the banners of the Polish communist state. The banner read, âThe party is for the people.â A courageous Pole had added to this banner, âBut the people are for the pope.â With his support of the free union movement Solidarity he not only created a new way of life for the working people of Poland and eventually all the people of Poland but also, through his influenceâprobably more than that of any other person in the 20th centuryâcontributed to the breaking down of communism in other countries. It was not long after communism fell in Poland that other communist states fell like dominoes across Eastern Europe, with East Germany and eventually Russia itself abandoning communism as a way of life.

As a young Pole, John Paul II saw the Holocaust up close, and he grasped its radical significance for the church. He went on to make it his goal to heal the rift with Judaism, and this became a key element of his 26-year papacy. He apologised, as one of the previous speakers said, for the sins the church had committed against the Jewish people. His outreach involved ridding Christian education material of any anti-Semitic themes, visiting synagogues, pointing to the Holocaust as a permanent point of moral reckoning and reaffirming the rights of Jews to be at home in Israelâwhich the Vatican formally recognised as a state in 1994.

No other pope travelled so widely and encountered so many individuals as John Paul II. He was estimated to have effectively circled the globe 27 times to deliver his message during his pontificate, including two visits to Australia. I can remember being in the grandstands of the QEII stadium in Brisbane, not long after the Olympic Games, and the tremendous atmosphere there. There was an Anglican or Lutheran pastor in front of meâI could not quite tell. I could see that he and his wife were tremendously moved by the fact that the Pope had come to Brisbane.

During his 1986 visit, the Pope visited every state and territory and attended 38 functions in just 6Â½ days. One of the major events during that visit was a mass at Flemington Racecourse. John Paul II spoke directly to the young people of Australia, saying:

quote.para: Young people of Australia, I ask you: does your God have a part in your hopes and ambitions for the Australia of tomorrow? Do you dream of an Australia in which the poor and the downtrodden, the disadvantaged and the lonely, the spiritually blind and those struggling to make sense of their lives, will be sustained by the hands of a loving God? Do you realise that God has no other hands but yours to stretch out to those in need?

speech.para: What strong and lovely words to a young nation and to the young people of a young nation.

I remember his second visit to Australia, in 1995, when he came here to beatify Mother Mary MacKillop. I remember a parliamentary debate not unlike this one. One of the members opposite would probably remember it, as would you, Mr Deputy Speaker McMullan. I think it was the longest debate on a private memberâs business motion that we had ever had. Just about everyone in the parliament wanted to speak on it. It was about the beatification of Mary MacKillop. That was largely inspired and brought to its climax by the Popeâs visit to Australia.

While most of his predecessors rarely ventured beyond the walls of the Holy See, John Paul II took the Catholic Church on the road, ministering to millions of the faithful, who were quite ecstatic in his presence. Interestingly, I met him quite by chance at the Vatican. I was there at the end of a parliamentary delegation trip and was on a private visit on the way home. Australiaâs Deputy Ambassador to the Holy See was going to the Vatican that day and invited me to join him. The visit was very fulsome. The deputy ambassador took me through various parts of the Vatican. He showed me where the next consistory was going to be heldâthat new motel type facilityâand took me up to meet some of the staff of the secretariat of state. There were no official tickets. I just happened to be behind the official enclosure.

When the Pope had finished blessing the sick and saying the prayers he delivered that day, he went along the steps of St Peter and was photographed with the various official groups that were there. I think there was a band from Austria, and the University of Rome were there. When he had finished, he was right at the edge of the steps of St Peter and he walked back down to a group of seminarians and across the enclosure where I was standing. I saw him look at his watch when I was about as far away as I am now from the opposition members. I said to my wife, âI think weâve missed out.â All of a sudden, he seemed to get another spurt of life and came down along the next row. That is how I met him.

He certainly had an ecstatic presence; there is no doubt about that. In his travels around the world, he went to the church in Africa, Latin America and Asia, where the church was struggling in a different way from the West, where the church was struggling to maintain its flock and to maintain its focus on Christian values. He seemed to be able to stimulate each group in a different way.

Around 18 million pilgrims participated in his general audiences, and this figure does not take into account the other, special audiences and religious ceremonies which he held. John Paul II met numerous government personalities during his 38 official visits, 738 audiences and meetings with heads of state, and 246 audiences and meetings with prime ministersâan extraordinary record. His desire for closeness with people almost led to his death, as is well recorded. In 1981 he was shot and seriously wounded by a Turkish fanatic in St Peterâs Square, but, more to the point, he forgave this man and frequently visited him in prison.

The longevity of the Pope allowed him to appoint all but three of the 117 cardinals who were to choose his successor. The clarity that he left the church was, I think, an important feature in the quick decision of the cardinals to appoint Joseph Ratzinger as Benedict XVI. I, along with other members, extend my congratulations to Pope Benedict XVI.

Probably the greatest legacy of Pope John Paul IIâfrom my perspective, not from an international perspectiveâwas the fact that he was a champion for the light, for decency and for high moral values, particularly in the great moral dilemmas of our time. He certainly copped a lot of criticism for his view on contraception, yet it was not based so much on an ideological, Catholic Church position as a consistency of view regarding the preservation of life. It did not extend just to contraception; it was equally forceful in the case of abortion, euthanasia and, more recently, stem cell research. The Pope spoke with a clarity that sometimes not all Catholics liked to agree with, but I think that, grudgingly, they knew he was right. I think that is one of the reasons why he had such a profound effect: he never varied from the truth. The religions of the world get into trouble when they start to play with the truth, when they alter things at the margins. We have seen that happen with a number of Christian churches in recent times.

Pope John Paul II was the greatest pontiff of modern times. He was a warrior for freedom and human dignity and was a contemporary Catholic philosopher without peer. He was a pilgrim, a thinker and a man of peace. We were all diminished by his passing on 2 April but are the richer for his spirituality and his vision.
Debate (on motion by Mr Quick) adjourned.
